Preface
have not written this book for other teachers of
theology (though
many of them will read it)_
have written
students
and not only for

[0 know the central
doctrines of the Bible in greater depth:
This
why
have called the book
An Introduction
Biblical
Doctrine_
have tried t0 make ir understandable even for Christians who have never

have avoided
rechnical

explaining them:
And most of the chapters can be read on their own_
that
someone can begin at any chapter and grasp
without having read the earlier
material:
Introductory studies do not have t0 be shallow or simplistic.
am convinced
that most Christians are able to understand the doctrinal teachings of the Bible
in considerable depth; provided that
are
presented clearly and without the
use of highly technical
language: Therefore
have nor hesitated
treal
theological disputes in some detail where
seemed necessaly.
Yet this book; despite its size, is still an introduction t0 systematic theology:
Entire books have been written
bout the topics covered in each chapter of
this book, and entire articles have been written about many of the verses
quoted in this book: Therefore each chapter is capable of opening out into
additional study in more breadth or more depth for those who are interested_
The bibliographies at the end of each chapter give some help in that direction.
The following six distinctive features of this book grow out of my convictions
about what systematic
theology is and how
should be taught:
1. A Clear Biblical Basis for Doctrines. Because
believe that theology
should be explicitly based on the teachings of Scripture, in each chapter
have attempted t0 show where the Bible gives support for the doctrines under
consideration: In fact; because
believe that the words of Scripture
themselves have power and authority greater than any human words_
have
not just given Bible references;
have frequently quoted Bible passages at
length so that readers can easily examine for themselves the scriptural
evidence and
that way be like the noble Bereans_
who were
examining the
scriptures daily tO see if these
were S0
(Acts
17:11). This conviction
about the unique nature of the Bible as God' $ words has also led t0 the
inclusion of
Scripture memory passage at the end of each chapter:
hope
or
using
they
things -
2. Clarity in the Explanation of Doctrines
do not believe that God
intended the study of theology to result in confusion and frustration. A student
who comes out of
course in
theology filled only with doctrinal uncertainty
and
thousand unanswered questions is hardly
able t0 give instruction in
sound doctrine and also t0 confute those who contradict it" (Titus 1.9).
Therefore
have tried t0 state the doctrinal
positions of this book clearly and
show where in Scripture
find
convincing evidence for those positions:
do not expect that everyone reading this book will agree with me at every
point of doctrine;
do think that every reader will understand the positions
am arguing for and where Scripture can be found to support those positions.
[think it is only fair tO readers of this book t0 say at the beginning what my
own convictions are regarding certain points that are disputed within
evangelical Christianity
hold to
conservative view of biblical inerrancy;
very much in agreement with the "Chicago Statement" of the International
Council on Biblica
Inerrancy (chapter
and
appendix
and
traditional
Reformed position with regard to questions of God'$ sovereignty and man'$
responsibility (chapter 16), the extent of the atonement (chapter 27), and the
question of predestination (chapter 32). Consistent with the Reformed view;
hold that those who are truly born again will never lose their salvation
(chapter 40)_
with
regard to male-female relationships,
argue for
view that
is neither traditional nor feminist; but "complementarian'
~namely; that God
crealed
Mall
and woman equal in value and personhood, and equal in bearing
his image, but that both creation and redemption indicate some distinct roles
for men and women in
(chapter 22) and in the church (chapter 47).
On church government,
advocate

argue for
baptistic view of baptism; namely; that those who give

hold that

phrase best applied to conversion; and

(chapter 39); moreover; that all the gifts of the Holy Spirit mentioned in the
New Testament are still valid for today; but that
apostle" is an office_
noc
gift, and that office does not continue today (chapters 52, 53).
believe that
Christ $ second coming could occur any day; that it will be premillennial
that is_
that it will mark the beginning of his thousand-year reign of perfect

but thar
will be post-tribulational
that is_
that many
Christians will go through the

This does not mean that
ignore other views
Where there are doctrinal
differences within
evangelical Christianity
have tried t0 represent other

disagree with them; and t0 give references
marriage
grear
the best available defenses of the opposing positions. In

3. Application to Life_
do not believe that God intended the study of
theology
be dry and boring-
is the study of God and all his
works!
is meant [0 be lived and
prayed and sung! All of the great
doctrinal writings of the Bible (such as Paul 's epistle t0 the Romans) are full
of praise to God and personal application t0 life. For this reason
have

at the end of each chapter, as

hymn related to the topic of the chapter: True theology
"teaching
which accords with
godliness'
Tim. 6.3), and

worship_
Focus On the Evangelical World:
do not think that
[rue
system of
theology
can be constructed from within what we may call the "liberal"
theological
tradition
that is, by people who
the absolute truthfulness of
the Bible_
who do not think the words of the Bible t0 be God' s
words
(see chapter
on the authority of Scripture). For this reason, the other writers
interact with in this book are mostly within what
today called the larger
conservative
evangelical" tradition
from the great Reformers John Calvin
and Martin Luther; down to the writings of evangelical scholars today
write
as an
evangelical and for evangelicals.
This does not mean that those in the
liberal tradition have
valuable t0 say; it simply means that differences

EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Definition
Systematic Theology
What is
systematic theology? Many different definitions have been
given;, but for the purposes of this book the following definition will
be used: Systematic theology is any Study that answers tne question,
What does the whole Bible teach us today?
about any given
topic:
This definition indicates that systematic
theology involves
collecting and understanding all the relevant passages in the Bible
various topics and then summarizing their teachings clearly so
that we know what to believe about each topic
Relationship to Other Disciplines
The emphasis of this book will not
therefore be on historical theology (a historical study of how Christians in
different periods have understood various theological topics) or philosophical
theology (studying theological topics largely without use of the Bible
but
using the tools and methods of philosophical reasoning and what can be
known about God from observing the universe
apologetics (providing
defense of the truthfulness of the Christian faith for the purpose of
convincing
unbelievers). These three subjects; which are worthwhile subjects for
Christians
pursue; are sometimes also included in
broader definition of
the term systematic theology: In
some consideration of historical,
philosophical, and apologetic matters will be found at points throughout this
book:
is because historical
study informs uS of the insights gained and
the mistakes made by others previously
understanding Scripture;
philosophical study helps 4s understand right and wrong thought forms
common in our culture and others; and apologetic study helps uS
the
teachings of Scripture
bear on the objections raised by unbelievers
But
Why
fact,
This
bring
these areas of study are not the focus of this volume; which rather interacts
directly with the biblical text in order t0 understand what the Bible itself says
us about various theological subjects
If someone prefers t0 use the term systematic theology in the
broader sense just mentioned instead of the narTow sense which has
been defined above
it will not make much difference
Those who
use the narrower definition will agree that these other areas of study
definitely contribute in
positive way [0
understanding of
systematic
theology; and those who use the broader definition will
certainly agree that historical
theology; philosophical theology, and
apologetics can be distinguished from the process of collecting and
synthesizing all the relevant Scripture passages for various topics_
Moreover; even though historical and philosophical studies do

and it is therefore appropriate t0 spend some time
focusing

process of analyzing the teaching of Scripture itself.
Systematic theology; as we have defined it, also differs from Old
Testament theology; New Testament theology; and biblical theology
These three disciplines organize their topics historically and in the

"Biblical

has
technical meaning in theological studies_
It is the larger category that contains both Old Testament

Biblical

teachings

Yet there is

Systematic theology, on the other hand,

A Note on Two Objections to the Study of Systematic Theology
#The Conclusions Are
Too Neat' to be True.
Some scholars look with
suspicion at systematic theology when
or even because
teachings fit
rogether in
noncontradictory way: They object that the results are
too neat"
and that systematic theologians must therefore be squeezing the Bible $
teachings into an artificial mold, distorting the true meaning of Scripture
get an orderly set of beliefs
To this objection LWo responses can be made: (1) We must first ask
the people making the objection
tell us at what specific points
Scripture has been misinterpreted
and then we muSt deal with the
understanding of those passages. Perhaps mistakes have been made;
and in that case there should be corrections
Yet it is also possible that the objector will have no specific
passages in mind, O no clearly erroneous interpretations tO point tO
in the works of the most responsible
evangelical theologians. Of
couise _
incompetent exegesis can be found in the writings of the
less competent scholars in any field of biblical studies, not just in
systematic
theology; but those "bad examples"
constitute an
objection not against the scholar's field but against the incompetent
scholar himself:
It is very important that the objector be specific at this point
because this objection is sometimes made by those who
perhaps
unconsciously
have adopted from Our culture
skeptical view of
the possibility of finding universally true conclusions about
anything, even about God from his Word. This kind of skepticism
regarding theological truth
especially common in the modern
university world where "systematic theology'
-if it is studied at all
is studied only from the perspectives of philosophical theology
and historical
theology (including perhaps
historical study of the
various ideas that were believed by the early Christians who wrote
the New 'Testament; and by other Christians at that time and
throughout church history) In this kind of intellectual climate the
study of "systematic theol
as defined in this chapter would be
considered impossible; because the Bible would be assumed to be
merely the work of many human authors who wrote out of diverse
cultures and experiences over the course of more than one thousand
years: trying
find
what the whole Bible teaches'
about any
subject would be thought nearly as hopeless as trying to find "what
all philosophers teach" about some question; for the answer in both

often

evangelicals who see Scripture as the product of human and
divine authorship, and therefore as
collection of
that
teach noncontradictory truths about God and about the universe he
created_
(2) Second,
must be answered that in God'$ own mind, and in the
nature of reality itself; true facts and ideas are all consistent with
one another: Therefore if we have accurately understood the
of God in Scripture we should expect our conclusions tO
"fit together" and be mutually consistent: Internal consistency;
is an argument for; not against; any individual results of systematic
theology:
#The Choice of Topics Dictates the Conclusions_
Another general
objection t0 systematic theology concerns the choice and arrangement of
topics, and even the fact that such topically arranged study of Scripture, using
categories sometimes different from those found in Scripture itself, is done at
all Why are these theological topics treated rather than just the topics
emphasized by the biblical authors, and why are the topics arranged in this
way rather than in some Other way? Perhaps
this objection would say
our
traditions and our cultures have determined the topics we treat and the
arrangement of topics,
that the results of this systematic-theological study
of Scripture; though acceptable in our own theological tradition; will in fact
be untrue to Scripture itself:
A variant of this objection is the statement that our starting point
logy"
wrilings
teachings =
then,

The Doctrine of the Word of God

Chapter 2
The Word 3of God
What are the different forms of the Word of God?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
What is meant by the phrase "the Word of God"? Actually; there are
several different meanings taken by this phrase in the Bible. It is
helpful
distinguish these different senses clearly at the beginning
of this study:
"The Word
Jesus Chnc
Sometimes the Bible refers t0 the Son of God as "the Word of
God.
In Revelation 19.13, John sees the risen Lord Jesus in heaven
and says _
"The name by which he is called is The Word of God:
Similarly; in the beginning of John's gospel we read, "In the
beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word
was God" (John 1:1). It is clear that John is speaking of the Son of
God here
because in verse 14 he says
"And the Word became flesh
and dwelt among 4s, full of grace and truth;
have beheld his
glory, glory as of the only Son from the Father:
These verses (and
perhaps
John 1.1) are the only instances where the Bible refers to
God the Son as "the Word" or "the Word of God
sO this usage
not common But it does indicate that among the members of the
Trinity it is especially God the Son who in his person as well as in
his words has the role of
communicating the character of God t0 US
and of expressing the will of God for 4S_
The Word
SpEch
God's Decrees. Sometimes God $ words take the form of powerful decrees
that cause events [0
happen or even cause things tO come into being:
And
God said,
'Let there be light'
and there was light" (Gen: 1.3). God even
created the animal world by speaking his powerful word:
And God said,
Let
the earth bring forth living creatures according
their kinds: cattle and
F"ze4:
creeping things and beasts of the earth according to their kinds_
And
was
(Gen: 1.24). Thus_
the psalmist can say; "By the word of the Lord the
heavens were made
and all their host by the breath of his mouth'
(Ps. 33.6).
These powerful, creative words from God are often called God'$
decrees_
decree of God is
word of God that causes something
happen: These decrees of God include not only the events of the
original creation but also the
continuing
existence of all
Hebrews 1:3 tells us that Christ is continually "upholding the
universe by his word of power:
God's Words of Personal Address:
God sometimes communicates with
people on earth by speaking directly t0 them
These can be called instances of
God'$ Word of personal address: Examples are found throughout Scripture
At the very beginning of creation God
Adam:
And the LORD God
commanded the man, saying_
You may freely eat of every tree of the
garden;
but of the tree of the knowledge of
and evil you shall not eat; for in the
that you eat of it YOu shall die'
(Gen_
2.16-17)
After the sin of Adam
and Eve_
God still comes and speaks directly and personally to them in the
words of the curse (Gen. 3.16-19).
Another prominent example of God's
direct persona
address
people on earth is found
the giving of the 'Ten
Commandments:
And God
all these words
saying; `T am the LORD
your God, who brought YOu out of the land of Egypt; out of the house of
bondage_
You shall have no other
before me
(Ex. 20.1-3). In the
Vew Testament; at Jesus' baptism, God the Father spoke with
voice
heaven, saying; "This is my beloved Son, with whom
am well pleased"
(Matt: 317).
In these and several other instances where God spoke words of
personal address t0 individual people it was clear to the hearers that
these were the actual words of God: they were hearing God $
voice_
and they were therefore hearing words that had absolute
divine authority and that were absolutely trustworthy: To disbelieve
disobey any of these words would have been t0 disbelieve or
disobey God and therefore would have been sin:
Though the words of God'$ personal address are always seen in
Scripture
be the actual words of God,
are also "human
words in that they are spoken in ordinary human language that is
immediately understandable.
The fact that these words are spoken
in human
language does not limit their divine character Or authority
in any way: they are
entirely the words of God, spoken by the
things;
speaks
Bood
day
spoke
gods
from
vely
they
still
voice of God himself:
Some theologians have
that since human language is always
some sense "imperfect;
any message that God addresses tO uS in
human language muSt also be limited in its authority Or
truthfulness _
But these passages and many others that record
instances ot God'
words of personal address t0 individuals give no
indication of any limitation of the authority or truthfulness of God $
words when they are spoken in human language_
Quite the contrary
true_
fOr the words always place an absolute
obligation
upon the
hearers [0 believe them and t0
them fully. To disbelieve 0r
disobey any part of them is t0 disbelieve Or disobey God himself.
3. God's Words as Speech Through Human Lips. Frequently in Scripture
God raises up prophets through whom he speaks. Once
it is evident thar
although these are human words, spoken in ordinary human language by
ordinary human beings_
the authority and truthfulness of these words is in no
way diminished:
still completely God's words as well.
In Deuteronomy 18,
God says to Moses:
[will raise up for them
prophet like you from among their brethren;
and

We must not underestimate the importance of this question: The

(Deut: 4.2)

If we are t0 trust and obey God

Chapter
The Four Characteristics of Scripture: (1)
Authority
How do we know that the Bible is God'$ Word?
In the previous chapter our
was 0 determine which writings
belong in the Bible and which
do not: But once
have
determined what the Bible is_
our next step is t0 ask what it is like
What does the whole Bible teach us about itself?
The major
of the Bible about itself can be classified into
four characteristics (sometimes termed attributes): (1) the authority
of Scripture; (2) the clarity of Scripture; (3) the necessity of
Scripture; and
the sufficiency of Scripture_
with
to the first characteristic, most Christians would agree
that the Bible is our authority in some sense. But in exactly what
sense does the Bible claim to be our authority? And how do we
become persuaded that the claims of Scripture t0 be God s Word are
true? These are the questions addressed in this chapter:
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The authority of Scripture means that all the words
Scripture are
God $ words in such
way that I0 disbelieve or disobey any word of
Scripture is to disbelieve or disobey God.
This definition may nOw be examined in its various parts.
Kn
LnTdr
~CNpuTe ArE Godl
Klnror
1. This Is What the Bible Claims for Itself: There are frequent claims in the
Bible that all the words of Scripture are God'$ words (as well as words that
were written down by men)
In the Old Testament, this is frequently seen in
the introductory phrase; "Thus says the LORD_
which appears hundreds of
goal
writings
reachings
regard =
times_
the world of the Old Testament; this phrase would have been
recognized as identical in form to the phrase,
Thus says king
which
Wds
used
preface the edict of
king to his subjects, an edict that could not
be challenged or questioned but that simply had to be obeyed_
Thus,
when
the prophets say,
Thus says the Lord,
they are claiming t0 be messengers
from the sovereign
of Israel, namely; God himself;, and they are claiming
that their words are the absolutely authoritative words of God_
When
prophet spoke in God s name in this way; every word he spoke had t0 come
from God_
or he would be
false prophet (cf: Num 22.38; Deut: 18.18-20;
Jer: 1.9; 14.14; 23.16-22; 29.31-32; Ezek: 2.7; 13.1-16).
Furthermore, God is often said t0 speak
'through" the prophet
Kings 14.18; 16.12
34; 2 Kings 9.36; 14.25; Jer: 37.2; Zech. 7:7
12). Thus_
what the prophet says in God'$ name_
God says
13.26 with v 21;
21.19 with 2
9.25-26; Hag:
1.12;

aS words that God himself
Thus, t0 disbelieve or
disobey
anything
prophet says is t0 disbelieve
disobey God himself
(Deut: 18.19;
Sam: 10.8; 13.13-14; 15.3,19,23;
Kings 20.35,
36).
These verses of course do not claim that all the words in the Old
Testament are God $ words, for these verses themselves are
referring only to specific sections of spoken or written words in the
Old Testament: But the cumulative force of these passages,
including the hundreds of passages that begin
Thus says the Lord;
is [0 demonstrate that within the Old Testament we have written
records f words that are said t0 be God $ Own words.
These words
when written down constitute large sections of the Old Testament
In the New Testament,

Second
Timothy 3.16 says,
All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for
teaching; rebuking; correcting and training in righteousness'
(NIV)
Here
Scripture'
(graphe) must refer to the Old Testament
written Scripture

sacred writings'

Paul

King
Kings
Kings
Kings
spoke:

theopneustos_

Since it is writings that are

belief that all of the Old Testament

this probably includes all of

This is important because people sometimes (intentionally 0r
unintentionally) attempt t0 substitute some other final standard than
the written words of Scripture. For example, people will sometimes
refer to
'what Jesus really said" and claim that when we translate
the Greek words of the Gospels back into the Aramaic language
Jesus spoke_
we can
gain
better
understanding of Jesus'
wordS
than was given by the writers of the Gospels_
In fact; it is
sometimes said that this work of reconstructing Jesus
words in
Aramaic enables uS
correct the erroneous translations made by
the gospeL
authors.
In othel
cases_
people have claimed to know
what Paul really
thought"
even when that is different from the meaning of the words
he wrote_
have spoken of
what Paul should have said if he
had been consistent
the rest of his theology:
Similarly, others
have spoken of "the church situation t0 which Matthew was
and have attempted t0 give normative force either to that
situation or to the solution they think Matthew was attempting t0
bring about in that situation
In all of these instances we muSt admit that
about the words
or situations that lie "behind" the text of Scripture may at times be
helpful t0 US in understanding what the text means_
Nevertheless_
our hypothetical reconstructions of these words or situations can
never replace or compete with Scripture itself as the final authority,
nor should we ever allow them to contradict Or call into question
the accuracy of any of the words of Scripture_
We muSt continually
remember that we have in the Bible God's very words_
and we mSt
not try to "improve'
them
SuME
way; for this cannot be done_
Rather; we should seek t0 understand them and then trust them and
them with our whole heart.

Chapter 5
The Inerrancy of Scripture
Are there any errors in the Bible?
Most books on systematic
theology have not included
separate
chapter on the inerancy of the Bible
The subject has usually been
dealt with under the heading of the authority of Scripture; and no
further treatment has been considered necessary: However; this
issue of inerrancy is of such concern in the
evangelical world today
that
warrants
separate chapter following our treatment of the
authority of the Word of God.
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The Meaning
Inerrancy
We will not at this point repeat the arguments concerning the
authority of Scripture that were given in chapter
There it was
argued that all the words in the Bible are God s words, and that
therefore t0 disbelieve 0r
disobey any word in Scripture is t0
disbelieve or disobey God: It was
argued further that the Bible
clearly teaches that God cannot lie or speak falsely (2 Sam: 7:28;
Titus 1.2; Heb: 6.18). Therefore; all the words in Scripture are
claimed to be completely tnue and without error in any part (Num:
23.19; Pss_
12.6; 119.89_
96; Prov 30.5; Matt: 24.35). God*s words
are_
fact; the ultimate standard of truth (John 17.17).
Especially relevant at this
are those Scripture texts that
indicate the total truthfulness and reliability of God $ words_
The
promises of the LORD are promises that are pure, silver refined in
furnace on the ground, purified seven times'
(Ps. 12.6), indicates
the flawlessness or absolute reliability and purity of Scripture:
Similarly, "Every word of God proves true; he is
shield to those
who take refuge in him" (Prov 30.5) , indicates the truthfulness of
every word that God has spoken. Though error and at least partial
falsehood may characterize the speech of every human being; it is
the characteristic of God'$ speech even when spoken through sinful
point
human beings that it is never false and that it never affirms error:
"God is not man, that he should lie, or
son of man; that he should
repent" (Num. 23.19) was spoken by sinful Balaam specifically
about the prophetic words that God had spoken through his own
lips.
With evidence such as this we are nOw in
position t0 define
biblical inerrancy: The inerrancy of Scripture means that Scripture
in tne original manuscripts does not affirm anything Ihat is
contrary
fact
This definition focuses on the question of truthfulness and
falsehood in the language of Scripture. The definition
simple
terms just means that the Bible always tells the truth, and that it
always tells the truth concerning everything it talks about: This
definition does not mean that the Bible tells us every fact there
know about any
subject; but it affirms that what it does say
about any subject is true.
It is important t0 realize at the outset of this discussion that the
focus of this controversy is on the question of truthfulness in
speech: It must be
recognized that absolute truthfulness in speech is
consistent with some other types of statements
such as the
following:
The Bible Can Be Inerrant and Still Speak in the Ordinary Language
of Everyday Speech:
This is especially true in
scientific" or "historical"
descriptions of facts Or events. The Bible can speak of the sun rising and the
rain
falling because
the perspective of the speaker this is exactly what
happens. From the standpoint of an observer standing on the sun (were that
possible) or on some hypothetical
fixed" point in space; the earth rotates and
brings the sun into view, and rain does not fall downward but upward or
sideways or whatever direction necessary for it to be drawn by gravity toward
the surface of the earth: But such explanations are hopelessly pedantic and
would make ordinary communication impossible
From the standpoint of the
speaker; the sun does rise and the rain does fall, and these are perfectly true
descriptions of the natural phenomena the speaker observes_
similar consideration applies tO numbers when used in measuring
or in counting:
A reporter can say that 8,000 men were killed in
certain battle without thereby implying that he has counted
everyone and that there are not 7,999 or 8,001 dead soldiers. If
one
trom
roughly 8,000 died,
would of course be false
say that
6,000
died, but
would not be false in most contexts for
reporter t0 say
that 8,000 men died when in fact 7,823 0r 8,242 had died: the limits
of truthfulness would depend on the
degree of precision implied by
the speaker and expected by his original
hearers
is also true for measurements_
Whether
say;
don"
live tar
from my office,
01 "[live
little over
mile from my office
01 "[
live one mile from my office,
live 1.287 miles from my
office;
all four statements are still approximations
some degree
of accuracy: Further
degrees of accuracy might be obtained with
more
precise scientific instruments, but these would still be
approximations
certain degree of accuracy: Thus,
measurements also
in order t0 be true, should conform tO the
degree of precision implied by the speaker and expected by the
hearers in the original context: It should not trouble Us, then, to
affirm both that the Bible is absolutely truthful in everything
says
and that it uses ordinary language to describe natural phenomena or
[0 give approximations Or round numbers when those are
appropriate in the context:
We should also note that
language can make vague O1 imprecise
statements without
untiue.
live
litcle over
mile from my
office" is
vague and imprecise statement; but it is also inerrant:
there is nothing untrue about it. It does not affirm anything that is
contrary t0 fact: In
similar way; biblical statements can be
imprecise and still be totally true
Inerrancy has t0 do with
truthfulness
not with the degree of precision with which events are
reported.
The Bible Can Be Inerrant and Still Include Loose or Free Quotations
The method by which one person quotes the words of another person
procedure that in large part varies from culture t0 culture. In contemporary
American and British culture we are used t0
quoting
person $ exact words
when
enclose the statement in quotation marks (this is called direct
quotation). But when we use indirect quotation (with no quotation marks) we
only expect an accurate report of the substance of
statement. Consider this
sentence: "Elliot said that he would return home for supper right away:
The
sentence does not quote Elliot directly; but it is an acceptable and truthful
report of Elliot $ actua)
statement [0 his
father;
will come [0 the house [0 eat
in two minutes,
even though the indirect quotation included none of the
speaker'$ original words_
This
being
Written Greek at the time of the New Testament had no quotation
marks 0r
equivalent kinds of punctuation, and an accurate citation
of another person needed to include only
correct representation of
the content of what the person said (rather like our indirect
quotations):
Was
not expected t0 cite each word exactly. Thus_
inerrancy is consistent with loose or free quotations of the Old
Testament 0r of the words of Jesus_
for example; s0
as the
content is not false tO what was originally stated_
The original
writer did not ordinarily imply that he was using the exact words of
the speaker and only those, nor did the original hearers expect
verbatim quoration in such
reporting:
3. It Is Consistent With Inerrancy to Have Unusual or Uncommon
Grammatical Constructions in the Bible: Some of the language of Scripture
elegant and stylistically excellent: Other scripturae
contain the
rough-hewn language of ordinary people_
At times this includes
failure
follow the commonly accepted "rules" of grammatical expression (such as the
use of
plural
verb where grammatical rules would require
singular verb
the use of
feminine adjective where
masculine one would be expected_
different spelling for
word than the one commonly used, etc.) These
stylistically
grammatically irregular statements (which are especially found
in the book of Revelation) should not trouble uS, for
do not affect the
truthfulness of the statements under consideration:
statement can be
ungrammaticaba
but still be entirely true_
For example, an uneducaled
backwoodsman in some rural area may be the most trusted man in the county
even
though his grammar is pOor; because he has earned
reputation for
neven
telling
Similarly; there are
tew statements in
Scripture (in the
original languages
that are
ungrammatical (according to current standards of
proper grammar at that time)
but still inerrant because they are completely
true
The issue is truthfulness in speech:
50nX CuTent Challeices
[nemTano
In this section we examine the major objections that are commonly
made against the concept of inerrancy:
1. The Bible Is Only Authoritative for "Faith and Practice:
One of the
mOSL
frequent objections is raised by those who say that the purpose of
Scripture is t0 teach us in areas that concern "faith and practice" only; that is_
in areas that directly relate [0 our religious faith Or [0
ethical conduct_ This
position would allow for the possibility of false statements in Scripture_
example
in other areas such as in minor historical details 0r scientific facts
long
writings
they
these areas_
it is said, do not concern the purpose of the Bible;
which is t0
instruct 4S in what we should believe and how we are
live.
Its advocales
often prefer t0 say that the Bible is "infallible,
buc
hesitate t0 use the
word inerrant:
The response to this objection can be stated as follows: the Bible
repeatedly affirms that all of Scripture is profitable for us (2 Tim:
3.16) and that all of it is "God-breathed
Thus
is completely pure
(Ps. 12.6) , perfect (Ps. 119.96), and true (Prov: 30.5).
The Bible
itself does not make any restriction on the kinds of subjects to
which it speaks truthfully:
The New Testament contains further affirmations of the reliability
of all parts of Scripture: in Acts 24.14,
Paul says that he worships
God;
"believing everything laid down by the law or written in the
prophets_
In Luke 24.25, Jesus says that the disciples are
foolish
men
because
are "slow of heart to believe all that the prophets
have spoken:
In Romans 15.4,
Paul says that
whatever was
written'
in the Old Testament was
written for our instruction:
These texts give no indication that there is any part of Scripture that
is not t0 be trusted or relied on completely. Similarly; in
Corinthians 10.11, Paul can refer even t0 minor historical details in
the Old Testament (sitting down to eat and drink; rising up
dance) and can say both that they "happened" (thus
implying
historical reliability) and
were written down for Our instruction:
If we begin
examine the way in which the New Testament
authors trust the smallest historical details of the Old Testament
narrative
we see n0 intention t0 separate OUL
matters of "faith and
practice_
or t0 say that this is somehow
recognizable category of
affirmations
Or t0
imply that statements not in that category need
not be trusted Or
thought to be inerrant: Rather;
seems that the
New Testament authors are willing to cite and affirm as true every
detail of the Old Testament
In the
following list are some examples of these historical details

The Four Characteristics of Scripture: (2)
Clarity
Can only Bible scholars understand the Bible rightly?

Anyone who has begun t0 read the Bible seriously will realize that

very early in the history of the church Peter

of Paul $ epistles were

So also our' beloved brother Paul wrote t0
You
according

do the other scriptures'
(2 Peter 3.15-16). We must admit

But
would be
mistake to think that most of Scripture or

general is difficult tO understand_
In fact; the Old

written in such

are able to be understood by
ordinary believers. Even in Peter
statement just quoted, the
context is an appeal t0 the
teachings of Paul *s letter; which Peter'$
readers had read and understood (2 Peter 3.15). In fact; Peter

And he does not say that there are
impossible

said t0 be such that even the

day when

To the

Cor: 1.2), "To the churches

'no prophecy of Scripture
LuMe
about by the prophet'$ own interpretation.

Ikc,

and

The Moral and Spiritual Oualitic, Neededl
Richt Undertanding
The New Testament writers frequently state that the ability t0

of the Spirit of God, for
are folly to him,

Mark 411-12; John 7.17;
8.43). Thus, although the New Testament authors affirm that the

unwilling
t0 receive its

will read
sincerely
seeking salvation, and by all believers who
will read
while seeking God's help in understanding it This is
because in both cases the Holy Spirit is at work overcoming the
effects of sin; which otherwise will make the truth appear t0 be
foolish
Cor: 2.14; 1.18-25; James 1.5-6,22-25).
Definitio
of the Chrir
ol Stinture
In order t0 summarize this biblical material, we can affirm thar the
Bible is written
such
way that all things necessary for Our

forth in Scripture. Although theologians have sometimes defined
the clarity of Scripture more narrowly (by saying; for example, only
that Scripture is clear in teaching the way of salvation), the many
reading
They
large
they
texts cited above apply t0 many different aspects of biblical

such
way [hat ILS
teachings
able to be understood by all who

seeking God $ help and being willing t0 follow it: Once

People Aicuer- nd Scriptur
During Jesus' lifetime, his Own disciples
times failed t0

Uw
reachings (see Matt

there

agree on the teachings of the Old Testament
about the letters

In fact,

order t0 help people t0 avoid making mistakes in interpreting

guidelines to encourage growth in the skill of

is the more technical term for this field
of study: hermeneutics is the study of correct methods of
interpretation (especially interpretation of Scripture).
Another technical term often used in discussions of biblical
interpretation is "exegesis_
term that refers more t0 the actual
MuSt
practice of interpreting Scripture, not to theories and principles
about how it should be done: exegesis is the process of interpreting
text of Scripture. Consequently, when one studies principles of
interpretation_
that is "hermeneutics
but when one applies those
principles and begins actually explaining
biblical text; he or she is
doing
exegesis_
The existence of many

Scripture throughout history reminds us that the doctrine of the
clarity of Scripture does not imply or suggest that all believers
agree on all the
of Scripture:
Nevertheless_
it does tell uS
something very important
that the problem always lies not with
Scripture but with ourselves. The situation is in fact similar t0 that
of the authority of Scripture.
Whereas we affirm that the words of
Scripture have all the authority of God himself; we also realize that
many people do not acknowledge that authority or submit
themselves to it. Similarly; we affirm that all the teachings of
Scripture are clear and able to be understood
but we also recognize
that people often (through their own shortcomings) misunderstand
what is clearly written in Scripture_
praGGII
ncouragenkent Fmm
Wadnna
The doctrine of the clarity of Scripture therefore has
very
important; and ultimately very encouraging; practical implication: It
tells us that where there are areas of doctrinal or ethical
disagreement (for example, over baptism Or predestination 01
church government), there are only two possible causes for these
disagreements:
On the one hand
may be that we are seeking
make affirmations where Scripture itself is silent In such cases
we should be more ready to admit that God has not given uS the
answer t0 OUr quest; and to allow for differences of viewpoint
within the church. (This will often be the case with

questions, such as methods of evangelism or styles of Bible
teaching =
appropriate church size ) (2) On the other hand, it is

have made mistakes in our interpretation of

This could have happened because the data
used
decide
question of interpretation were inaccurate O1 incomplete.
Or it could be because there is some personal inadequacy on OuI
part, whether it be, for example, personal pride,

faith,
selfishness
even failure t0 devote enough time t0
prayerfully reading and studying Scripture.
Will
teachings =
very
we
But in no case are we free tO say that the teaching of the Bible on

In no case should we think that persistent disagreements on some

Rather; if

This truth should give great encouragement t0 all Christians tO read

We should never
dssuie

every day for

Is there any role then for Bible scholars or for those with

parts

They can teach Scripture clearly;

explore new areas of

Scripture.

the answering of difficult questions that have been raised by both

continual activity of refining and making more precise the church'$
understanding of detailed points of interpretation of individual

The process of relating

uE
another;

Every scholar who deeply loves God*s Word will soon realize that
there
much more in Scripture than can be learned in any one

defend the teachings of the Bible against attacks by

correcting his opponents with gentleness"
and

have

large
They

good knowledge of the English Bible), but rather that technical

They can supplement the study of Scripture for the benefit of the

These four functions benefit the church as

If such

The

in a

the people of the church as
whole)
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
If the doctrine of the clarity of Scripture
true, why does there seem to
be so much
disagreement among Christians about the teaching of the
Bible? Observing the diversity of interpretations of Scripture, some
conclude; "People can make the Bible say
anything they want
How do
you think Jesus would respond t0 this statement?
What would happen t0 the church
most believers gave up reading the
Bible for themselves and only listened t0
Bible teachers 0r read books
about the Bible? If you thought that only expert scholars could
understand the Bible rightly; what would happen to your personal
of Scripture? Has this already happened to some extent in your
life Or in the lives of those you know?
Do you think that there are right and wrong interprerations of most or all
passages
Scripture? If yOu thought the Bible was generally unclear;
how would your answer change? Will

text of Scripture? Will

gain
biblical
reading
answer [0 some difficult doctrinal 0r moral

If even seminary professors disagree about some Bible teaching_
can

correct decision on that
teaching? (Give reasons for your answer: ) Do YOu think ordinary people
among the Jews at the time of Jesus had
hard time
deciding whether
believe Jesus or the scholarly experts who disagreed with him? Did Jesus
expect them to be able to decide?
How can
pastor preach biblically based sermons each Sunday without

himself) are able t0 interpret Scripture rightly? Do
think it should
ever be necessary; in
doctrinal or ethica)
controversy; for
Bible
scholar to speak in
church and base his main arguments on special
meanings of Greek or Hebrew words that the church members
themselves are unable to evaluate or take issue with personally? Is there
appropriate way for
scholar t0 use such technical knowledge in
popular writing 0r speaking?
Church leaders at the time of Martin Luther said they wanted to keep the
Bible in Latin t0 prevent the common people from reading it and then
misinterpreting it Evaluate this argument Why do you think Martin
Luther was SO anxious
translate the Bible into German? Why do you

like William Tyndale in England
who were transE
the
Bible into the language of the people? Why is the task of Bible
translation into other languages S0 important
part of the work of
missions?
Does the doctrine of the clarity of Scripture mean that the New
Testament can be fully understood by people who do not have access
an Old Testament?

The Four Characteristics of Scripture:
Necessity
For what purposes are the Bible necessary? How much can people
know about God without the Bible?
Do we need t0 have
Bible 0r t0 have someone tell us what the
Bible says in order t0 know that God exists? Or that we are sinners
needing to be saved? Or to know how to find salvation? Or to know
God'$ will for our lives? These are the kinds of questions which an
investigation of the necessity of Scripture is intended t0 answer:
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The necessity of Scripture may be defined as follows: The necessity
of Scripture means that the Bible is necessary for knowing the
gospel, for maintaining spiritual life
and for knowing God $ will,
but is not necessary for knowing that God exists or for knowing
something about God $ character and moral laws.
That definition may now be explained in its various parts_

news [0
them:
However; it must be emphasized that Scripture nowhere indicates
that people can know the gospel, or know the way of salvation,
through such general revelation. They may know that God exists,
that he is their Creator, that
Owe
him obedience, and that they
have sinned
him.
The existence of systems of sacrifice in
primitive religions throughout history attests tO the fact that these
things can be clearly known by people apart from the Bible: The
repeated occurrences of the "rain and fruitful seasons'
mentioned in
Acts 14.17 may even lead some people t0 reason that God is not
only holy and righteous but also loving and forgiving:
But how the
holiness and justice of God can ever be reconciled with his
willingness
forgive sins is
mystery that has never been solved
by any religion apart from the Bible. Nor does the Bible give us any
hope that it ever can be discovered apart from specific revelation
from God. It is the great wonder of our redemption that God
himself has provided the way of salvation by
his own Son
who
both God and man, t0 be our representative and bear the
penalty for our sins
thus
combining the justice and love of God in
one infinitely wise and amazingly
act. This
which
seems
commonplace t0 the Christian ear; should not lose its wonder
for US:
could never have been conceived by man alone apart from
God's special, verbal revelation
Furthermore, even if an adherent of
primitive religion could think
that God somehow must have himself paid the penalty for our sins_
such
thought would only be an extraordinary speculation.
could
never be held with enough certainty
be the ground on which to
rest saving faith unless God himself confirmed such speculation
they
good
they
"gainst L
sending
gracious
facl;
with his own words, namely; the words of the gospel proclaiming
either that this indeed was going t0 happen (if the revelation came
in the time before Christ) or that it indeed has happened (if the
revelation came in the time after Christ). The Bible never views
human speculation apart from the Word of God as
sufficient basis
on which t0 rest
saving faith: such saving faith, according t0
Scripture, is always confidence 0r trust in God that rests on the
truthfulness of God'
own words.

The Four Characteristics of Scripture: (4)
Sufficiency
Is the Bible enough for knowing what God wants US t0 think or

EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Are we t0 look for other words from God in addition t0 those we
have in Scripture? The doctrine of the sufficiency of Scripture
addresses this question:
Huetniin n
huflcienc
OleaTituT
We can define the
sufficiency of Scripture as follows: The
sufficiency of Scripture means that Scripture contained all the
words of God he intended his people to have at each stage of
redemptive history, and that it now contains everything we need
God [0 tell us for salvation, for trusting him perfectly, and for
obeying him perfectly:
This definition emphasizes that it is in Scripture alone that we are
search for God $ words t0 us. It also reminds us that God considers
what he has told us in the Bible to be enough for uS_
and that we
should rejoice in the
revelation that he has given 4S and be
content with ic
Significant scriptural support and explanation of this doctrine is
found in Paul $ words to Timothy;
childhood you have been
acquainted with the sacred writings which are able tO instruct YOu
for salvation through faith in Christ Jesus"
Tim. 3.15). The
context shows that
sacred writings'
here means the written words
of Scripture (2 Tim. 3.16). This is an indication that the words of
God which we have in Scripture are all the words of God we need
in order t0 be saved: these words are able t0 make US wise "for
great
from
salvation. -
This is confirmed by other passages that talk about the
words of Scripture as the means God uses to bring us t0 salvation
(James 1:18;
Peter 1.23)
Other passages indicate that the Bible is sufficient to equip us for
living the Christian life_
Once again Paul writes t0 Timothy;
AlL
scripture is inspired by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof;
for correction; and for training in righteousness
that the man of
God may be complete; equipped for every good work
Lim:
3.16-17).
Here Paul indicates that one purpose for which God caused
Scripture

equipped for
every
wOrk:
there is any
good
that God wants
Christian [0 do_
this passage indicates that God has made provision

training the Christian in it. Thus_
there is no "good
that God wants uS to do other than those that are taught
somewhere in Scripture:
can equip uS tor every
good work
A similar
is found in Psalm 119:

1). This

equivalence between being "blameless
and
walking in the law of the LORD
those who are blameless are
those who walk in the law of the Lord
Here again is an indication
that all that God requires of uS is recorded in his written Word:
simply to do all that the Bible commands us is t0 be blameless in
God's sight:
To be morally perfect in God s sight, then, what must we do in
addition to what God commands us in Scripture?
at all! If we simply keep the words of Scripture
will be
"blameless
and we will be doing "every good
that God

work"
good

Nothing'

very practical sense; it means

Scripture.

these areas_

systematic
and ethics and find answers tO our questions
At this point we differ from Roman Catholic theologians, who

The Amount of Scripture Given Was Sufficient at Each
Stage of
Redemptive History
The doctrine of the sufficiency of Scripture does not imply that God
canno
add any more words t0 those he has already spoken to his
people:
rather implies that man cannot add on his Own initiative
any words [0 those that God has already spoken
Furthermore; it
implies that in fact God has not spoken to mankind any more words
which he requires Us t0 believe or obey other than those which we
have nOw in the Bible:
This point is important; for it helps US to understand how God could
tell his people that his words to them were sufficient at many
different points in the history of redemption, and how he could
nevertheless add tO those words later: For example; in Deuteronomy

The secret

[0 4S_

At each

that God

those
With further progress in the

With

things
ohey
things.

For Christians today;

After the death;

The doctrine of the sufficiency of Scripture has several practical
applications t0 our Christian lives. The following list is intended to
be helpful but not exhaustive
The sufficiency of Scripture should encourage us as we try t0
discover what God would have US t0 think (about
particular
doctrinal
issue) or t0 do (in
particular situation)
We should be
encouraged that everything God wants t0 tell us about that question
is t0 be found in Scripture. This does not mean that the Bible
answers all the questions that we might think up_
The secret
belong to the LORD our God" (Deut: 29.29). But it does mean
that when we are
facing
problem of genuine importance tO OUI
Christian life;
we can
approach Scripture with the confidence that
from it God will provide us with guidance for that problem:
There will of course be some times when the answer we find is that
Scripture does not speak directly
question: (This would be
the case_
for example; if we tried to find from Scripture what
order
of worship
follow on Sunday mornings
whether it is better [0
kneel or
perhaps to stand when we pray; 0r at what time we should
eat OuT meals during the
etc.) In those cases,
we may conclude
that God has not required uS t0 think or to act in any certain way
with
regard to that question (except; perhaps, in terms of more
general principles regarding our attitudes and goals). But in many
other cases we will find direct and clear guidance from the Lord to
equip us for
every good work'
(2 Tim: 3.17)-
As we go through life, frequent practice in searching Scripture for
guidance will result in an
increasing ability
find accurate_
carefully formulated answers t0 our problems and questions_
Lifelong growth in understanding Scripture
thus include
growth
the
of rightly understanding the Bible
reachings
and applying them to specific questions.
The sufficiency of Scripture reminds uS that we are to add
nothing
Scripture, and that we are t0 consider no other
writings
of equal value to Scripture.
This principle
violated by almost all
cults and sects. Mormons, for example, claim to believe the Bible_
but they also claim divine authority for the Book of Mormon:
Christian Scientists similarly claim to believe the Bible
but in
practice
hold the book Science and Health With
Key [0 the
Scriptures, by Mary Baker Eddy; on
par with Scripture Or above it
things
day;
Will
skill
they
in authority. Since these claims violate God'$ commands not to add
his words, we should not think that any additional words from
God to uS would be found in these writings
Even in Christian
churches
similar error is sometimes made when people go beyond
what Scripture says and assert with great confidence new ideas
about God or heaven, basing their teachings not on Scripture but on
their own
peculation
01 even on claimed
experiences of dying and
coming back to life_
The sufficiency of Scripture also tells us that God does not
require uS t0 believe anything about himself or his redemptive work
that is not found
Scripture. Among
from the time of the
early church are some collections of
alleged sayings of Jesus that
Were
not preserved in the Gospels. It is likely that at least some of

about Jesus' words and deeds in order t0 trust and
hin
perfectly: Though these collections of sayings do have some limited

Chapter 9
The Existence of God
How do we know that God exists?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
How do we know that God exists? The answer can be given in IWO
parts: First, all people have an inner sense of God. Second, we
believe the evidence that is found in Scripture and
nature:.
Humanitr",
SeIe 0l Gud
All persons everywhere have
inner sense that God exists
that they are his creatures; and that he is their Creator: Paul says
that even Gentile unbelievers "knew God" but did not honor him as
God or give thanks to him (Rom: 1.21). He says that wicked
unbelievers have
exchanged the truth about God for
lie" (Rom:
1.25) , implying that they actively or willfully rejected some truth
about God $ existence and character that
knew: Paul says that
"what can be known about God is plain to them;
and adds that this
is "because God has shown it t0 them'
(Rom. 1.19).
Yet Scripture also recognizes that some people
this inner sense
of God and even
thar God exists . It is
the
who says in
his heart;
There is no God" (Ps. 14.1; 53.1). It is the wicked person
who first
curses and renounces the LORD'
and then in pride
repeatedly thinks "there is no God" (Ps. 10.3-4). These passages
indicate both that sin leads people to think irrationally and to deny
God'$ existence_
and that it is someone who is
thinking irrationally
who has been deceived who will say; " There is no God
Paul also recognizes that sin will cause people t0
their
knowledge of God: he
of those who "by their wickedness
suppress the truth'
(Rom: 1:18) and says that those who do this are
without excuse
for this denial of God (Rom 1.20).
series of
active verbs indicates that this is
willful suppression of the truth
deep,
they
deny
deny
fvol "
deny
speaks
(Rom:
1.23
28,32)."
In the life of
Christian this inner awareness of God becomes

Spirit bears witness with
our spirits that we are children of God (Rom: 8.16), and we
CUME
know Jesus Christ
within our hearts (Eph 3.17; Phil. 3.8, 10;

Christian is such that though we have not seen our Lord Jesus

Peter 1.8)-
Eelieting the Evidenc
In addition t0 people
inner awareness of God that bears clear
witness t0 the tact that God exists
clear evidence of his existence is
to be seen in Scripture and in nature_
The evidence that God exists is of course found throughout the
Bible: In fact, the Bible everywhere assumes that God exists. The
first verse of Genesis does not present evidence for the existence of
God but begins immediately t0 tell us what he has done: "In the
beginning God created the heavens and the earth:
It we are
convinced that the Bible is true
then we know from the Bible not
only that God exists but also very much about his nature and his
acts.
The world also gives abundant evidence of God $ existence. Paul
says that God $ eterna
nature and deity have been "clearly
perceived in the
that have been made'
(Rom. 1.20). This
broad reference to "the things that have been made" suggests that in
some sense every created thing gives evidence of God'$ character:
Nevertheless;
is man himself, created in the image of God
who
most abundantly bears witness t0 the existence of God: whenever
we meet another human being;
we should (if our minds are
correctly) realize that such an incredibly intricate, skillful,
communicative living creature could only have been created by an
infinite, all-wise Creator:
In addition t0 the evidence seen in the existence of
human
there is further excellent evidence in nature. The "rains and
fnuitful seasons'
as well as the
food and gladness" that all people
experience and benefit from are also said by Barnabas and Paul to
loving
Holy
living
suntur
FLuute
things
thinking
living '
beings;
be witnesses
God (Acts 14.17). David tells us of the witness of
the heavens: "The heavens are telling the glory of God; and the
firmament proclaims his handiwork: Day to day pours forth speech;
and night to night declares knowledge
(Ps. 19.1-2). To look
upward into the sky by day or by night is tO see Sun, moon, and
stars, sky and clouds, all continually declaring by their existence
and beauty and greatness that
powerful and wise Creator has
made them and sustains them in their order:
This wide variety of testimonies
God $ existence fTom various
parts of the created world suggests [O 4S that in one sense
everything that exists gives evidence of God'$ existence_
For those
who have eyes
see and evaluate the evidence correctly; every leaf
every tree_
blade of grass, every star in the sky; and every
other part of creation all cry Out continuously; "God made mel God
made mel God made mel" [f our hearts and minds were not
blinded by sin, it would be impossible for uS t0 look closely at
leaf from any tree and say; "No one created this: it just happened:
The beauty of
snowflake; the majestic power of
thunderstorm;
the
honeybee; the refreshing taste of cold water; the
incredible abilities of the human hand-
all these and thousands of
other aspects of creation simply could not have come into existence
apart from the activity of an all-powerful and all-wise Creator:
Thus, for those who are correctly evaluating the evidence,
everything in Scripture and everything in nature proves clearly that
God exists and that he is the powerful and wise Creator that
Scripture describes him to be. Therefore_
when
believe that God
exiStS,
we are
basing our belief not on some blind
apart from
any evidence

overwhelming amount of reliable evidence
from God $ words and God$ works: It is
characteristic of true

confidence based on reliable evidence, and faith in
the existence of God shares this characteristic.
Furthermore
these evidences can all be seen as valid proofs for the
existence of God_
even
though some people reject them. This does
not mean that the evidence is invalid in itself, only that those who
reject the evidence are evaluating
wrongly.

"praniy
Knaeng
The traditional "proofs" for the existence of God that have been

hope
various points in history are in fact attempts t0 analyze the

If it is true that sin
causes people t0 think irrationally; then these proofs are attempts [0
Cause

correctly about the evidence for
God'$ existence_
in spite of the irrational tendencies caused by sin:
Most of the traditional
proofs for the existence of God can be
classified in four major types of argument:
The cosmological argument considers the fact that every known
thing in the universe has
cause:
Therefore, it reasons
the universe
itself must also have
cause
and the cause of such
great universe
can only be God:
The teleological argument is really
subcategory of the
cosmological argument: It focuses on the evidence of harmony;
order; and design in the universe
and argues that its design gives
evidence of an intelligent purpose (the Greek word telos means
end" or
'purpose
Since the universe appears to be
designed with
purpose _
there must be an
intelligent and
purposeful God who created
to function this way:
The ontological argument begins with the idea of God, who is
defined as
being
greater than which
can be imagined.
then argues that the characteristic of existence must
[0 such
being
since it is greater
exist than not t0 exist.
The moral argument begins from man'
sense of right and
wrong; and of the need for justice to be done_
and argues that there
must be
God who is the source of right and wrong and who will
someday mete out justice t0 all people:
Because all of these arguments are based on facts about the creation
that are indeed true facts_
we may say that all of these proofs (when
carefully constructed) are; in an objective sense
valid proofs_
valid in that they correctly evaluate the evidence and correctly
reason [0
conclusion
tact; the universe does have God as
its cause_
and
does show evidence of purposeful design; and God
does exist as
greater than which
can be imagined,
and God has given 4S
sense of right and wrong and
sense thal
'goal"
nothing
belong
They
Tue
being
nothing
his
judgment is coming someday The actual facts referred to in
these proofs, therefore; are true, and in that sense the proofs are
valid, even though not all people are persuaded by them:
But in another sense
if "valid" means
able
compel agreement
evem
from those who begin with false assumptions_
then ot course
none of the proofs is valid because not one of them is able to
compel agreement from everyone who considers them. Yet this is
because many unbelievers either begin with invalid assumptions or
do not reason correctly from the evidence_
It is not because the
proofs are invalid in themselves_
The value of these proofs, then, lies chiefly in overcoming some of
the intellectual
objections of unbelievers. They cannot bring
unbelievers tO saving faith, for that comes about through belief in
the testimony of Scripture: But
can help overcome objections
from unbelievers
and, for believers_
they can provide further
intellectual evidence for
something they have already been
persuaded of from their own inner sense of God and from the
testimony of Scripture.

PERMAOAASAEM
Finally;
must be remembered that in this sinful world God must
enable us to be persuaded or we would never believe in him. We
read that "the
of this world has blinded the minds of the
unbelievers, t0 keep them from seeing the
light of the gospel of the
glory of Christ" (2 Cor: 4.4). Furthermore,
Paul says that
since, in
the wisdom of God, the world did not know God through wisdom,
it pleased God through the folly of what we preach
save those
who believe" ( 1 Cor: 1.21). In this sinful world, human wisdom is
inadequate for coming t0 know God. Thus, Paul'$ preaching came
demonstration of the Spirit and of power; thatyour faith might
not rest in the wisdom of men but in the power of God" (1 Cor: 2.5).
We are dependent upon God to remove the blindness and
irrationality caused by sin and
enable uS [0 evaluate the evidence
rightly; believe what Scripture says, and come to saving faith in
Christ

unable tO

Unity. The unity of God may be defined as follows: God is not divided into
parts, yet we see different attributes of God emphasized at different times.
This attribute of God has also been called God $ simplicity; using simple in the
less common sense of
not complex" or
not composed of parts_
But since
the word simple today has the more common sense of
easy t0 understand"
and
unintelligent or foolish;
it is more helpful now to speak of God $
unity
rather than his
simplicity:
When Scripture speaks about God 's attributes
never singles ouL one

that
attribute is completely true of God and is true of all of God $
character: For example, John can say that "God is light"

(1 John 4.8). There is no

light and part
God is love_
that God
partly light and

also love:
The
true of other descriptions of God $ character; such as that in

part of God_

Why then does Scripture speak of these different attributes of God? It is
probably because we are unable to grasp all of God $ character at one time
and we need to learn of it from different perspectives over
period of time.
Yet these perspectives should never be set in opposition tO one another; for
they are just different ways of
at the totality of God's character:
In terms of practical application; this means that we should never think; for
example
that God is
loving God at one point in history and
just Or
wrathful God at another point in history: He is the same God always, and
everything he says Or does is fully consistent with all his attributes_
It is not
accurate
say, as some have said, that God is
God of justice in the Old
Testament and
God of love in the New Testament God is and always has
been infinitely just and infinitely
as well; and everything he does in the
Old Testament as well as the
Testament is completely consistent with
both of those attributes_
Now
is true that some actions of God show certain of his attributes more
prominently. Creation demonstrates his power and wisdom, the atonement
demonstrates his love and justice_
and the radiance of heaven demonstrates
his glory and beauty: But all of these in some way 0r other also demonstrate
his knowledge and holiness and mercy and truthfulness and patience and
sovereignty; and s0 forth: It would be difficult indeed t0 find some attribute of
God that is not reflected at least to some degree in any one of his acts of
redemption.
This is due t0 the fact mentioned above: God
unity and
everything he does is an act of the whole person of God
Moreover; the doctrine of the unity of God should caution us against
attempting t0 single out any one attribute of God as more important than all
the others_
At various times people have attempted
see God's holiness_
his love, or his self-existence_
his righteousness
or" some other attribute as
the most important attribute of his being:
But all such attempts seem to
misconceive of God as
combination of various parts_
with some parts being
somehow larger or more influential than others _
Furthermore, it is hard
understand exactly what "most important" might mean
Does
mean that
there are some actions of God that are not fully consistent with some of his
other attributes? That there are
SUME
attributes that God somehow sets aside
at times in order
act in ways
slightly contrary tO those attributes? Certainly
we cannot maintain either of these views
for that would mean that God is
inconsistent with his own character Or that he
changes and becomes
looking -
loving
New
something different from what he was previously: Rather; when we see all the
attributes aS merely various aspects of the total character of God, then such
question becomes quite unnecessary and we discover that there is no attribute
that can be singled out as more important: It is God himself in his whole
who is supremely important; and it is God himself in his whole being whom
we are t0 seek t0 know and [0 love.

Chapter 12
The Character of God: "Communicable"
Attributes
(Part 1)
How is God like us in his being and in mental and moral
attributes?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
In this chaptel
consider the attributes of God that are
communicable;
more shared with us than those mentioned in the previous chapter: It must be
remembered that this division into "incommunicable'
and
communicable
not an absolute division and there
some room for difference of opinion
concerning which attributes should fit into which categories_
The list of
attributes here put in the category
communicable'
common one, but
understanding the definition of each attribute
more important than being
able
categorize them in exactly the way presented in this book:
Furthermore, any list of God' $ attributes must be based on some
understanding of how finely one wishes
make distinctions between various
aspects of God $ character: Are God'$
goodness and love two attributes or
one? What about knowledge and wisdom; or spirituality and invisibility? In
this chapter; each of these attributes is treated separately, and the result is _
rather long list of various attributes. Yet in severa
cases it would not make
much difference if someone were
[0 treat these
as various aspects of the
same attribute. If we remember that it is the entire and wholly integrated
person of God about whom we are talking_
will be apparent that the division
into various attributes is not
matter of great doctrinal significance but is
something that must be based 0n one'$
judgment concerning the most
effective way
present the biblical material
This chapter divides God $
communicable'
attributes into five major
categories_
with individual attributes listed under each category as follows:

1. Spirituality. People have often wondered_
what is God made 0f
[s he

The answer of Scripture is that God is none of these. Rather;
read that
"God is spirit'
(John 4.24)
This statement is
spoken by Jesus in the context
discussion with the woman at the well in Samaria. The discussion is

because

Thus _

the previous chapter). We
should not think of God s existence as spirit as
meaning that God is infinitely
for example; for it is not part of God but all of God that is in every
point of space (see Ps. 139.7-10). Nor should we think that God's existence
as spirit means that God is infinitely small, for nO place in the universe can
surround him or contain him (see
Kings 8.27). Thus
God*s being cannot be

existence as
spirit:

This
spatial
large,
You
visiting
The creation language in this commandment
heaven above, or
earth
beneath, or

reminder that God's being, his

To think of his being in terms of

him, to think of him as less than he really is. To

graven (Or
carved"

wisdom, love, mercy, omnipresence_

form Or mode of being that is like anything else in

This
why God $ jealousy is given as the reason for the prohibition against

for

jealous God
(Ex

prohibition against making any images of him).
Thus _
God does not have
physical body, nor is he made of any kind of

Furthermore, God is not merely

steam
air or space, all of which are created things: God $ being is nOt
like any of these _
God'$ being is nOt even exactly like our own spirits_
these are created
that apparently are able to exist only in one place in

Instead of all these ideas of God

this means, it is
kind of existence that is unlike
anything else in creation. It
kind of existence that is far superior t0 all Our material existence:
We
might say that God is "pure being'
"the fullness or essence of being:
Furthermore, this kind of existence is nOt less real or less desirable than our
own existence.
Rather; it is more real and more desirable than the material
and immaterial existence of all creation.
Before there was any creation, God
existed as spirit His Own being is SO very real
that it was able t0 cause
everything else to come into existence!
At this point we can define God 's spirituality: God $ spirituality means that
limit
things
God exists as

torm of

Chapter 44
God in Three Persons: The Trinity
How can God be three persons, yet one God?
The preceding chapters have discussed many attributes of God_
But if we
understood only those attributes_
we would not
rightly understand God at all,
for we would not understand that God_
in his very being
has always existed
as more than one person
In fact; God exists as three persons, yet he is one
God
It is important tO remember the doctrine of the Trinity in connection with the
study of God $ attributes_
When we think of God as eternal, omnipresent;
omnipotent; and s0 forth, we may have
tendency t0 think only of God the
Father
connection with these attributes.
But the biblical teaching on the
Trinity tells us that all of God:
attributes are true of all three persons, for
each is fully God_
Thus
God the Son and God the Holy Spirit are also eternal,
omnipresent; omnipotent; infinitely wise; infinitely holy; infinitely loving
omniscient; and s0 forth:
The doctrine of the Trinity is one of the most important doctrines of the
Christian faith_
To study the Bible
on the Trinity gives 4S great
insight into the question that is at the center of all of our seeking after God:
What is God like in himself? Here we learn that in himself, in his very being_
God exists in the persons of Father; Son; and Holy Spirit, yet he
one God:
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
We may define the doctrine of the Trinity as follows: God eternally exists as
three persons, Father; Son, and Holy Spirit; and each person is fully God, and
there
one God:
The Doctrine of the Trinity Is Progressively Revealed in Scripture
Partial Revelation in the Old Testament: The word trinity is never found
in the Bible, though the idea represented by the word
taught
many
places_
The word trinity means "tri-unity" or "three-in-oneness
Ic is used [0
teachings
summarize the teaching of Scripture that God is three persons yet one God
Sometimes people think the doctrine of the Trinity is found only in the New
Testament; not in the Old: If God has eternally existed as three persons, it
would be surprising to find no indications of that in the Old Testament:
Although the doctrine of the Trinity is not explicitly found in the Old
Testament; several passages suggest Or even imply that God exists as more
than one person.
For instance, according t0 Genesis 1:26, God said
Let uS make man in our
image; after our likeness_
What do the plural verb
"let us"=
and the plural
pronoun
our"
mean? Some have suggested they are plurals of majesty;
form of speech
king would use
saying; for example
"We are pleased
grant YOUI request:
However; in Old Testament Hebrew there are no other
examples of
monarch using plural verbs or plural pronouns of himself in
such
"plural of majesty;
so this suggestion has no evidence tO suppOrt
Another
suggestion is that God is here speaking
angels_
But angels did not
participate in the creation of man, nor was man created in the image and
likeness of angels_
this suggestion is not convincing: The best explanation
is that already in the first chapter of Genesis we have an indication of
plurality of persons in God himself.
We are not told how many persons, and
have nothing approaching
complete doctrine of the [rinity, but it is
implied that more than one person is involved_
The same can be said of
Genesis 3.22
"Behold, the man has become like one of uS

distinctly your own? How do eastern religions (such as Buddhism) differ

Creation
Why;
and when did God create the universe?

How did God create the world? Did he create every different kind of plant and
animal directly; or did he use some kind of evolutionary process, guiding the
development 0f
things from the simplest tO the most complex? And
how
quickly did God bring about creation? Was
all completed within six
twenty-four-hour
or did he use thousands or perhaps millions of years?
How old is the earth; and how old is the human race?
These questions face uS When
deal with the doctrine of creation Unlike
most of the earlier material in this book; this chapter treats several questions
on which
evangelical Christians have differing viewpoints, sometimes very
strongly held ones:
This chapter is
organized to move from those aspects of creation that are mOSt
clearly taught in Scripture, and on which almost all evangelicals would agree
(creation out of
nothing; special creation of Adam and Eve; and the goodness
of the universe), to other aspects of creation about which
evangelicals have
had disagreements (whether God used
process of evolution to bring about
much of creation, and
old the earth and the human race are)
We may define the doctrine of creation as follows: God created the entire
universe Out of nothing;
was riginally very good; and he created it to
glorify himself:

The Creation of Time_
One other aspect of God'$ creation is the creation
of time (the succession of moments one after another). This idea was
discussed with respect t0 God's attribute of eternity in chapter 11_
and we
need only summarize it here:
When we speak of God $ existence "before

Rather; God's eternity means that he has

difficult for us even t0 imagine. (See Job 36.26; Ps. 90.2, 4; John 8.58;
Peter 3.8; Rev: 1.8). The fact that God created time reminds us of his lordship

and our obligation tO use
for his glory
The Work of the Son and of the Holy Spirit in Creation. God the Father

The teaching of Scripture about the relationship between God and creation is
unique among the religions of the world. The Bible teaches that God is
distinct from his creation_
He is not part of it, for he has made it and nles
Uvei
ic The term often used to say that God is much greater than creation is
the word transcendent
simply; this means that God is far
above
the
creation in the sense that he
greater than the creation and he is independent
of it
God is also very much involved in creation, for
is continually dependent on
him for its existence and its functioning-
The technical term used t0 speak of
God's involvement in creation is the
immanent; meaning
remaining in"
creation The God of the Bible is no abstract deity removed from, and
uninterested in his creation. The Bible
the story of God $ involvement with
his creation; and particularly the people in it. Job affirms that even the
animals and plants depend on God: "In his hand is the life of every living
thing and the breath
all mankind" (Job 12.10). In the New Testament; Paul
affirms that God
'gives tO all men life and breath and everything" and that "in
him we live and move and have our being'
(Acts 17.25, 28). Indeed, in Christ
"all things hold together" (Col. 1:17), and he is continually "upholding the
universe by his word of power" (Heb: 1.3). God $ transcendence and
immanence are both affirmed in
single verse when Paul
one God
and Father of us all, who
above all and through all and in all" (Eph: 4.6).

philosophy that sees creation as an "emanation'
