Appicahon
The doctrine of creation has many applications for Christians today. It makes
us realize that the material universe is good in itself; for God created it
and wants US [0 use
in ways pleasing to him. Therefore we should seek to be
like the early Christians_
who
'partook of food with glad and generous hearts"
(Acts 2.46), always with thanksgiving
God and trust in his provisions_
healthy appreciation of creation will keep us from false asceticism that denies
the goodness of creation and the blessings that come t0 uS through it: It will
also encourage some Christians to do scientific and technological research
into the goodness of God's abundant creation; Or t0 support such research
The doctrine of creation will also enable us to recognize more clearly that
scientific and technological study in itself glorifies God, for it enables US t0
discover how incredibly wise, powerful, and skillful God was in his work of
creation:
Great
are the works of the LORD, studied by all who have pleasure
in them'
(Ps. 111.2).
The doctrine of creation also reminds Us that God is sovereign over the
universe he created. He made it all, and he is Lord of all of it. We owe all that
we are and have to him; and we may have complete confidence that he will
ultimately defeat all his enemies and be manifested as Sovereign
worshiped forever: In addition, the incredible size of the universe and the
amazing complexity of every created thing will, if
hearts are right; draw
us continually to worship and praise him for his greatness_
Finally, as we indicated above,
wholeheartedly enjoy creative
activities (artistic, musical, athletic, domestic; literary; etc:) with an attitude of
thanksgiving that our Creator God enables us t0 imitate him in Our creativity.

Chapter 16
God's Providence
If God controls all things, how can our actions have real
meaning? What are the decrees of God?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Once
understand that God is the all-powerful Creator (see chapter 15), it
seems reasonable
conclude that he also preserves and govems everything in
the universe as well. Though the term providence is not found in Scripture;
has been traditionally used to summarize God'$
ongoing relationship
creation: When we accept the biblical doctrine of providence_
avoid four
common errors in
thinking about God'$ relationship to creation: The biblical
doctrine is not deism (which teaches that God created the world and then
essentially abandoned it), nor pantheism (which teaches that the creation does
not have
real, distinct existence in itself; but is only part of God); but
providence, which teaches that though God is actively related to and involved
in the creation at each moment; creation is distinct from him. Moreover; the
biblical doctrine does not teach that events in creation are determined by
chance (0r"
randomness), nor are they determined by impersonal
fate (or
determinism), buc by God
who is the personal yet infinitely powerful Creator
and Lord
We may define God $ providence as follows: God is continually involved with
all created
in such
way that he (1) keeps them existing and
maintaining the properties with which he created them;
cooperates with
created things in every action, directing tneir distinctive properties
cause
them [0 act as they
and (3) directs them to fulfill his purposes:
Under the general category of providence we have three subtopics, according
the three elements
the definition above:
Preservation; (2)
Concurrence, and (3) Govemment:
We shall examine each of these separately, then consider
differing views and
objections t0 the doctrine of providence. It should be noted that this is
doctrine on which there has been substantial
eement among Christians
things
do;
disagre
since the early history of the church, particularly with respect to God s
relationship to the
choices of moral creatures. In this chapter we will
first present
summary of the position favored in this textbook (what is
commonly called the "Reformed" or "Calvinist" position),
then consider
arguments that have been made from another position (what is commonly
called the
Arminian" position).
Pre_cNation
God keeps all created things existing and maintaining the properties with
which he created them:
Hebrews 1.3 tells uS that Christ is
upholding the universe by his word of
power:

bear:
This
commonly used in the New Testament for canying something from one

This second aspect of providence; concurrence, is an expansion of the idea

Events Fully Caused by God and Fully Caused by the Creature as

These creaturely factors and properties
therefore be called the "secondary

even though
are the causes that are evident to us by observation:

On an Arminian View; How Can God Know the Future?: According t0
the Arminian view; our human choices are not caused by God. They are
torally free. But Scripture gives many examples of God predicting the future

this way if it is not certain what will happen?
In response to this question, Arminians give three different kinds of answer:
Some say that God is not able to know details about the future; specifically;
they deny that God is able t0 know what choices individual human beings will
make in the future.
This seems [0 me [0 be the most consistent Arminian
position, but the result is that, while God may be able t0 make some fairly
accurate predictions based on complete knowledge of the present; these
cannot be certain predictions. Ultimately it also means that God is ignorant of
all future human choices_
which means that he does nOr even know what the
stock market will do tomorow;
who will be elected as the next president of
the United States_
0r who will be converted On this view, what event of
human history could God know with certainty in advance? No event
This is
radical revision of the idea of omniscience and seems
be clearly denied by
the dozens 0f examples of
unfailing predictive prophecy in Scripture, the
fulfillment of which demonstrates that God is the true God in opposition to
false
Other Arminians simply affirm that God knows everything that
happen;
but this does not mean that he has planned or caused what will happen
simply means that he has the ability

necessary implication of the Arminian view:
Yet there
implication that is more
troubling: If
choices have t0 allow
for the possibility of choosing evil, then
God $ choices are nOL real, since
he cannot choose evil, or (2) God $ choices are real, and there is the genuine
possibility that God might someday choose to do evil
perhaps
little, and
perhaps
great deal. If we ponder the second implication it becomes
terrifying But it is contrary t0 the abundant testimony of Scripture:
On the
other hand
the first implication is clearly false: God is the definition of what
is real, and it is clearly an error tO say that his choices are not real. Both
implications therefore provide good reason for rejecting the Arminian
position that real choices must allow the possibility of choosing evil. But this
usS back t0 the earlier question for Which there does nOr seem [0 be
satisfactory answer from the Arminian position: How can evil exist if God did
not want it [0 exist?
On an Arminian View, How
We Know That God Will Triumph
Over Evil?: If we go back t0 the Arminian assertion that evil is not
according
to the will of God, another problem arises: if all the evil now in the world
came into the
even though God did not want it, how can we be sure that
God will triumph over it in the end? Of course; God says in Scripture that he
will triumph over evil.
But if he was unable [0
it out of his universe in
the first place and it came in against his will, and if he is unable t0 predict the
outcome of any future events that involve free choices by human, angelic; and
demonic agents; how then can we be sure that God $ declaration that he will
triumph over all evil is in itself tnue? Perhaps this
just
hopeful prediction
of something that (on the Arminian viewpoint) God simply cannot know: Far
from the
incredible freedom from wOry about the future" which the
they
feal
puts
Cau
world
keep
Calvinist has because he knows that an omnipotent God makes
work together for
(Rom: 8.28 KJV); the Arminian position seems
logically
drive US [0
deep-seated anxiety about the ultimate outcome of
history:
Both of these last two objections regarding evil make uS realize that, while we
may have difficulties in
thinking about the Reformed view of evil as ordained
by God and completely under the control of God_
there are far more serious
difficulties with the Arminian view of evil as not ordained 0r even willed by
God
and therefore not assuredly under the control of God
d. The Difference in the Unanswered Questions: Since we are finite in OuI
understanding;
inevitably will have some unanswered questions abour
every biblica)
doctrine. Yet on this issue the questions that Calvinists and
Arminians MUSC
leave unanswered are
different: On the one hand,
Calvinists must say that
do not know the answer t0 the following
questions:
Exactly how God can ordain that we do evil willingly; and yet
God not be blamed for evil.
Exactly how God can cause US
choose something willingly:
To both, Calvinists would say that the answer is somehow to be found in an
d Yaremess
God*s infinite greatness_
in the knowledge of the fact that he can
do far more than we could ever think possible. So the effect of these
unanswered questions is t0 increase our appreciation of the greatness of God_
On the other hand,
Arminians muSt leave unanswered questions regarding
God'$ knowledge of the future
why he would allow evil when
is against his
will, and whether he will certainly triumph over evil: Their failure tO resolve
these questions tends to diminish the greatness of God
his omniscience, his
omnipotence_
and the absolute reliability of his promises for the future: And
these unanswered questions tend to exalt the greatness of man (his freedom t0
do what God does not want) and the power of evil (it comes and remains in
the universe even though God does not want it) Moreover; by denying that
God can make creatures who have real choices that are nevertheless caused
by him, the Arminian position diminishes the wisdom and skill of God the
Creator:

good"

YOu S0 far today?

that way; does it increase 0r decrease your
anxiety about the future?
think for
moment about some events
that you might have attributed to luck in the past: Instead, begin to
about those events as under the control of your wise and loving heavenly
Father: How does that make you feel differently about them and about
the future
generally?

pattern of little "superstitious" actions Or rituals
that you think will bring good luck or prevent bad luck (such as not

ladder; being afraid when
black cat walks across YOuI
path, not stepping on cracks on
sidewalk, carrying
certain item "just
for
etc.)? Do you think those actions tend t0 increase or
decrease your trust in God during the
and your obedience
him?

proper understanding of the doctrine of providence should
lead
Christian t0
more active prayer life

his wonders to perform;

Human

and scan his work in vain;
God is his Own interpreter;

Chapter 47
Miracles
What are miracles? Can they happen today?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
consideration of the subject of miracles
closely connected with God'$
providence, which was considered
the previous chapter: There we argued
that God exercises an extensive, ongoing; sovereign control over all aspects of
his creation
This chapter will assume an understanding of that discussion of
providence and will build on
in approaching the question of miracles
clninanl
We may define
miracle as follows:
miracle
less common kind of God 5
activity in which he arouses people
Ove
and wonder and bears witness 0
himself
This definition takes into account OUr previous understanding of
God'$ providence whereby God preserves, controls_
and governs all
we understand providence in this way; we Will naturally avoid some other
common explanations 0r definitions of miracles
For example_
one definition of miracle is
direct intervention of God in the
world:
But this definition assumes
deistic view of God's relationship to the
world, in which the world continues on its Own and God only intervenes in it
occasionally. This
certainly not the biblical view;
according-
which God
makes the rain to fall (Matt: 5.45), causes the grass
grow (Ps. 104.14), and
continually carries along all things by his word of power (Heb. 1.3).
Another
detinition of miracle is
more direct activity of God in the world
But [0
talk about
more direct"
of God suggests that his ordinary
providential activity is somehow nOr
direct" and
hints
SOIE of
deistic removal of God from the world
Another definition is
God
in the world without using means tO
about the results he wishes
Yet to speak of God
without means
leaves us with very few if any miracles in the Bible, for it is hard tO think of
miracle that came about with no means at all: in the
of people_
for
things.
working
again_
working
bring
working
healing'
example
some of the physical properties of the sick person $ body were
doubtless involved as part of the healing: When Jesus multiplied the loaves
and fishes, he at least used the original five loaves and two fishes that were
there_
When he
changed water t0 wine_
he used water and made it become
wine. This definition seems t0 be inadequate_
Yer another definition of miracle is
an exception to
natural law
God
acting contrary [0 the laws of nature.
But the phrase "laws of nature
popular understanding implies that there are certain qualities inherent in the
things that exist; "laws of nature
that operate independently of God_
and that
God must intervene or "break" these laws for
miracle [0 occur:
Once again
this definition does not adequately account for the biblical teaching on
providence_
Another definition of miracle is
an event impossible tO explain by natural
causes:
This definition is inadequate because ( 1) it does not include God as
the one who
brings about the miracle;
assumes that God does not use
some natural
causes when he works in an unusual or amazing way; and thus it
assumes
that God only occasionally intervenes in the world; and (3) it
will result in
significant minimizing of actual
miracles and an increase in
skepticism, since many times when God works in answer t0 prayer the result
is amazing t0 those who prayed but it is not
absolutely impossible to explain
by natural
causes, especially for
skeptic who simply refuses t0 see God $
hand at work
Therefore_
the original definition given above
where
miracle is simply
less common way of God's working in the world, seems to be preferable and
more consistent with the biblical doctrine of God $ providence.
This
definition does not say that
miracle is
different kind of working by God,
but only that_
less
common way of God $ working and that
is done SO
as t0 arouse people'$
surprise_
awe; Or amazement in such
way that God
bears witness t0 himself.
The biblical terminology for miracles frequently points to this idea of God's
power at work to arouse people's wonder and amazement: Primarily three sets
of terms are employed:
'sign'
(Heb
oth; Gk semeion), which means
something that points to Or indicates something else, especially (with
reference t0 miracles) God's activity and power; (2)
'wonder" (Heb. mopeth;
Gk teras), an event that causes people to be amazed or astonished; and (3)
miracle" or "mighty work" (Heb
"biirah; Gk dynamis), an act displaying
great power; especially (with reference
miracles) divine power:
Often
again
signs and wonders
is used as
stock expression to refer t0 miracles (Ex:
7.3; Deut: 6.22; Ps. 135.9; Acts 4.30; 5.12_
Rom: 15.19; et al.), and
sometimes all three terms are combined; "mighty works and wonders and
signs
(Acts 2.22) or
signs and wonders and mighty works`
(2 Cor: 12.12;
Heb. 2.4).
In addition t0 the meanings of the terms used for miracles_
another reason
supporting our definition is the fact that miracles in Scripture do arouse
people
4we
and amazement and indicate that God $ power is at work: The
Bible frequently tells us that God himself is the one who performs
miracles'
wondrous
Psalm 136.4 says that God is the one "who alone does
great wonders
(cf. Ps. 72.18). The song of Moses declares:
Who is like you; 0 LORD, among the gods?
Who
like you, majestic in holiness_
terrible in glorious deeds, doing wonders? (Ex 15.11)
Thus
the miraculous signs that Moses did when his staff turned into
snake
and back again, 01 when his hand became leprous and then clean again (Ex:
4.2-8),
were given that Moses might demonstrate [0 the people of Israel that
God had sent him. Similarly; the miraculous signs God did by the hand of
Moses and Aaron through the plagues
far surpassing the false miracles or
imitation signs done by the magicians
Pharaoh
court (Ex 7.12; 8.18-19;
9.11) , showed that the people of Israel were those who worshiped the one true
God
When Elijah confronted the priests of Baal
on Mount Carmel ( 1
18.17-40) , the fire from heaven demonstrated that the LORD was the one true
God
Now if we accept the definition that
miracle
less common kind of
God's activity in which he arouses people'$ awe and wonder and bears
witness t0 himself;
then
may ask what kinds of things should be

Of course

right to consider the incarnation of

most important miracles in all history. The events of the exodus such as the
parting of the Red Sea and the fall of Jericho were remarkable miracles_
When Jesus healed people and cleansed lepers and cast out demons, those
were certainly miracles as well (see Matt 11:4-5; Luke 4.36-41; John 2.23;
4.54; 6.2; 20.30-31).
But can we consider unusual answers
prayer t0 be miracles? Apparently s0
if they are remarkable enough to arouse people
awe and wonder and cause
things.
Kings
them [0
acknowledge God"$ power at work: the answer to Elijah's prayer that

miracle ( 1
18.24, 36-38) , as
were the answers to his prayers that the widow $ dead son would come back
to life (1

17.1; 18.41-45 with James 5.17-18). In the New Testament; the release
of Peter
prison
answer 0 the prayers of the church was certainly
miracle (Acts 12.5-17; note also Paul'
prayer for Publius's father in Acts
28.8)
But there must have been many miracles not nearly as dramatic as
those _
because Jesus healed many hundreds of people,
thar were sick
with various diseases
(Luke 4.40).
Paul healed
rest of the people on the
island who had diseases
(Acts 28.9).
On the other hand, Christians see answers t0 prayer every day; and we should
not water down our definition of miracle s0 much that every answer tO prayer
is called
miracle_
But when an answel
prayer is SO remarkable that people
involved with it are amazed and acknowledge God's power at work in an
unusual way; then it seems appropriate t0 call it
miracle
This is consistent
with our definition and seems supported by the biblical evidence that works
of God that aroused people's awe and wonder were called miracles (Gk
dynamis)
But whether we adopt
broad 0r narTow definition of miracle, all should
agree that if God really does work in answer tO Our prayers; whether in
common or uncommon ways, it is important that we recognize this and give
thanks to him, and that we not ignore
O1 go
great lengths
devise
possible
'natural
cavses
explain away what God has
tact done in
answer I0 prayer: While we must be careful not to exaggerate in

prayer;

glorify and thank God for what he has done.

One purpose of miracles is certainly to authenticate the message of the gospel.
was evident in Jesus

Were Mlirada Restricted tO

An Unusual Concentration of Miracles in the Apostles' Ministry: Some

this chapter? ( You may wish to argue for
different definition of
miracle" as well.)
Do miracles have t0 be
large and "remarkable" (such as
the dead
healing
man blind from birth)
accomplish useful purposes in the
church today? What kinds of "small-scale'
miracles might also
accomplish some of the purposes for miracles listed
this chapter?
Have you known of any answers t0 prayer in your Own church (0r your
own life) that you would characterize as "miraculous'
according to the
definition given at the
beginning of the chapter?
Would you like to see more miraculous power of the Holy Spirit (or
MUIE
unusual answers [0
prayer) at work in YOur own church today; Or
not? If more miracles did Occur; what might be the dangers? What might
be the benefits?

bulwark never

not his equal.

our striving would be losing;

from age t0 age the same,

QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Before reading this chapter; did yOu think that most demonic activity Was
confined to the time of the New Testament 0r t0 other cultures than your
own? After

own life or the lives of others around

of fear? Do you think that the Lord

Are there any areas of sin in your Own life nOw that might give
foothold to some demonic activity? [f s0,
what would the Lord have you
do with respect t0 that
Are there cases where you have had victory over some demonic force by
speaking to it in the name of Jesus? How can the material in this chapter
help you be more effective in this kind of spiritual conflict? What are the
dangers of becoming too interested in or tOo deeply involved in this kind
of ministry? How can yOu safeguard against that excessive emphasis?
What do you think Paul's procedure was when he came t0 preach the
gospel in city after city where it had never been heard before and where
there was demon worship? How could the church today
from
Paul $ example?

The Creation of Man
Why did God create us? How did God make us like himself? How
can we please him
everyday living?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The previous chapters have discussed the nature of God and his creation of
the universe, the spiritual beings that he created, and his relationship to the
world in terms of
miracles and
answering prayer: In this next section;
we focus on the pinnacle of God's creative activity, his creation of human
beings, both male and female; to be more like him than anything else he has
made.
We will consider first God'$ purpose in
man and the nature of
man as God created him to be (chapters 21-23). Then we will look at the
nature of sin and man'$ disobedience t0 God (chapter 24). Finally, we
examine the initiation of God's plan for saving man, discussing man'$
relationship to God in the covenants that God established (chapter 25).
The Uxo tla Word Man

J0 the

women. Those who make this objection would prefer that we only use

~humankind
"human

Chapter 22
Man As Male and Female
Why did God create two sexes? Can men and women be equal and
yet have different roles?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
We noted in the previous chapter that one aspect of
creation in the
image
God is his creation as male and temale:
So God created man in his
Own
image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created
them
(Gen: 1.27)
The same connection between creation in the image of
God and creation as male and female is made in Genesis 5.1-2, "When God
created man, he made him in the likeness of God
Male and female he created
them_
and he blessed them and named them Man when
Kere
created_
Although the creation of man as male and female
not the only way in which
we are in the image of God_
it is
significant enough aspect of our creation in
the image of God that Scripture mentions it in the very same verse in which
describes God' $ initial creation of man_
We may summarize the ways in
which our creation as male and female represents something of our creation in
God'$ image as follows:
The creation of man as male and female shows God
image in
harmonious interpersonal relationships,
(2) equality in personhood and
importance_
and
difference in role and authority:
Pertcnal Rditcl-Iup:
God did not create human
be isolated persons
uS in
his image, he made us in such
way that we can attain interpersonal unity of
various sorts in all forms of human society. InterpersonaE
unity can be
especially deep
the human family and also
our" spiritual family, the
church: Between men and women, interpersonal unity comes t0 its fullest
expression in this age in marriage,
where husband and wife become; in
sense, [WO
persons
one:
Therefore
man leaves his father and his mother
and cleaves
his wife; and
become one flesh" (Gen: 2.24). This unity is
man"
they
belugs
but;
making
they
not only
physical unity;
is also
spiritual
and emotional
unity of profound
dimensions.
A husband and wife joined
together in
are people that
"God has joined together" (Matt: 19.6). Sexual union with someone other
than one
Own wife or husband
specially offensive kind of sin against
one
own body
Cor: 6.16
18-20) , and, within marriage_
husbands and
wives no longer have exclusive rule over their Own bodies, but share them
with their spouses
Cor: 7.3-5) . Husbands "should love their wives aS their
own bodies
(Eph: 5.28).
The union between husband and wife is nOr
temporary but
(Mal. 2.14-16; Rom: 7.2), and it is not trivial but is
profound relationship created by God in order t0 picture the relationship
between Christ and his church (Eph: 5.23-32).
The fact that God created two distinct persons as male and female, rather than
just one man, is
of our being in the image of God because
can be seen
reflect [0 some
degree the plurality of persons within the Trinity. In the
verse prior tO the one that tells
creation as male and female,
we see the
first explicit indication of
plurality of persons within God:
Then God said,
Let US make man in our
image
after our likeness; and ler them have
dominion'
(Gen. 1.26)
There is some similarity here: just as there was
fellowship and communication and sharing of glory among the members of
the Trinity before the world was made (see John 17.5, 24,and chapter 14 on
the Trinity; above), so God made Adam and Eve in such
way [hat they
would share love and communication and mutual giving of honor to one
another in their interpersonal relationship. Of course such reflection of the
Trinity would come
expression in various ways within human society, but
it would certainly exist from the beginning in the close interpersonal unity of
marriage.
Someone might object that such
representation of the plurality of persons in
God is not really
complete one
for God is three persons in one while God
created Adam and Eve as only tWo persons in one. If God intended uS t0
reflect the plurality of persons in the Trinity; why did he not create three
persons rather than two who could reflect the interpersonal unity among the
members of the Trinity? FirSt, we must agree that this fact shows the analogy
between
marriage and the Trinity
be an inexact one. Second, although
cannot be certain of the reasons why God did not do
something when
Scripture does not explicitly tell us those reasons;
we can
suggest tWO
possible answers_
The fact that God is three in one while Adam and Eve
were only tWo in one may be
reminder that God' $ Own excellence is far
greater than ours
that he possesses far greater plurality and far greater unity
than we ourselves_
as creatures,
can possess;
(2) [hough the unity is not
exactly the same, the unity in
family among husband, wife, and children,
marriage
lifelong
pant
does also reflect t0 some
degree the interpersonal
unity yet diversity of
persons among the members of the Trinity:
second objection might be raised from the fact that Jesus himself was
unmarried, that Paul was unmarried at the time he was an apostle (and
perhaps earlier) , and that Paul in
Corinthians 7:1,7-9 seems t0 say that it is
better for Christians not to marry: If marriage is such an important part of Our
reflection of the image of God
then why were Paul and Jesus not married_
and why did Paul encourage others not
be married?
For Jesus, the situation is unique; for he is both God and man, and sovereign
Lord over all creation. Rather than being married to any one individual human
being
he has taken the entire church as his bride (see Eph 5.23-32) and
enjoys with each member of his church
spiritual and emotional
unity that
will last for etemity.
The situation with Paul and his advice
the Corinthian Christians is
somewhat different: There Paul does not say that it is wrong to marry (see
Cor: 7.28, 36), but rather views
something good,
right and
privilege that may be given up for the sake of the kingdom of God: "[ think
that in view of the present distress it is well for
person t0 remain as he is

in Colossians 3.18-19 Paul says, "Wives, be subject
your husbands_
as is
fitting
the Lord_
Husbands_
love YOuI wives, and do not be harsh with
them" (see also Titus 2.45;
Peter %.1-7).
Apnlicatio
If our analysis is corect; then there are some practical applications_
particularly within
and also with
regard t0 relationships between
men and women generally:
When husbands begin to act
selfish, harsh; domineering-
or even abusive
being
(Eph:
facl,
taking
obey
marriage,
and chuel ways_
should realize thar this
result of sin
result of the
fall, and is destructive and contrary t0 God $ purposes for them. To act this
way will bring
destructiveness in their
especially in their
marriages_
Husbands must rather fulfill the New Testament commands t0 love
their wives, honor them; be considerate of them, and put them first in their
interests_
Similarly; when wives feel rebellious; resentful of their husband s leadership
in the family, or when they compete with their husbands for leadership in the
family, they should realize that this is
result ot sin;
result of the fall
should not act that way; because O do s0 will
destructive consequences
t0 their
marriages
as well. A wife
t0 act in accordance with God $
pattern should rather be submissive to her husband and agree that he is the
leader in their home and rejoice in that:
Once we have said this_
we MuSL
realize thar there are two other; nearly
opposite
distortions of the biblica
pattern that can occur: If tyranny by the
husband and usurpation of authority by the wife are errors of aggressiveness
there are two other errors, errors of passivity or laziness. For_
husband
the
other extreme from being
domineering "tyrant" is to be entirely passive and
to fail to take initiative in the family
in colloquial terms
to be
'wimp_
this distortion of the biblical pattern;
husband becomes S0
considerate'
his wife that he allows her
make all the decisions and even agrees when she
urges him to do wrong (note this behavior in Adam; Ahab, and Solomon,
among others). Often such
husband is increasingly absent (either physically
emotionally) from the home and occupies his time almost exclusively with
other concems
The
corresponding
error on the part of the wife, opposite of attempting t0
domineer or usurp authority over her husband, is
becoming entirely passive_
contributing nothing to the decision-making process of the family; and being
unwilling
speak words of correction to her husband, even though he is
doing wrong: Submission tO authority does not mean being entirely passive
and agreeing with everything that the person in authority says Or suggests
is certainly not that way when we are submissive t0 the authority ot an
employer or of government officials (we can certainly differ with our
government and still be subject to it); Or even of the authority of the officers
in a church (we can be subject tO them even though we may disagree with
some of their decisions).
wife can certainly be subject to the authority of
her husband and still participate fully in the decision-=
process of the
family:
they
lives;
grear
They
bring
desiring
-making
Husbands
therefore, should aim for
considerate, thoughtful leadership
in their families_
Wives should aim for active, intelligent, joyful submission
their husbands' authority. In avoiding both kinds of mistakes and following
biblical pattem_
husbands and wives will discover true biblical manhood and
womanhood
all of their noble dignity and joyful complementarity; as God
created them to be, and will thus reflect more fully the image of God in their
lives.

Chapter 2
The Essential Nature of Man
What does Scripture mean by "soul" and "spirit"?
Are they the same thing?
EXPLANATION
SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Introduction:
Trichommu
Dichotomu and Monism
How many parts are there
man? Everyone agrees that we have
physical bodies. Most people (both Christians and non-Christians)
sense that they also have an immaterial part
soul" that will live
after their bodies die.
But here the agreement ends. Some people believe that in addition
"body
and
soul" we have
third part;
"spirit" that most
directly relates to God. The view that man is made of three parts
(body; soul, and spirit) is called trichotomy ` Though this has been
common view in popular
evangelical Bible teaching, there are few
scholarly defenses of it today:
According
many trichotomists,
man
soul includes his intellect; his emotions
and his will:
They
maintain that all people have such
soul; and that the different
elements of the soul can either serve God or be yielded to sin: They
argue that man' $ spirit is
higher faculty in man that comes alive
when
person becomes
Christian (see Rom: 8.10: "If Christ is in
YOu; although your bodies are dead because of sin,
spirits are
alive because of righteousness
The spirit of
person then would
be that part of
or her that most directly worships and prays
God (see John 4.24; Phil. 3.3).
Others have said that
spirit" is not
separate part of man; but
simply another term for
soul;
and that both terms are used
interchangeably in Scripture to talk about the immaterial part of
man; the part that lives on after our bodies die:
The view that man is
made Up of two parts (body and soullspirit) is called dichotomy:
Those who hold this view often agree that Scripture uses the word
AND
your
hin
spirit (Heb. riach, and Gk pneuma) more frequently when
referring tO our relationship to God, but such usage (they say) is not
uniform, and the word soul is also used in all the ways that spirit
can be used:
Outside the realm of
evangelical thought we find yet another view;
the idea that man cannot exist at all apart from
physical body, and
therefore there can be no separate existence for any
soul" after the
body dies (although this view can allow for the resurrection of the
whole person ar some future time). The view that man is only one
element; and that his body is the person_
is called monism:
According
monism, the scriptural terms soul and spirit are just
other expressions for the
person'
himself, or for the person'$
"life_
This view has nOt
generally been adopted by evangelical
theologians because s0 many scriptural texts seem clearly t0 affirm
that our souls or spirits live on after our bodies die (see Gen: 35.18;
31.5; Luke 23.43, 46; Acts 7.59; Phil. 1.23-24; 2 Cor: 5.8; Heb:
12.23; Rev. 6.9; 20.4; and chapter 42_
on the intermediate state
below)
But the other tWo views continue [0 be held in the Christian world
today. Although dichotomy has been held more commonly through
the history of the church and is far more common among
evangelical scholars today; trichotomy has also had many
supporters_
This chapter will support the dichotomist view that man is [WO
parts
and soul (or spirit), but we shall also examine the
arguments for trichotomy
MblielcWam
Before
whether Scripture views
soul" and "spirit" as
distinct parts of man; we must at the outset make it clear that the
emphasis of Scripture is on the overall unity of man as created by
God:
When God made man he "breathed into his nostrils the breath
of life; and man became
being" (Gen: 2.7)
Here Adam is
unified person with body and soul living and acting
This
original harmonious and unified state of man will occur again when
Christ returns and we are fully redeemed in our bodies as well as
souls to live with him forever (see
Cor: 15.51-54) . Moreover;
we are t0 grow in holiness and love for God in every aspect of 0uI
body
asking `
living
together;
lives
in our bodies as well as in our spirits or souls (cf:
Cor:
7.34).
We are t0 "cleanse ourselves from every defilement of body
and spirit, and make holiness perfect in the fear of God" (2 Cor:
7.1).
But once we have emphasized the fact that God created uS t0 have
unity between body and soul, and that
action we take in this
life is an act of our whole person;
involving to some extent both
body and soul, then we can g0 on
point out that Scripture quite
clearly teaches that there is an immateria
part of man '$ nature_
And
we can investigate what that part is like_
Scripture Uses "Soul" and *Spirit" Interchangeably: When we look at
the usage of the biblical words translated
soul" (Heb_

Conclusion. Although the arguments for trichotomy do have some force
none of them provides conclusive evidence that would overcome the wide
testimony of Scripture showing that the terms soul and spirit are frequently
interchangeable and are in many cases synonymous:
We might also note the observation of Louis Berkhof on the origin
of trichotomy:
The tripartite conception of man originated in Greek philosophy;
which conceived of the relation of the body and the spirit of man t0
each other after the
of the mutual relation berween the
material
universe and God. It was thought that, just as the latter could
enter into communion with each other only by means of
third
substance 0r an intermediate
So the former could enter into
mutual vital relationships only by means of
third or intermediate
element; namely; the soul:
Some trichotomists today have
tendency t0
related error
that also was found in Greek philosophy
the idea thar the material
world, including our bodies
essentially
and something
King
they
living
analogy
being:
adopt
evil
escaped from. The danger is to say that the realm of the
spirit" is

of the value
our physical bodies as created by God and
(Gen. 1.31), and therefore as something t0 be presented t0
God

Trichotomy can also have an anti-intellectual
tendency: If we think
of the spirit as that element of us that relates most directly t0 God,
and if we think that the spirit is something distinct from our
intellect, emotions; and will, we can easily fall into an anti-
intellectual kind of Christianity that thinks that vigorous academic
work is somehow
unspiritual"
view that contradicts Jesus
command t0 love God with all our "mind" (Mark 12.30) and Paul $
desire to "take every thought captive t0 obey Christ" (2 Cor: 10.5).
Such
separation of the realm of the
spirit"

contradiction t0 Paul's

making decisions; and place t0O much

the realm of guidance, an

Finally; trichotomy can
subtlely influence US to think that our

By contrast; if

What is the origin of our individual souls? Two views have been
common in the history of the church_
Creationism is the view that God creates
et
soul for each person
and sends it to that person's body sometime between conception
and birth. Traducianism, 0n the other hand_
holds that the soul as
well as the body of
child are inherited from the baby'
mother and
father at the time of conception_
Both views have had numerous
defenders in the history of the church; with creationism eventually
becoming the prevailing view in the Roman Catholic Church:
Luther was in favor of traducianism; while Calvin favored
creationism. On the other hand
there are some later Calvinist
theologians such as Jonathan Edwards and A. H: Strong who
favored traducianism (as do most Lutherans today) Creationism
has had many modern evangelical advocates as well.
There is one other popular view called pre-existentianism, namely,

the soul
earth tO be joined with the baby'$ body as he or she

Chapter 24
Sin
What is sin? Where did it come from? Do we inherit
sinful
nature from Adam? Do we inherit
from Adam?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The Definitian of Sin
The history of the human race as presented in Scripture is primarily
history
of man in
state of sin and rebellion against God and of God $ plan of
redemption t0 bring man back to himself Therefore, it is appropriate nOw t0
consider the nature of the sin that separates man from God_
We may define sin as follows: Sin is any failure to conform [0 the moral law
of God in aCt; attitude, or nature. Sin is here defined in relation to God and
his moral law. Sin includes not only individual acts such as
lying
committing murder; but also attitudes that are contrary to the attitudes God
requires of uS_
We see this already in the Ten Commandments, which not only
prohibit sinful actions but also wrong attitudes:
You shall not covet yOuI
neighbor's house_
You shall not covet your neighbor's wife;
or his manservant
maidservant; his OX Or donkey;
anything that belongs
your neighbor"
(Ex. 20.17 NIV) Here God specifies that
desire [0 steal O1 [0 commit
adultery
also sin in his sight The Sermon on the Mount also prohibits sinful
attitudes such as anger (Matt. 5.22) or lust (Matt: 5.28). Paul lists attitudes
such as
jealousy, anger; and selfishness (Gal. 5.20) as things that are
works of
the flesh opposed t0 the desires of the Spirit (Gal: 5.20). Therefore
life that
pleasing
God is one that has moral purity not only in its actions_
but also
in its desires of heart: In fact, the greatest commandment of all requires that
our heart be filled with an attitude of love for God:
You shall love the Lord
your God with all your heart; and with all your soul, and with all your mind,
and with all your strength'
(Mark 12.30).
The definition of sin given above specifies that sin is
failure t0 conform tO
God'$ moral law not only in action and in attitude, but also in our moral
nature. Our very nature, the internal character that is the essence of who we
are as persons
can also be sinful. Before we were redeemed by Christ, not
guilt
stealing
only did we do sinful acts and have sinful attitudes_
we were also sinners by
nature. So Paul can say that "while we were yet sinners Christ died for us'
(Rom: 5.8), 0r that previously "we were by nature children of wrath; like the
rest
of mankind" (Eph 2.3). Even while asleep_
unbeliever; though nor
committing sinful actions 0r actively nurturing sinful attitudes, is still
sinner" in God's sight; he or she still has
sinful nature that does not
conform [0 God'
moral law:
Other definitions of the essential character
of sin have been suggested.
Probably the most common definition is tO say that the essence
sin is
selfishness_
However; such
definition is unsatisfactory because
Scripture itself does not define sin this way: (2) Much self-interest is good and
approved by Scripture, as when Jesus commands us to "lay up for yourselves
treasures in heaven" (Matt_ 6.20), or when we seek tO grow in sanctification
and Christian maturity ( 1
Thess. 4.3), or even when
we come to God through
Christ for salvation. God certainly appeals t0 the self-interest of sinful people
when he says
"Tum back, turn back from your evil ways; for why will you
die,
0 house of Israel?" (Ezek: 33.11). To define the essential character of sin
as selfishness will lead many people t0 think that they should abandon all
desire for their Own personal benefit; which is certainly contrary to Scripture:
Much sin is not selfishness in the ordinary sense of the term
people can
show selfless devotion t0
talse
or to secular and humanistic
educational
political goals that are contrary t0 Scripture, yet these would
not be due t0 "selfishness"
in any ordinary sense of the word. Moreover;
hatred of God, idolatry; and unbelief are not generally due to selfishness, but
they are very serious sins: (4) Such

Does Our Ability Limit Our Responsibility? Pelagius
popular
Christian teacher active in Rome about AD 383-410 and then later (until
AD. 424) in Palestine, taught that God holds man responsible only for those
things that man is able t0 do. Since God warns US to do good, therefore, We
must have the ability to do the good that God commands. The Pelagian
position rejects the doctrine of "inherited sin" (or "original sin"
and
maintains that sin consists only in separate sinful acts.
However; the idea that we are responsible before God only for what we are
able to do is contrary t0 the testimony of Scripture; which affirms both that
were dead through the trespasses and sins'
in which
once walked
(Eph 2:1), and thus unable to do any spiritual good, and also that we are all
guilty before God. Moreover; if Our responsibility before God were limited by

Rom. 3.25). Paul realizes that if Christ had not
come
pay the penalty for sins,
God could not be shown to be righteous_
Because he had passed over sins and not punished them in the past; people
they
They
This
speaks
could rightly accuse God of unrighteousness_
the assumption being that
God
who does not punish sins is not
righteous God. Therefore, when God sent
Christ t0 die and pay the penalty for our sins, he showed how he could still be
righteous
he had stored up the punishment due to previous sins (those of
Old Testament saints_
and then, in perfect righteousness, he gave that penalty
Jesus on the cross. The propitiation of Calvary thereby clearly
demonstrated that God is perfectly righteous: "it was to prove at the present
time that he himself is righteous and that he justifies him who has faith in
Jesus" (Rom. 3.26).
Therefore in the cross we have
clear demonstration of the reason God
punishes sin: if he did not punish sin he would not be
righteous God, and
there would be no ultimate justice in the universe
But when sin is punished,
God is showing himself to be
righteous judge over all, and justice is being
done in his universe.

Chapter 25
The Covenants Between God and Man
What principles determine the way God relates t0 us?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
How does God relate t0 man? Since the creation of the world
God's
relationship
man has been defined by specific requirements and promises_
God tells people how he wants them
act and also makes promises about
how he will act toward them in various circumstances_
The Bible contains
several summaries of the provisions that define the different relationships
between God and man that occur in Scripture
and
often calls these
summaries
covenants.
With respect to covenants between God and man in
Scripture_
we may give the following definition:
covenant iS an
unchangeable , divinely imposed legal agreement between God and man that
stipulates the conditions of their relationship:
Although this definition includes the word agreement in order t0 show that
there are tWo parties, God and man, who must enter into the provisions of the
relationship, the phrase "divinely imposed" is also included to show that man
can never
negotiate with God or change the terms of the covenant: he can
only accept the covenant obligations 0r reject them: Probably for this reason
the Greek translators of the Old Testament (known as the Septuagint), and,
following them, the New Testament authors_
did not use the ordinary Greek
word for contracts or agreements in which both parties were equal (syntheke),
but rather chose
less
LUMMUM
word, diatheke, which emphasized that the
provisions of the covenant were laid down by one of the parties only (In facL;
the word diatheke was often used t0 refer [0
"testament"
0r "will" that a
person would leave to assign the distribution of his or her
after death )
This definition also notes that covenants are "unchangeable_
They may be
superseded or replaced by
different covenant; but
may not be changed
once they are established. Although there have been many additional details
specified in the covenants God has made with man throughout the history of
Scripture_
the essential element at the heart of all of them is the promise;
will be their God, and they shall be my people
(Jer: 31.33; 2 Cor: 6.16; et
goods
they
al.)
Since the covenant relationship between God and man occurs in various
forms throughout Scripture from Genesis to Revelation;
treatment of this
subject might be put at several different points in the study of systematic
theology:
have put
here at the end of the treatment of man as created (in
the image of God) and man as fallen into sin_
but before the discussion of the
person and work of Christ:
Anenine
Klnr
Some have questioned whether it is appropriate t0 speak of
covenant of
works thar God had with Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. The actual
word covenant is nOr used in the Genesis narratives.
However; the essential
parts of the covenant are all there
clear definition of the parties involved,
legally binding set of provisions that stipulates the conditions of their
relationship, the promise of
for obedience, and the condition for
obtaining those blessings. Moreover; Hosea 6.7, in referring t0 the sins of
Israel, says, "But like Adam they transgressed the covenant
(RSV mg;; s0
NIV; NASB)
This passage views Adam as
covenant
relationship that he then transgressed in the Garden of Eden
In addition, in
Romans 5.12-21 Paul sees both Adam and Christ as heads of
people whom
they represent;
something that would be entirely consistent with the idea of
Adam being in
covenant before the fall
In the Garden of Eden; it seems quite clear that there was
legally binding set
of provisions that defined the conditions of the relationship between God and
man_
The two parties are evident as God
to Adam and gives
commands t0 him. The requirements of the relationship are clearly defined in
the commands that God gave to Adam and Eve (Gen. 1.28-30; cf: 2:15) and
in the direct command to Adam; "You may freely eat of every tree of the
garden; but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat; for
in the day that YOu eat of it YOu shall die" (Gen: 2.16-17).
In this statement t0 Adam about the tree of the
knowledge of good and evil
there is
promise of punishment for disobedience
death; most fully
understood to mean death in an extensive sense, physical, spiritual, and
eternal death and separation from God_
In the promise of punishment for
disobedience there is implicit
promise of blessing for obedience. This
would consist of not
receiving death, and the implication is that the
would be the opposite of
death: '
It would involve physical life that
would not end and spiritual life in terms of
relationship with God that would
blessings
existing
speaks
blessing
blessing

Chapter 26
The Person of Christ
How is Jesus fully God and fully man; yet one person?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
We may summarize the biblical teaching about the person of Christ as
follows: Jesus Christ was fully God and fully man in one person, and will be
forever:

Brief Summary Sentence: Sometimes in the study of systematic theology;
the following sentence has been used to summarize the incarnation:
Remaining what he was_
he became what he was nOL
In other words
while
Jesus continued "remaining
what he was (that is, fully divine)
he also
became what he previously had not been (that is, fully human as well) Jesus
did not give up any of his deity when he became man, but he did take on
humanity that was not his before_
#Communication" of Attributes: Once we have decided that Jesus
fully man and fully God, and that his human nature remained fully human and
his divine nature remained fully divine,
we can still ask whether there were
some

communicated"
trom one
nature t0 the other:
seems there were.
"the
Maly
(1) From the Divine Nature t0 the Human Nature: Although Jesus
human
nature did not change its essential character; because it was united with the
divine nature in the one person of Christ; Jesus' human nature gained (a)
worthiness to be worshiped and (b) an inability to sin, both of which did not
belong to human beings otherwise.
(2) From the Human Nature t0 the Divine Nature: Jesus
human nature
gave him (a) an ability to experience suffering and death; (b) an ability t0
understand by experience what we are experiencing; and (c) an ability t0 be
substitute sacrifice
which Jesus as God alone could not have done:

may be easy for US [0 lose

-far more

The fact that the infinite
omnipotent;, eternal Son of God could become man and join himself to
human nature forever; SO that infinite God became one person with finite man,
will remain for eternity the most profound miracle and the most profound
mystery in all the universe_

Chapter 22
The Atonement
Was it necessary for Christ t0 die? Did Christ' s entire earthly life
earn any saving benefits for us? The cause and nature of the
atonement Did Christ descend into hell?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
We may define the atonement as follows: The atonement is the work Christ
did in his life and death to earn our salvation. This definition indicates that
we are
the word atonement in
broader sense than it is sometimes used.
Sometimes
used t0 refer only t0 Jesus' dying and paying for our sins on
the crOSS_
But, as will be seen below; since saving benefits also come [0 4S
from Christ'$ life, we have included that in our definition as well
WneEE
Anneinemg
What was the ultimate cause that led to Christ' $
earth and
dying for
our sins? To find this we must trace the question back to
something
in the
character of God himself: And here Scripture points t0
things: the love
and justice of God.
The love of God as
cause of the atonement
seen in the most familiar
passage in the Bible: "For God so loved the world that he
his only Son,
that whoever believes in him should not perish but have eternal life'
(John
3.16). But the justice of God also required that God find
way thal the
penalty due t0 us for our sins would be paid (for he could not accept 4S into
fellowship with himself unless the penalty was paid) Paul explains that this
was why God sent Christ t0 be
propitiation'
(Rom_
3.25 NASB) (that is,
sacrifice that bears God $ wrath s0 that God becomes "propitious
favorably disposed toward us): it was "t0 show God s righteousness, because
in his divine forbearance he had passed over former sins
(Rom 3.25). Here
Paul says that God had been forgiving sins in the Old Testament but no
penalty had been paid
fact that would make people wonder whether
was indeed just and ask how he could forgive sins without
penalty. No God
using
coming.
gave
God
who was truly just could do
could he? Yer when God sent Christ t0 die
and pay the penalty for our sins,
"it was t0 prove at the present time that he
himself is righteous and that he justifies him who has faith in Jesus'
(Rom
3.26).
Therefore both the love and the
justice of God were the ultimate cause of the
atonement. It is not helpful for uS t0 ask which is more important; however;
because without the love of God_
he would never have taken any steps to
redeem US, yet without the justice of God, the specific requirement that Christ
should eam Our salvation by dying for OuI sins would not have been met.
Both the love and the
ustice of God were equally important
The Necestir
Was there any other way for God to save human beings than by sending his
Son
die in our
place?
Before answering this question_
it is important t0 realize that it was not
necessary for God tO save any people at all:
When we
appreciate that
God
did not spare the angels when they sinned_
but cast them into hell and
committed them to pits of nether gloom to be
until the judgment"
Peter 2.4), then we realize that God could also have chosen with perfect
justice to have left us in our sins awaiting judgment: he could have chosen to
save no one, just as he did with the sinful
angels.
So in this sense the
atonement was nO
absolutely necessary:
But once God, in his love, decided to save some human beings
then several
passages in Scripture indicate that there was n other way for God t0 do this
than through the death of his Son. Therefore
the atonement was nOC
absolutely necessary; but; as
consequence
of God $ decision
Sdâ‚¬ sumE
human
beings, the atonement was absolutely necessary This is sometimes
called the
consequent absolute necessity" view of the atonement:
In the Garden of Gethsemane Jesus prays_
"If ic be possible, let this cup pass
from me; nevertheless; not as
will, but as YOu will" (Matt: 26.39). We may
be confident that Jesus always prayed according to the will of the Father; and
that he always prayed with fullness of faith Thus
seems that this prayer;
which Matthew takes
record fOr US
shows thar
was not possible for
Jesus [0 avoid the death on the cross
which was soon
[0 come t0 him (the
cup"
suffering that he had said would be
If he was going to
accomplish the work that the Father sent him tO do, and if people were going
be redeemed for God
then it was necessary for him to die on the cross_
that;
kepi
pains
his).
He said
something similar after his resurrection, when he was talking with
DYO
disciples on the road to Emmaus. They were sad that Jesus had died, but
his response was_
"0 foolish men, and slow of heart to believe all that the
prophets have spoken! Was
not necessary that the Christ should suffer these
things and enter into his glory?
(Luke 24.25-26). Jesus understood that
God's plan of redemption (which he explained for the disciples from many
Old Testament Scriptures; Luke 24.27) made it necessary for the Messiah to
die for the sins of his people.
As we saw above_
Paul in Romans 3 also shows that if God were t0 be
righteous, and still save people, he had to send Christ tO pay the penalty for
sins: "It was t0 prove at the present time that he himself is righteous and that
he justifies him who has faith in Jesus" (Rom 3.26). The
[0 the
Hebrews emphasizes that Christ had tO suffer for 0ur sins: "He had to be
made like his brethren in every respect; S0 that he might become
merciful
and faithful high priest
the service ot God,
make expiation [lit.
'propitiation
for the sins of the people" (Heb: 2.17). The author of Hebrews
also argues that since "it is impossible that the blood of bulls and goats should
take away sins
(Heb. 10.4),
better sacrifice is required (Heb 9.23). Only
the blood of Christ; that is, his death; would be able really t0 take away sins
(Heb. 9.25-26). There was no other way for God t0 save US than for Christ t0
die in our place:
Nte
In this section we consider tWo aspects of Christ's work: (1) Christ's
obedience for us, in which he obeyed the requirements of the law in our place
and was perfectly obedient t0 the will of God the Father as OUI representative_
and
Christ'$ sufferings for US
in which he took the penalty due for 0ur
sins and as
result died fOr 0uT sins.
It is important t0 notice that in both of these categories the primary emphasis
and the primary influence of Christ'$ work of redemption is nOt On US, but 0n
God the Father: Jesus obeyed the Father in our place and perfectly met the
demands of the law: And he suffered in our place;
receiving
in himself the
penalty that God the Father would have visited upon us_
In both cases_
the
atonement is viewed as objective; that is, something that has primary
influence directly on God himself: Only secondarily does it have application
[0 4S, and this
only because there was
definite event in the relationship
between God the Father and God the Son that secured
salvation:
Christ'$ Obedience for Us (Sometimes Called His
Active Obedience"
If Christ had only earned
forgiveness of sins for US, then we would not merit
epistle
Ralure =
OM
heaven_
Our guilc
would have been removed, but we would simply be in the
position of Adam and Eve before they had done anything good or bad and
before they had passed
time of probation successfully To be established in
righteousness forever and to have their fellowship with God made sure
forever; Adam and Eve had to obey God perfectly over
period of time. Then
God would have looked on their faithful obedience with pleasure and delight;
and they would have lived with him in fellowship forever:
For this reason, Christ had to live
life of perfect obedience to God in order
0 earn
righteousness for uS_
He had t0 obey the law for his whole life on our
behalf so that the positive merits of his perfect obedience would be counted
for uS . Sometimes this is called Christ'$
active Obedience _
while his
suffering and dying for Our sins is called his ""passive obedience.
Paul says
is that he may be found in Christ;
not
having
righteousness of
[his] own, based on law; but that which is through faith in Christ; the
righteousness from God that depends on faith" (Phil 3.9) It is not just moral
neutrality that Paul knows he needs from Christ (that is,
clean slate with sins
forgiven), but
positive moral
righteousness:
And he knows that that cannot
come from himself; but must come through faith in Christ. Similarly; Paul
says that Christ has been made
our righteousness"
Cor: 1.30). And he
quite explicitly says;
For as by one man'
disobedience many were made
sinners_
so by one man
obedience many will be made righteous
(Rom:
5.19).
Some
theologians have not taught that Christ needed to achieve
record

One of the differences berween Reformed
theologians and other Catholic and
Protestant theologians has been the question of the extent of the atonement
The question may be put this way: when Christ died on the cross, did he pay
for the sins of the entire human race 0r only for the sins of those who he knew
would ultimately be saved?
Non-Reformed people argue that the gospel offer in Scripture is repeatedly
made to all people, and for this offer to be genuine, the payment for sins must
have already been made and must be actually available for all people. They
long
long
keeping
leading-
also say that if the people whose sins Christ paid for are limited, then the free
offer of the gospel also is limited, and the offer of the gospel cannot be made
to all mankind without exception:
On the other hand, Reformed people argue that if Christ'$ death actually paid
for the sins of every person who ever lived, then there is no penalty left for
anyone [0 pay; and
necessarily follows that all people will be saved_
without
exception
For God could not condemn tO eternal punishment anyone whose
sins are already paid for: that would be demanding double payment and
would therefore be unjust: In answer t0 the objection that this compromises
the free offer of the gospel to every person, Reformed people answer that we
do not know who they are who will come t0 trust in Christ, for only God
knows that:
As far as
are concered, the free offer of the gospel is to be
made t0 everybody without exception:
We also know that everyone who
repents and believes in Christ will be saved, s0 all are called to repentance (cf:
Acts 17.30). The fact that God foreknew who would be saved, and that he
accepted Christ'$ death as payment for their sins only; does not inhibit the free
offer of the gospel, for who will respond to it is hidden in the secret counsels
of God
That we do not know who will respond no more constitutes
reason
for not offering the gospel to all than not knowing the extent of the harvest
prevents the farmer from sowing seed in his fields_
Finally,
Reformed people argue that God's purposes in redemption are agreed
upon within the Trinity and they are certainly accomplished. Those whom
God planned to save are the same people for whom Christ also came to die,
and to those same people the Holy Spirit will certainly apply the benefits of
Christ'$ redemptive work, even awakening their faith (John 1:12; Phil. 1.29;
cf: Eph: 2.2) and calling them tO trust in him
What God the Father purposed_
God the Son and the Holy Spirit agreed to and surely carried out:

clear on the fact that the death of Christ has no benefit for
person unless that
person believes in Christ: Therefore
the
problem seems to be more something
that Reformed people think unbelievers should believe (if they were
consistent in reasoning back into the secret counsels of God and the
relationship between the Father and Son in the counsels of the Trinity at the
point of Christ' =
propitiatory sacrifice on the cross)
But unbelievers simply
do not reason that way: they know that they must exercise taith
Christ
before
will experience any benefits from his saving work Moreover; it is
far more likely that people will understand the sentence "Christ died for your
sins" in the doctrinally correct sense that "Christ died in order
offer you
forgiveness for your sins" rather than in the doctrinally incorrect sense,
"Christ died and completely paid the penalty already for all your sins.
3. In terms of the practical, pastoral effects of Our words, both those who hold
particular redemption and those who hold to general redemption agree at
several key points:
likc
they
speak
very
they
Both sincerely want t0 avoid
implying that people will be saved whether
they believe in Christ 0r nOt. Non-Reformed people sometimes accuse
Reformed people of saying that the elect will be saved irrespective of
responding
the gospel, but this is clearly
misrepresentation of the
Reformed position.
Un the other hand_
Reformed people think that those who
hold to generaba
redemption are in danger of implying that everybody will be
saved whether
believe in Christ 0r' nOL. Bur this
nol
position that non -
Reformed people actually hold, and it is always precarious t0 criticize people
for
position that they do nOt say they hold, just because YOu think that they
should hold that position if they were consistent with their other views:
b. Both sides want [0 avoid
implying that there might be some people who
come t0 Christ for salvation but are turned away because Christ did not die
for them. No one wants tO say 0r imply to an unbeliever; "Christ might have
died for your sins (and then again he might not havel)
Both sides want [0
clearly affirm that all who come t0 Christ for salvation will
tact be saved:
"Him who comes t0 me
will not cast out" (John 6.37)_
Both sides want [O avoid
implying that God is hypocritical or insincere
when he makes the free offer of the gospel. It is _
genuine offer; and it is
always true that all who wish
come
Christ for salvation and who do
actually come to him will be saved_
Finally;
may ask why this matter is S0 important after all. Although
Reformed people have sometimes made belief in particular redemption
test
of doctrinal orthodoxy; it would be healthy tO realize that Scripture itself
never
singles this out as
doctrine of major importance, nor does
once
make it the subject of any explicit theological discussion
Our knowledge of
the issue comes only from incidental references tO it in passages whose
concern is with other doctrinal 0r practical matters_
In fact; this is really
question that probes into the inner counsels of the Trinity and does S0 in an
area in which there is very little direct scriptural
testimony
fact that should
cause S [0 be cautious_
A balanced pastoral perspective would seem to be to
say that this
of particular redemption seems t0 US t0 be true; that it
gives logical consistency t0 OuI theological system, and that
can be helpful
in assuring people of Christ's love for them individually and of the
completeness of his redemptive work for them; but that it also is
subject that
almost inevitably leads [0 some
confusion, some
misunderstanding; and often
some wrongful argumentativeness and divisiveness among God's people
of which are negative pastoral considerations Perhaps that is why the apostles
such as John and Peter and Paul;
their wisdom, placed almost no emphasis
on this question at all. And perhaps we would do well to ponder their
they
teaching
example_
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL
APPLICATON
In what ways has this chapter enabled you to appreciate Christ'$ death
more than you did before? Has it given YOu more 0r less confidence in
the fact that your sins have actually been paid for by Christ?
If the ultimate cause of the atonement is found in the love and justice of
God, then was there
anything in YOu that required God to love YOu Or to
take steps to save YOu (when he looked forward and thought of you as
sinner in rebellion against him)? Does your answer t0 this question help
you [0
appreciate the character of God's love for YOu as
person who did
not at all deserve that love? How does that realization make you feel in
your relationship t0 God?
Do you think that Christ'$
were enough t0 pay for your sins?
Are you willing to rely on his work t0 pay for all your sins? Do you
think he is
sufficient Savior; worthy of yOur trust? When he invites
YOW,
Come 0 me
and
will give YOu rest" (Matt: 11:28) , do you
now trust him? Will yOu now and always rely on him with your whole
heart for complete salvation?
If Christ bore all the guilt for our sins, all the wrath of God against sin,
and all the penalty of the death that we deserved_
then
God ever turn
his wrath
you as
believer (see Rom: 8.31-39)? Can any of the
hardships 0r
sufferings that You experience in life be due to the wrath of
God against
If not; then why do we as Christians experience
difficulties and sufferings in this life (see Rom. 8.28; Heb. 12.3-11)?
Do you think Christ's life was good enough to deserve God's approval?
Are yOU
willing to rely on it for YOur eternal destiny? Is Jesus Christ a
reliable enough and good enough Savior for YOu tO trust him? Which
would YOu rather trust in for YOur eternal standing before God: your own
life or Christ' s?
If Christ has indeed redeemed you
bondage [0 sin and t0 the
kingdom of Satan; are there areas of your life in which you could more
fully realize this to be true? Could this realization give YOu more
encouragement
your Christian life?
Do You think it was fair for Christ tO be your substitute and t0 pay your
penalty? When You think about him acting as YOur substitute and dying
for YOu_
what attitude and emotion is called forth in your heart?

3. Christ Was Seated at God's Right Hand (Christ's Session). One specific
aspect of Christ $ ascension into heaven and receiving of honor was the fact
that he sat down at the right hand of God. This is sometimes called his session
at God'$ right hand:
The Old Testament predicted that the Messiah would sit at the right hand of
God: "The LORD says t0 my lord: *Sit at my right hand, till
make your
enemies your footstool'
(Ps. 110.1). When Christ ascended back into heaven
he received the fulfillment of that promise:
When he had made purification
for sins
he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high" (Heb: 1.3)
This web
into the presence of God and
at God $ right hand is
dramatic indication of the completion of Christ'$ work of redemption: Just as
human being
sit down at the completion of
large task [0 enjoy the
satisfaction of having accomplished it, so Jesus sat at the right hand of God,
visibly demonstrating that his work of redemption was completed.
In addition
showing the completion of Christ's work of redemption, the act
of sitting at God'$ right hand is an indication that he received authority over
the universe. Paul says that God
raised him from the dead and made him sit
at his right hand in the heavenly places_
far above all rule and authority and
power and dominion_
and above every name that is named" (Eph:
1.20-21).
Similarly, Peter says that Jesus "has gone into heaven and is at the right hand
of God_
with angels, authorities, and powers subject to him" (1 Peter 3.22).
Paul also alludes t0 Psalm 110:1 when he says that Christ "muSt reign until he
has put all his enemies under his feet"
Cor: 15.25).
One additional aspect of the authority that Christ received from the Father
when he sat at his right hand was the authority t0 pour out the Holy Spirit on
the church_
Peter says on the Day of Pentecost;
Being therefore exalted at the
right hand of God_
and having received from the Father the promise of the
Holy Spirit; he has poured out this which you see and hear" (Acts 2.33).
The fact that Jesus nOw sits at the right hand of God in heaven does not mean
that he is perpetually "fixed" there or that he is inactive. He is also seen as
standing at God s right hand (Acts 7.56) and as walking among the seven
lampstands in heaven (Rev: 2.1). Just as
human
sits on his
royal
throne at his accession to the kingship, but then engages in many other
activities throughout each day; so Christ sat at the right hand of God as
dramatic evidence of the completion of his redemptive work and his reception
of authority over the universe_
but he is certainly engaged in other activities in
heaven as well:

sitting
will

Christ's Ascension Has Doctrinal Significance for Our Lives. Just as the
resurrection has profound implications for our lives_
so Christ' $ ascension has
significant implications for US. First, since we are united with Christ in every
aspect of his work of redemption;
Christ'$ going Up into heaven
foreshadows our future ascension into heaven with him: "We who are alive;
who are left, shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the
Lord in the air; and S0 we shall always be with the Lord" (1 Thess. 4.17)
The
author of Hebrews wants US [0 run the race of life with the knowledge that we
are following
Jesus' steps and will eventually arrive at the blessings of life
in heaven that he is now enjoying: "Let US run with perseverance the race that
is ser before uS,
to Jesus the pioneer and perfecter of our faith, who
for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame_
and is seated at the right hand of the throne of God" (Heb. 12.1-2).
And Jesus
himself says that he will one day take us t0 be with himself (John 14.3)
Second;
Jesus

ascended into heaven and achieved the
set before him gives great

uS that we will eventually go there also.
Third, because of our union with Christ in his ascension; we are
to share

and we will later share

with him, and made us sit with him in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus"

t0 come: "Do you not know that we are
judge angels?"
Cor: 6.3).

In talking about the life, death, and resurrection of Christ; theologians have
sometimes talked about the
states of Jesus Christ
By this they mean the
different relationships Jesus had to God's law for mankind_
to the possession
of authority, and t0
receiving honor for himself. Generally two states
(humiliation and exaltation) are distinguished. Thus, the doctrine of "the
rwofold state of Christ" is the
that Christ experienced first the state
of humiliation, then the state of exaltation:
Within the humiliation of Christ are included his incarnation, suffering; death;
and burial. Sometimes
fifth aspect (descent into hell) is included
but as
explained above; the position taken in this book is that that concept is nOt
supported in Scripture
In the exaltation of Christ, there are also four aspects: his resurrection,
ascension into heaven, session at the right hand of God
and return in glory
and power: Many systematic theologies use the state of humiliation and the
state of exaltation as broad categories
organize their discussion of Jesus
work:

Chapter 29
The Offices of Christ
How is Christ prophet; priest; and king?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
There were three major offices among the people of Israel in the Old
Testament: the prophet (such as Nathan,
Sam: 7.2), the priest (such as
Abiathar;
Sam: 30.7)
and the king (such as
David,
Sam: 5.3). These
three offices were distinct The prophet spoke God'
words t0 the people; the
priest offered sacrifices_
prayers_
and praises to God on behalf of the people;
and the
ruled over the people as God $ representative_
These three offices
foreshadowed Christ'$ own work in different ways. Therefore we can look
at Christ'
work; nOw
thinking about the perspective of these three
offices 01
categories_
Christ fulfills these three offices in the
following ways:
as prophet he reveals God tO us and speaks God's words t0 us; as priest he
both offers
sacrifice t0 God on our behalf and is himself the sacrifice that is
offered; and as
he rules over the church and over the universe as well.
We nOw
uI
discuss each of these offices

Chapter 30
The Work of the Holy Spirit
What are the distinctive activities of the Holy Spirit throughout the
history of the Bible?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
In the previous chapters we have discussed at some length the
person and work of God the Father; and, more recently, the person
and work of God the Son, Jesus Christ. We have also examined the
biblical evidence for the deity and distinct personality of the Holy
Spirit (in connection with the doctrine of the Trinity). It is
appropriate nOW in this chapter that we focus on the distinctive
work of the Holy Spirit Among the different activities of the
members of the Trinity; what activities are said to be especially the
work of God the Holy Spirit?
We should realize at the outset that other chapters in this book deal
more or less directly with certain aspects of the Holy Spirit'$ work
The chapters on baptism in and
filling with the Holy Spirit (39) and
the gifts of the Holy Spirit (52-53) deal almost entirely with
specific works of the Holy Spirit Moreover; the chapters on the
authority of Scripture
prayer (18) , the gospel call (33),
regeneration (34), sanctification (38) , perseverance (40),
glorification (42), church discipline (46), the means of grace within
the church (48), and worship (51) all treat various aspects of the
Holy Spirit' $ work
the worid, and especially in the lives of
believers
Nonetheless
in this chapter we shall attempt to gain an
overview of the teaching of all of Scripture on the work of the Holy
Spirit in order t0 understand more fully what kinds of activities
have been especially delegated to the Holy Spirit by God the Father
and God the Son:
We may define the work of the Holy Spirit as follows: The work of
the Holy Spirit
[0 manifest the active presence of God in the
world, and especially in the church: This definition indicates that
the Holy Spirit is the member of the Trinity whom the Scripture
most often represents as
present t0 do God's work in the
world. Although this is true tO some extent throughout the Bible, it
is particularly true in the new covenant age. In the Old Testament;
the presence of God was many times manifested in the glory of God
and
theophanies
and in the
gospels Jesus himself manifested the
presence of God among men. But after Jesus ascended into heaven,
and
continuing through the entire church age, the
Spirit is now
the primary manifestation of the presence of the Trinity among uS_
He is the one who is most prominently present with us now:
From the very beginning of creation we have an indication that the
Holy Spirit $ work is t0 complete and sustain what God the Father
has planned and what God the Son has begun; for in Genesis 1.2,
"the Spirit of God was moving over the face of the waters:
And at
Pentecost; with the beginning of the new creation in Christ; it is the
Holy Spirit who comes t0 grant power [0 the church (Acts 1.8; 2.4,
17-18). Because the Holy Spirit is the person of the Trinity through
whom God particularly manifests his presence in the new covenant
age, it is appropriate that Paul should call the Holy Spirit the
fnuits'
(Rom_
8.23) and the
guarantee
down payment;
Cor: 1.22; 5.5) of the full manifestation of God $ presence that we
know in the new heavens and new earth (cf: Rev 21.3-4).
Even in the Old Testament; it was predicted that the presence of the
Holy Spirit would bring abundant blessings from God: Isaiah
predicted
time when the Spirit would bring great renewal
For the palace will be forsaken; the populous city deserted
until

Similarly, God prophesied through Isaiah t0 Jacob, "For

By contrast; the departure of the Holy Spirit removed the blessing

In what specific ways does the Holy Spirit
God $ blessing?
We may distinguish four aspects of the work of the Holy Spirit to

the Holy Spirit
empowers;
the Holy Spirit purifies; (3) the Holy Spirit reveals;
