Chapter 3
Common Grace
What are the undeserved blessings that God gives t0 all people,
both believers and unbelievers?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Introduction and Definition
When Adam and Eve sinned,
became worthy of eternal
punishment and separation from God (Gen: 2.17). In the same way;
when human beings sin today they become liable t0 the wrath of
God and to eternal punishment: "The wages of sin is death" (Rom:
6.23). This means that once people sin
God'$ justice would require
only one thing
that they be eternally separated from God, cut off
from experiencing any
from him, and that they live forever in
hell, receiving only his wrath eternally: In
this was what
happened to angels who sinned, and it could justly have happened
LO 4S as well: "God did not spare the angels when they sinned, but
cast them into hell and committed them t0 pits of nether gloom to
be kept until the judgment"
(2 Peter 2.4).
But in fact Adam and Eve did not die at once (though the sentence
of death began to be worked out in their lives on the
thev
sinned). The full execution of the sentence of death was delayed for
many years. Moreover; millions of their descendants even
this
do not die and g0 to hell as soon as
sin; but continue [0
live for many years, enjoying countless
in this world:
How can this be? How can God continue tO give blessings I0
sinners who deserve only death
~not only
those who
ultimately be saved, but also to millions who will never be saved_
whose sins will never be forgiven?
The answer t0 these questions is that God bestows common grace:
We may define common grace as follows: Common grace is the
grace of God by which he gives people innumerable blessings that
are nOc
part of salvation: The word common here means something
they
good
fact;
day -
day
they -
blessings _
Will
that is common t0 all people and is not restricted t0 believers 0r to
the elect only:
In distinction from common grace; the grace of God that brings
people to salvation
often called "saving grace:
Of course_
when
we talk about
common grace
and "saving grace
Ke 4rE
not
implying that there are two different kinds of grace in God himself;
but only that God $ grace manifests itself in the world in two
different ways:
Common grace is different from saving grace in its
results (it does not bring about salvation), in its recipients (it is
given to believers and unbelievers alike). and in its source (it does
not directly flow from Christ $ atoning work; since Christ $ death
did not eam any measure of
forgiveness for unbelievers, and
therefore did not merit the blessings of common grace for them
either) However; on this last point it should be said that common
grace does
indirectly from Christ'$ redemptive work; because
the fact that God did not judge the world at once when sin entered it
was primarily or perhaps exclusively due to the fact that he planned
eventually to save some sinners through the death of his Son.-
Erample
OIIn Arjcr

everyday life_

every breath that people take is of grace

Common Grace and Special Grace Influence Each Other: Common

8. Common Grace Does Not Save People_
In spite of all of this,
must

Common grace does
not

people t0 genuine repentance and faith
it cannot and does not save
(though in the intellectua
and moral

accepting the gospel) Common grace restrains sin but does not change
anyone'$ foundational disposition t0 sin, nor does
in any significant
measure purify fallen human nature
We must also

approval or favor: These actions do not spring from faith
"Whatever does nOt proceed from faith is sin;
Rom: 14.23), nor

some form or another: Therefore, although we may readily

in terms of meriting God

common grace than believers
may be more skillful, harder
working;
more

Why does God bestow common grace on undeserving sinners who

But the day of
the Lord will come like
thief" (2 Peter 3.9-10). In fact; this reason was true

that they might have an

and also s0 that they would bear children and enable

Chapter 32
Election and Reprobation
When and why did God choose us? Are some not chosen?
In the earlier chapters we talked about the fact that we all have
sinned and deserve eternal punishment from God, and the fact that
Christ died and earned salvation for US. But nOw in this unit
(chapters 32-43) we will look at the way God applies that salvation
[O our lives.
We begin in this chapter with God's work of election,
that is, his decision [0 choose US t0 be saved before the foundation
of the world. This act of election is, of course_
nor (strictly
speaking_
part of the application of salvation t0 US, since
came
before Christ earned our salvation when he died on the cross. But
treat election at this point because it is chronologically the
beginning of God $ dealing with us in
gracious way: Therefore,
is rightly thought of as the first step in the process of God'$
bringing salvation t0 us individually:
Other steps in God $ work of
applying salvation to our lives include
our
the gospel call, our being regenerated by the Holy
Spirit;
responding in faith and repentance, and God forgiving uS
and giving 4s membership in his family; as well as granting 4S
growth in the Christian life and
keeping us faithful to himself
throughout life
At the end of our life we die and go into his
presence, then when Christ returs we receive resurrection bodies,
and the process of
acquiring salvation is complete_
Various theologians have given specific terms to
number of these
events, and have often listed them in
specific order in which they
believe that
occur in our lives
Such
list of the events in
which God applies salvation tO US is called the order of salvation,
and
sometimes referred to by
Latin phrase, ordo salutis, which
simply means
order of salvation_
Before discussing any of these
elements in the application of salvation t0 our lives_
we can give
complete list here of the elements that will be treated in the
hearing `
they
following chapters:
"The Order of Salvation'
Election (God $ choice of people t0 be saved)
The gospel call (proclaiming the message of the gospel)
Regeneration (being born again)
Conversion (faith and repentance)
Justification (right legal
Adoption (membership in God s family)
Sanctification (right conduct of life)
8. Perseverance (remaining
Christian)
Death (going to be with the Lord)
10. Glorification (receiving
resurection body)
We should note here that items 2
and part of
are all involved in
"becoming
Christian.
Numbers
and
work themselves out in this life
number
occurs at the end of this life_
and number 10 occurs when Christ

We begin our discussion of the order of salvation with the first
element; election. In connection with this we will also discuss at the
end of this chapter the question of "reprobation;
the decision of
God to pass over those who will not be saved, and to punish them
for their sins.
As will be explained below, election and reprobation
are different in several important respects
and it is important tO
distinguish these so that we do not think wrongly about God or his
activily.
The term predestination is also frequently used in this discussion.
In this textbook; and in Reformed
theology generally,
predestination is
broadel
term and includes the two aspects of
election (for believers) and reprobation (for unbelievers) However;
the term double predestination
not
helpful term because it gives
standing)
the impression that both election and reprobation are carried out in
the same way by God and have no essential differences between
them, which is certainly not true. Therefore, the term double
predestination is not generally used by Reformed theologians
though it is sometimes used t0 refer [0 Reformed [eaching by those
who criticize it: The term double predestination will not be used in
this book t0 refer t0 election and reprobation, since it blurs the
distinctions between them and does not give an accurate indication
of what is actually being taught:
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
We may define election as follows: Election is an act of God before
creation in which he chooses some people t0 be saved, nOt on
account of any foreseen merit in them; but only because of his
sovereign good pleasure:
There has been much controversy in the church and much
misunderstanding
over this doctrine. Many of the controversial
questions regarding man '$ will and responsibility and regarding the
justice of God with respect to human choices have been discussed
some length in connection with God' $ providence (chapter 16).
We will focus here only on those additional questions that apply
specifically to the question of election:
Our approach in this chapter will be first simply t0 cite
number of
passages from the New Testament that discuss election. Then we
will attempr tO understand the purpose of God that the New
Testament authors see in the doctrine of election. Finally, we will
attempt to clarify our
understanding of this doctrine and answer
some
objections, and also t0 consider the doctrine of reprobation:

Another objection to

One common solution to this question (from the Reformed

The verses

We also muSt remember that there are important differences

Practical nppichhon
WeNTI
Iecnn
In terms of our Own
relationship with God
the doctrine of election
does have significant practical application. When we think of the
biblical teaching on both election and reprobation, it is appropriate
apply it to our own lives individually: It is right for each
Christian t0 ask of himself or herself;
Why am
Christian? What
is the final reason why God decided to save me?"
The doctrine of election tells uS that
am
Christian simply
because God in eternity past decided to set his love on me_
But why
did he decide
set his love on me? Not for
anything good in me;_
but simply because he decided to love me. There is no more
ultimate reason than that:
It humbles us before God to think in this way. It makes US realize
that we have no claim on God'$ grace whatsoever: Our salvation is
totally due
grace alone
Our only appropriate response is t0 give
God eternal praise
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL
APPLICATOR
Do you think that God chose YOu individually to be saved before he
created the world? Do you think he did it on the basis of the fact that he
knew YOu would believe in Christ, Or was it
unconditional election;
not
based
anything that he foresaw in you that made YOu worthy of his
love? No matter how YOu answered the previous question, explain how
your answer makes YOu feel when you think about yourself in
relationship t0 God
Does the doctrine of election give You any comfort Or assurance about
your future?
After reading this chapter; do you honestly feel
that you would like to
give thanks or praise
God for choosing YOu t0 be saved? Do you sense
any unfairness in the fact that God did not decide to save everyone?
If you agree with the doctrine of election as presented in this chapter;
does it diminish your sense of individual personhood 0r make you feel
somewhat like
robor or
puppet in God'
hands? Do you think it
should make you feel this way?
What effect do you think this chapter will have on YOur motivation for
evangelism? Is this
positive or negative effect? Can you think of ways
in which the doctrine of election can be used as
positive
encouragement t0 evangelism (see
Thess:
1.4-5;
Tim: 2.10)?
Whether you adopt
Reformed or Arminian perspective on the question
of election
can you think of some positive benefits in the Christian life
that those who hold the opposite position from yours seem more
frequently to experience than you do? Even though you do not agree
with the other position; can yOu list some helpful concems 0r practical
truths about the Christian life that YOu might learn from that position? Is
there
anything that Calvinists and Arminians could do to bring about
greater understanding and less division on this question?

The Gospel Call and Effective Calling
What is the gospel message? How does
become effective?

salvation into ur

Those whom he predestined he also called; and

ag0_

QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Can yOu remember the
time you heard the gospel and responded
it? Can you describe what it felt like in your heart? Do you think the
Holy Spirit was
make that gospel call effective in your life?
Did you resist it at the time?

what difference would it make if you

those elements are important t0 add? What is the one thing most needed
make your proclamation of the gospel
more effective?
Before
this chapter; had you thought of Jesus in heaven speaking
the words of the gospel invitation personally t0 people even today? If
MUM -
Christians do begin to think of Jesus speaking t0 them in this way,
how do you think it will affect their response t0 the gospel?
Do you understand the elements of the gospel call clearly enough to
present them to others? Could yOu easily turn in the Bible to find four or
five appropriate verses that would explain the gospel call clearly
people? (Memorizing the elements of the gospel call and the verses that
explain it should be one of the first disciplines of anyone's Christian
life.)

We may define regeneration as follows: Regeneration is
secret act
of God
which he imparts new spiritual life t0 US. This is
sometimes called "being born again'

Recematation
Totallz
Work ol God

"born
"born

Have you been born again? Is there evidence of the new birth in your

Chapter 35
Conversion (Faith and Repentance)
What is true repentance? What is saving faith? Can people accept
Jesus as Savior and not as Lord?
The last two chapters have explained how God himself (through the
human preaching of the Word) issues the gospel call to us and, by
the work of the Holy Spirit, regenerates US, imparting new spiritual
life within. In this chapter we examine OuI response tO the
gospel
call:
We may define conversion as follows: Conversion is our
willing response to the gospel call,
which we sincerely repent of
sins and place our trust in Christ for salvation:
The word conversion itself means
turning'
here it represents
spiritua
tur
turning from sin to Christ: The turning
sin is
called repentance_
and the
Christ is called faith: We can
look at each of these
lements of conversion, and in one sense it
does not matter which one we discuss first; for neither one can
occur without the other; and they must occur together when true
conversion takes place: For the purposes of this chapter;
shall
examine saving faith first, and then repentance

we may ask whether anyone in the gospels ever came
t0 sincere faith in Christ without
repenting of his or her sins.
When we realize that genuine saving faith must be accompanied by
genuine repentance for sin, it helps us to understand why some
preaching of the gospeL
has such inadequate results today If there is
no mention of the need for repentance, sometimes the gospel
message becomes only; "Believe
Jesus Christ and be saved"
without any mention of repentance at all:
But this watered-down
version of the gospel does not ask for
wholehearted commitment
Christ-
commitment to Christ; if genuine, must include
commitment t0 turn from sin_
Preaching the need for faith without
repentance i5
preaching only half of the gospel. It will result in
many people being deceived, thinking that they have heard the
Christian gospeE
and tried it; but nothing has happened: 'They might
pven
say
something like;
accepted Christ as Savior over and over
again and it never worked_
Yet they never really did receive Christ
as their Savior; for he comes to us in his majesty and invites US t0
receive him as he is
the one who deserves [0 be
and demands t0
absolute Lord of our lives as well.
Finally; what shall we say about the common practice of asking
people t0 pray t0 receive Christ as their personal Savior and Lord?
Since personal faith in Christ must involve an actual decision of the
will, it is often very helpful to express that decision in spoken
words_
and this could
naturally take the form of
prayer
they
asking '
guods
repaid
very
Christ in which we tell him of OuT SOTTow for sin; our' commitment
forsake it, and our decision actually t0 put our trust in him. Such
spoken prayer does not in itself save 4S_
but the attitude of heart
that
represents does constitute true conversion, and the decision
speak that prayer can often be the point at which
person truly
comes
faith in Christ:
Doth Faith
Continue Throughout Life
Although
have been considering initial faith and repentance as
the two aspects of conversion at the beginning of the Christian life,
it is important
realize that faith and repentance are not confined
the beginning of the Christian life: They are rather attitudes of
heart that continue throughout our lives as Christians. Jesus tells his
disciples tO pray daily;
And forgive US our sins as we also have
forgiven those who sin against us"
(Matt. 6.12, author
translation),
prayer
genuine
will certainly involve daily
SOITOw for sin and genuine repentance:
And the risen Christ says t0
the church
Laodicea
'Those whom
love,
reprove and chasten;
so be zealous and repent-
(Rev: 3.19; cf:
Cor: 7:10).
With regard to faith, Paul tells uS
So faith; hope, love abide, these
three; but the greatest of these is love'
Cor: 13.13). He certainly
means that these three abide throughout the course of this life; but
he probably also means that they abide for all eternity: if faith is
trusting God to provide all Our needs
then this attitude will never
cease
not even in the age t0 come:
But in any case; the point is
clearly made that faith continues throughout this life
Paul also
says, "The life
now live in the flesh
live by faith in the Son of
God, who loved me and
himself for me"
(Gal: 2.20).
Therefore; although it is tnue that initial saving faith and initial
repentanc
occur only once in our lives, and when they occur they
constitute true conversion, nonetheless
the heart attitudes of
repentance and faith only
begin
conversion. These same attitudes
should continue throughout the course of our Christian lives. Each
day there should be heartfelt repentance for sins that we have
committed_
and faith in Christ t0 provide for Our needs and t0
empower US t0 live the Christian life.

Chapter 36
Justification (Right Legal Standing Before
God)
How and when do we gain right legal standing before God?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
In the previous chapters we talked about the gospel call (in which
God calls us t0 trust in Christ for salvation), regeneration (in which
God imparts new spiritual life t0 uS), and conversion (in which we
respond
the gospeL
call in repentance for sin and faith in Christ
for salvation). But what about the guilt of our sin? The gospel call
invited us [0 tNust in Christ for
forgiveness of sins. Regeneration
made
possible for US tO respond to that invitation. In conversion
we did respond
trusting in Christ for forgiveness of sins Now the
next step in the process of applying redemption t0 us is that God
must respond
our faith and do what he promised, that is, actually
declare our sins to be forgiven: This must be
legal declaration
concerning our relationship to God s laws, stating that we are
completely forgiven and no longer liable to punishment.
A right understanding of justification
absolutely crucial to the
whole Christian faith: Once Martin Luther realized the truth of
justification by faith alone_
he became
Christian and overflowed
with the new-found joy of the gospel. The primary issue in the
Protestant Reformation was
dispute with the Roman Catholic
Church over justification:
we are to safeguard the truth of the
gospeba
for future generations
we must understand the truth of
justification.
Even today;
true view of justification is the
line between the biblical gospel of salvation by faith alone and all
false gospels of salvation based on good works.
When Paul gives an overview of the process by which God applies
salvation t0 US, he mentions justification explicitly: "Those whom
he predestined he also called; and those whom he called he also
dividing
justified; and those whom he justified he also glorified" (Rom:
8.30). As we explained in
previous chapter; the word called here
refers to the effective calling of the gospel, which includes
regeneration and brings forth the response of repentance and faith
(or
conversion) on our part After effective calling and the response
that
initiates 0n our part; the next step in the application of
redemption is "justification
Here Paul mentions that this is
something that God himself does:
Those whom he called he also
justified
Moreover; Paul quite clearly teaches that this justification comes
after our faith and as God $ response [0 our faith_
He says that God
"justifies him who has faith in Jesus'
(Rom: 3.26) , and that
man
justified by faith apart from works of law'
(Rom. 3.28). He says,;
"Since we are justified by faith; we have peace with God through
our Lord Jesus Christ" (Rom: 5.1). Moreover;
man
not
justified by works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ" (Gal.
2.16).
Just what is justification? We may define it as follows: Justification
is an instantaneous legal act of God
which he (1) thinks 0f our
sins as
forgiven and Christ $ righteousness as belonging to US, and
(2) declares uS I0 be righteous in his sight
In explaining the elements of this definition
we will look first at
the second half of
the aspect of justification
which God
declares uS to be righteous in his sight:
The reason for
these items in reverse order is that the emphasis of the New
Testament in the use of the word justification and related terms is
on the second half of the definition_
the legal declaration by God:
But there are also passages that show that this declaration is based
on the fact that God fist thinks
righteousness as belonging t0 uS_
So both aspects must be treated,
pven
though the New Testament
terms for justification focus on the legal declaration by God
dnehnclanneinclude
Leal Dedaratiol
The use of the word justify in the Bible indicates that justification is
legal declaration by God. The verb justify in the New Testament
(Gk dikaioo) has
range of meanings
but
common sense is
"to declare righteous_
For example_
read, "When they heard
this all the people and the tax collectors justified God, having been
baptized with the baptism of John" (Luke 7:29). Of course the
treating
very
people and the tax collectors did not make God to be righteous
that would be impossible for anyone t0 do. Rather they declared
God to be righteous. This is also the sense of the term in passages
where the New Testament (alks about uS
declared righteous
by God (Rom 3.20,26, 28; 5.1; 8.30; 10.4,10; Gal. 2.16; 3.24).
sense
particularly evident;, tor example_
in Romans 4.5:
"And to one who does not work but trusts him who justifies the
ungodly, his faith is reckoned as righteousness:
Here Paul cannor
mean that God
makes the
ungodly to be righteous'
(by changing
them internally and making them morally perfect), for then they
would have merit Or works of their Own to depend on. Rather; he
means that God declares the
ungodly to be righteous in his sight
not on the basis of their good works, but
response
their faith.
The idea that justification is
legal declaration is quite evident also
when justification is contrasted with condemnation_
Paul says,
shall bring any charge against God's elect? It is God who
justifies:
who is t0 condemn?" (Rom_
8.33-34).
condemn"
someone is tO declare that person
guilty The opposite of
condemnation is justification, which, in this context; must mean "tO
declare someone not guilty:
This is also evident from the fact that
God'$ act of
justifying
given as Paul $ answer t0 the possibility of
someone bringing an accusation OF
charge" against God'$ people:
such
declaration of
cannot stand in the face of God's
declaration of righteousness_
Some Old Testament examples of the word justify (Gk dikaioo in
the Septuagint; when translating the hiphil of tsadak; "to justify'
add support t0 this
understanding: For example;
we read of
judges
who "justify the righteous and condemn the wicked" (Deut: 25.1
NASB) Now in this case "justify" must mean "declare to be
righteous or nOt
guilty;" just as
condemn'
means
declare to be
guilty:
It would make no sense t0 say that "justify" here means "to
make someone t0 be
internally;
for judges simply do not and
cannot make people t0 be
on the inside: Nor does
judge
act
condemning
the wicked make that person to be evil on the
inside;
simply declares that the person is guilty with respect tO the
particular crime that has been brought before the court (cf: Ex:
23.7;
Kings 8.32;
Chron. 6.23). Similarly, Job refuses to say
that his comforters were right in what
said:
Far be it from me
that
should declare you right"
(Job 27:5 NASB, using the same
Hebrew and Greek terms for "justify"
The same idea is found in
being
This
"Who
Euilt
good
good
they
Proverbs: "He who justifies the wicked and he who condemns the
righteous are both alike an abomination to the LORD
(Prov: 17.15).
Here the idea of legal declaration is especially strong: Certainly
would not be an abomination t0 the Lord if "justify" meant "to
make someone
righteous inside-
In thal case
to "justify
the wicked" would be
good thing in God'$ sight: But if
"justify" means
declare to be righteous,
then it is perfectly clear
why "he who justifies the wicked" is
an abomination t0 the LORD:
Similarly, Isaiah condemns those
'who justify the wicked for
bribe" (Isa. 5.23 NASB); again, "justify'
must mean
declare t0 be
righteous
(here used in the context of
legal declaration).
In this sense of
declare to be righteous'
declare to be not
guilty" Paul frequently uses the word to speak of God'$ justification
of us, his declaration that we, though
guilty sinners
are nonetheless
righteous in his sight It is important
emphasize that this legal
declaration in itself does nOt change our internal
nature 0r character
at all In this sense of "justify;
God issues
legal declaration about
This is why theologians have also said that justification is
forensic; where the word forensic means "having t0 do with
proceedings_
John Murray makes an important distinction between regeneration
and justification:
Regeneration is an act of God
uS; justification is a judgment of God
with respect to us. The distinction is like that of the distinction between
the act of
surgeon and the act of
judge. The surgeon, when he
removes an inward cancer; does
something
in VS_
That is nOt what
judge does
he gives
verdict
regarding our judicial status. If we are
innocent he declares accordingly
The purity of the gospel is bound up with the
recognition of this
distinction. If justification is confused with regeneration or
sanctification; then the door is opened for the perversion of the gospel
at its center: Justification is still the article of the standing or falling of
the Church:
UendeWecarno
Sizht
In God'$ legal declaration of justification
he specifically declares
that we are just in his sight: This declaration involves two aspects_
Bood
very
legal
First, it means that he declares that we have no penalty t0 pay for
sin,
including past; present; and future sins_
After _
long discussion
of justification by faith alone (Rom: 4:1-5.21), and
parenthetical
discussion on remaining sin in the Christian life_
Paul returns [0 his
main argument in the book of Romans and tells what
true of
those who have been justified by faith: "There
therefore nOw no
condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus
(Rom: &.1). In this
sense those who are justified have nO penalty t0 pay for sin. This
means that we are not subject to any charge of
condemnation:
shall bring any charge against God 's elect? It
is God who justifies; who is to condemn?" (Rom: 8.33-34).
The idea of full
forgiveness of sins
prominent when Paul
discusses justification by faith alone in Romans
Paul quotes
David as pronouncing
blessing on one
[0 whom God reckons
righteousness apart from works_
He then recalls how David said,
"Blessed are those
whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are
covered; blessed is the man

Another

QUESTIONS FOR
PERSONAL
APPLICATOR
Look back over the list of privileges that come with our adoption as
God s children.
Had you previously thought of these as automatically
yours because you had been born again? Can you describe what our
eternal
life would be like if we had regeneration and justification and
many of the other
privileges that come with salvation; but no adoption
into God s family? Now how do you feel about the fact that God has
adopted you into his family compared with the way you felt before
reading this chapter?
Has your relationship with your Own human family become better or
more difficult as
result of your
becoming _
Christian? If your
relationship with your earthly family has become more difficult; how
have you found Mark 10.29-30 to be tnue in your life as
Christian?
Sometimes people who have had
unloving
01 cruel
earthly fathers have
found that their background creates difficulty in their thinking about God
and relating to him as
heavenly Father: How can Hebrews 12.10,
Matthew 7.11
and Luke 11.13, which contrast sinful earthly fathers with
our
perfect Father in heaven, be of help in that situation? Might
Peter
1.18 be helpful in this situation as well? What can
person who has had
cruel
and unloving earthly father do [0 gain
better and better
appreciation of who God is and what kind of Father he is? Do YOu think
that any of the people who became Christians in the first century had
cruel
and
unloving fathers,
01 nO
living fathers at all? What teachings of
the Old Testament would have helped them at this point? Do you think
thac people who have had
earthly fathers have
God-given inward
sense of what
father would be like?
Think of the people who are members of your church
Has this chapter
helped you
think of them more as your brothers and sisters (0r if they
are
older; as those who are like "fathers
and
mothers" to you)? How do
you think an added appreciation of this idea of the church as
family
would be helpful to your church? How could you encourage
greater
appreciation of this idea?
Does your church have any sense of competition with other churches that
might be overcome by greater appreciation of the doctrine of adoption?
In the human family; when one of the children commits
crime and is
publicly punished for
the entire family suffers shame
On the other
hand
when
family member is honored for an
outstanding achievement,
the entire family is proud and rejoices. How does this analogy of events
human family make you feel about YOur own personal level of
holiness in life, and the way
reflects on the other members of your
spiritual family? How does
make you feel about the need for personal
holiness among your brothers and sisters
the church? Do you
personally have
strong inward desire t0 imitate your heavenly Father in
your conduct (Eph: 5.1;
Peter 1.14-16)?
Do you sense the Holy Spirit within you bearing witness with your spirit
that your are
child of God (Rom. 8.15-16; Gal. 46)? Can You describe
what that sense is like?
Do you sense any discrimination against Christians of other races 0r
other social 0r economic
positions? Can yOu understand how the
doctrine of adoption should obliterate such distinctions in the church (see
Gal. 3.26-28)? Can you also see how the doctrine of adoption means that
neither men nor women should think of the other sex as more important
or less important in the church (see Gal. 3.28)?

Chapter 38
Sanctification
(Growth in Likeness to Christ)
How do we grow in Christian maturity?

EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The previous chapters have discussed several acts of God that occur
at the beginning of our Christian lives
the gospel call (which God
addresses to us), regeneration (by which God imparts new life to
us) , justification (by which God gives US right legal standing before
him), and adoption (in which God makes uS members of his
family) We have also discussed conversion (in which we repent of
sins and trust in Christ for salvation) These events all occur at the
beginning of our Christian lives
But nOw we come [0
part of the application of redemption that is
progressive work that continues throughout our earthly lives. It is
also
work in which God and man cooperate, each playing distinct
roles_
This part of the application of redemption is called
sanctification: Sanctification is
progressive work of God and man
that makes US more and more free from sin and like Christ in
actual lives.

QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Can yOu remember in your Own experience the definite
beginning to
sanctification that occurred when you became
Christian? Did you sense
clear break from the
power and love of sin in your life? Do you
really believe that yOu are even now dead to the ruling power and love of
sin in your life? How can this truth of the Christian life be of help to you
specific areas of your life where YOu still need to grow in
sanctification?
As you look back over the last few years of your Christian life, can yOu
see
pattern of definite growth in sanctification? What are some
that you used to delight in which no longer interest you? What are some
things that you used
have no interest
that now hold
interest for
you?
As you have grown tO greater maturity and holiness in the Christian life,
have you become more conscious of the weight of sin that remains in
your heart? If nOt; why has this not been so? Do you think that it would
be helpful if you had
greater consciousness of the sin that remains in
your own life?
you had this,
what difference would it make in your
Uwn
life?
would it affect your life if yOu thought more about the fact that the
Holy Spirit is continually at work in YOu t0 increase your sanctification?
In living the Christian life
have YOu maintained
balance between your
passive role and your active role in sanctification; 0r have YOu tended tO
emphasize one aspect over the other; and why? What might you do to
correct this imbalance; if there is one in your life?
Have YOu thought previously that sanctification affects your intellect and
goal
hope
long
ruling
things
great
How
the way you think? What areas of your intellect still need quite
bit of
growth in sanctification? With
to your emotions
in what areas do
you know that God still needs to work to bring about greater
sanctification? Are there areas or aspects of sanctification that need t0 be
improved with respect
your physical body and its obedience
God'$
purposes?
Are there areas where you have struggled for years t0 grow in
sanctification, but with no progress at all in your life? Has this chapter
helped you regain hope for progress in those areas? (For Christians who
have serious
discouragement over lack of progress in sanctification; it is
very important t0 talk personally to
pastor Or other mature Christian
about this situation, rather than
g0 on for
long period of time:)
Overall, has this chapter been an encouragement Or discouragement tO
you in your Christian life?

Should we seek a "baptism in the

What does
mean
be filled with the Holy Spirit?
Systematic theology books have not traditionally included

But with the spread of Pentecostalism that began in 1901

have put this

But this question concems an event that occurs either at

conversion

sides of the question agree that some kind of second experience has
happened to many people after their conversion, and therefore one
very important question is how to understand this experience in the
light of Scripture and what scriptural categories properly apply to it

With regard to this topic of baptism in or being filled with the
Spirit; do you think that
evangelical churches generally have been
toward more divisiveness or more unity on this issue?

fruit" is always

Chapter 44
Death and the Intermediate State
What is the purpose of death in the Christian life? What happens
our bodies and souls when we die?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Why Do Christians Die?
Our treatment of the application of redemption must include
consideration of death and the question of how Christians should
view their own death and the death of others_
We also muSt ask
whal
happens
[0 uS between the time that we die and the time that
Christ returns
give US new resurrection bodies_
Death Is Not
Punishment for Christians. Paul tells uS clearly that there
no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus" (Rom: 8.1). All the
penalty for our sins has been
Therefore, even though we know that
Christians die,
should not view the death of Christians as
punishment
from God or in any way
result of
penalty due to us for our sins_
It is tNe
that the penalty for sin is death, but that penalty no longer applies to uS
not
in terms of physicab
death; and not in terms of spiritual death 0r separation
from God: All of that has been paid for by Christ: Therefore there must be
another reason than punishment for OUI sins if we are t0 understand why
Christians die:
2. Death Is the Final Outcome of
Fallen World: In his great
wisdom; God decided that he would not apply to us the benefits of Christ $
redemptive work all at once_
Rather; he has chosen t0 apply the benefits of
salvation t0 uS
gradually
over time (as we have seen in chapters 33-40).
Similarly; he has not chosen t0 remove all evil from the world immediately;
but
wait until the final judgment and the establishment of the new heaven
and new earth (see chapters 56 and 52). In short;
still live in
fallen world
and ouI
experience of salvation is still incomplete_
The last aspect of the fallen world to be removed will be death Paul
paid:
Living '
says:
Then comes the end, when he delivers the kingdom
God the Father
after destroying every rule and every authority and pOwer: For he
must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet: The last
enemy [0 be destroyed
death (1 Cor: 15.26)
When Christ returns_
then shall come
pass the saying that is written:
Death is swallowed up in victory:
"0 death; where is your victory?
death; where is your sting?"
Cor: 15.54-55)
But until that time death remains
reality even in the lives of
Christians- Although death does not come [0 4S as
penalty fOr our
individual sins (for that has been
by Christ), it does come t0 uS
result of living in
fallen world, where the effects of sin have
not all been removed_
Related to the experience of death are other

Did Old Testament Believers Enter Immediately Into God'$ Presence?
Some have said that; although the souls of believers since Christ $
resurrection go immediately into God'$ presence in heaven, the souls of
believers who died before Christ $ resurrection did not enjoy the blessings of
heaven but went into
place of waiting for Christ '$ work of redemption to be
complete. Sometimes this is called the limbus patrum,
simply limbo_
This
view has been especially common in Roman Catholic theology; but it has also
been held by some Lutherans_
Some of the support for this doctrine comes
from
particular view of the idea of Christ'=
descent into hell, which we
discussed in an earlier chapter:

Should We Pray for the Dead? Finally; the fact that the souls of believers
g0 immediately into God $ presence means that we should not pray for the
dead. Although this idea is taught in
Maccabees 12.42-45 (see above), it is
nowhere taught in the Bible itself: Moreover; there
no indication that this
was the practice of any Christians at the time of the New Testament; nor
should it have been:
Once believers die they enter into God'$ presence and
are in a state of perfect happiness with him_
What good would it do to
pray for them anymore? Final heavenly reward will be based on deeds done in
this life, as Scripture repeatedly testifies
Cor: 3.12-15; 2 Cor: 5.10; et
al.)
Further; the souls of unbelievers who die g0 to
place of punishment
and eternal separation from the presence of God_
It would do no good to pray
for them either; since their final destiny has been settled by their sin and their
rebellion against God in this life.
To pray for the dead therefore is simply to
pray for something that God has told us has already been decided
Moreover; t0 teach that we should pray for the dead, Or t0 encourage others to
do so_
would be t0 encourage false
that the destinies of people might be
changed after they die,
something which Scripture nowhere encourages US to
think It may lead people t0 much useless anxiety and much time essentially
wasted in prayers that will have absolutely no results_
and will thereby divert
attention from prayers that could be made for events for this life and could
have great effect in advancing the work of the kingdom. We should spend
time praying according to God's will
2. The Souls of Unbelievers Go Immediately
Eternal Punishment:
Scripture nevel

second chance
trust in Christ after death: In fact; the situation is quite the contrary. Jesus'
saying

they

am in

(Luke 16.24-26).
The book of Hebrews connects death with the consequence of
judgment in close sequence: "just as
is appointed for men to die
once_
and after that comes judgment
(Heb. 9.27). Moreover;
Scripture never represents the final judgment as
depending on

but only on what has happened in this
life (Matt. 25.31-46; Rom 2.5-10; cf: 2 Cor: 5.10). Some have

Christ $ preaching
the spirits in prison in
3.18-20 and the

even t0 the dead" in

but those
are inadequate interpretations of the verses in question; and_
closer inspection, do not support such
view:
We should also realize that the idea that there will be
second
chance to accept Christ after death is based on the assumption that
everyone deserves
chance
accept Christ and that eternal
punishment only comes
those who consciously decide
reject
him. But certainly that idea
nol
supported by Scripture: we all are
sinners by nature and choice, and no one actually deserves any of
God'$ grace Or deserves any opportunity to hear the gospel of
Christ
those come only because of God's unmerited favor:
Condemnation comes not only because of
willful rejection of
Christ; but also because ot the sins that we have committed and the
rebellion against God that those sins represent (see John 3.18).
The idea that people have
second chance to accept Christ after
death would also destroy most motivation for
evangelism and
missionary activity today; and
not consistent with the intense
missionary zeal that was felt by the New Testament church as
whole_
and that was especially exemplified in the missionary travels
of the apostle Paul:
The fact that there is conscious punishment for unbelievers after
they die and that this punishment goes on forever is certainly
difficult doctrine for uS
contemplate. But the passages teaching it
hope
grear
Peter
appear s0 clear that
seems that we muSt affirm it if we are [0
affirm what Scripture teaches_
Jesus says that at the day of final
judgment he will say t0 those at his left hand; "Depart from me, YOu
cursed_
into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels,
and he says that "they will go away into eternal punishment; but the
righteous into eternal life
(Malt: 25.41, 46).
These passages show that we cannot accept as faithful to Scripture
the doctrine of annihilationism This is
doctrine that says thar
unbelievers, either immediately upon death; or else after
suffering
for
period of time
will simply cease t0 exist
God will
annihilate"
them and
will no longer be: Although the idea
initially sounds attractive
4S, and
avoids the emotional
difficulty connected with affirming eternal conscious punishment
for the wicked, such an idea is not explicitly affirmed in any
passages of Scripture, and seems S0 clearly to be contradicted by
those passages that connect the eternal blessing of the righteous
with the eternal punishment of the wicked (Matt: 25.46) and that
talk about punishment extending t0 the wicked day and night
forever (Rev: 14.11; 20.10).
Although unbelievers pass into
of eternal punishment
immediately upon death; their bodies will not be raised until the day
of final judgment. On that
their bodies will be raised and
reunited with their souls
and they will stand before God s throne
for final judgment
be pronounced upon them in the body (see
Matt: 25.31-46; John 5.28-29; Acts 24.15; and Rev: 20.12, 15).
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Have yOu thought very much about the possibility of your own death?
Has there been an element of fear connected with those thoughts? What;
if anything; do you fear about death? Do you think that these fears have
come from the influence of the world around you or from Scripture?
How would the teachings of Scripture encourage YOu t0 deal with these
fears?
Has this chapter changed your feelings about YOUr Own death in any
way? Can you honestly contemplate
now as
something that will
you nearer to Christ and increase YOuI own trust in God and faithfulness
to him? How would you express your hopes regarding
own death?
Do you think yOu would have the courage
refuse
sin even if it
they
SLale
day,
bring
yoUT
mean
being thrown to the lions in
Roman coliseum; 0r burned at the
stake during the Reformation, Or thrown in prison for years in some
foreign country today? Do you think the Christian martyrs throughout
history had thought that they would have enough courage when put t0
the test? What happened t0 them t0
them for this suffering (read
Cor: 10:13)? If yOu can obtain
copy; YOu may wish t0 read the account
of the martyrdom of Polycarp,
stirring testimony of faith in God and of
God s faithfulness
the second century AD_
Have YOu settled in your
Uwn
mind that obedience to Christ is more important than preserving
your own life? What would make you hesitant to believe this or act on
this conviction?
If you have experienced the death of
believer who was close [0 yOu, do
you think that your reaction t0 that death was one of SOITow mingled
with joy? How has this chapter influenced the way you feel about that
situation, if at all?
Have you previously believed in the doctrine of purgatory? If yOu no
longer believe in
now, can you describe the way the doctrine made you
feel, and the way yOu now feel
emotionally about the fact thar that
doctrine is not true and there is no such place as purgatory?
If death itself is viewed as
of the process of sanctification, then how
should we view the process of growing older and weaker in this world?
Is that the way the world views aging? What about you?

Chapter 42
Glorification
(Receiving
Resurrection Body)
When will we receive resurrection bodies? What will they be like?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
When Christ redeemed us he did not just redeem our spirits (0r
souls)
he redeemed us as whole persons
and this includes the
redemption of our bodies. Therefore the application of Christ'$
work of redemption tO us will not be complete until our bodies are
entirely set free from the effects of the fall and brought to that state
of perfection for which God created them. In fact; the redemption
of our bodies will only occur when Christ returns and raises our
bodies from the dead
But at this present time_
Paul says that we
wait for
redemption of our bodies,
and then adds, "for in this
hope
we were
saved" (Rom. 8.23-24). The stage in the application
of redemption when we receive resurrection bodies is called
glorification. Referring
that future day Paul says that we will be
glorified with him" (Rom. 8:17). Moreover; when Paul traces the
steps in the application of redemption, the last one he names is
glorification:
And those whom he predestined he also called; and
those whom he called he also justified; and
whom he justified
he also glorified
(Rom. 8.30).
The day
we are
glorified will be
day of great victory because on
that day the last enemy; death; will be destroyed, just as Scripture

EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The Nature of the Church
Definition: The church is the community of all true believers for all
time. This definition understands the church to be made of all those who are
truly saved. Paul says, "Christ loved the church and
himself up for her"
(Eph: 5.25). Here the term "the church" is used t0 apply to all those whom
Christ died t0 redeem, all those who are saved by the death of Christ. But that
must include all true believers for all time
both believers in the
Testament age and believers in the Old Testament age as well
So great is
God'$ plan for the church that he has exalted Christ to
position of highest
authority for the sake of the church: "He has put all things under his feet and
has made him the head over all
for the church, which is his body; the
fulness of him who fills all in all" (Eph: 1.22-23).
Jesus Christ himself builds the church by calling his people to
himself: He promised,
will build my church" (Matt: 16.18). And
Luke is careful tO tell uS that the growth of the church came not by
human effort alone, but that "the Lord added to their number day by
day those who were
being saved" (Acts 2.47). But this process
whereby Christ builds the church is just
continuation of the
pattern established by God in the Old Testament whereby he called
people to himself to be
worshiping assembly before him: There
are several indications in the Old Testament that God thought of his
people as
church;
people assembled for the purpose of
worshiping God. When Moses tells the
that the Lord said t0

church:
It is not surprising; then, that the New Testament authors can speak
of the Old Testament people of IsraeE
"church" (ekklesia).

"the church (ekklesia) in the wilderness
(Acts 7.38
author $

The Church and the Kingdom of God
What is the relationship between
the church and the kingdom of God? The differences have been summarized
well by George Ladd:
The Kingdom
primarily the dynamic reign or kingly rule of God,
and, derivatively; the sphere in which the rule is experienced
biblical idiom; the Kingdom is not identified with its subjects. They
are the people of God's rule who enter it; live under
and are
governed by it The church is the community of the Kingdom but
never the Kingdom itself. Jesus' disciples
to the
Kingdom as
the Kingdom belongs to them; but they are not the Kingdom The
Kingdom is the rule of God; the church is
society of men:
Ladd goes on t0 summarize five
specific aspects of the relationship between
the kingdom and the church:
The church is not the
kingdom (for Jesus and
the early Christians preached that the kingdom of God was near; not that the
church was near; and preached the
news
of the kingdom; not the good
news of the church: Acts 8.12; 19.8; 20.25; 28.23
31).
The kingdom
creates the church (for as people enter into God s kingdom they become
joined to the human fellowship of the church)
The church witnesses t0 the
kingdom (for Jesus said, "this gospel of the kingdom will be preached
throughout the whole world,
Matt. 24.14). (4) The church is the instrument
of the kingdom (for the
Spirit; manifesting the power of the kingdom;
works through the disciples to heal the sick and cast out demons, as he did in
the
ministry of Jesus: Matt: 10.8; Luke 10:17). (5) The church is the custodian
of the kingdom (for the church has been given the keys of the kingdom of
heaven: Matt: 16.19).
Therefore we should not identify the kingdom of God and the
church (as in Roman Catholic
theology),
nor should we see the
belong [
good
Holy
kingdom of God as entirely future, something distinct from the
church age (as in older dispensational theology_
Rather;
should
recognize that there is
close connection between the
kingdom of
God and the church: As the church proclaims the
news of the
kingdom, people will come into the church and begin t0 experience
the blessings
God' s rule in their
The kingdom manifests
itself through the church; and thereby the future reign of God
breaks into the present (it is
already'
here: Matt: 12.28; Rom:
14.17; and
not
here fully: Matt. 25.34;
Cor: 6.9-10).
Therefore those who believe in Christ will begin
experience
something
of what God s final kingdom reign will be like:
will
know some measure of victory over sin (Rom: 6.14; 14.17), over
demonic opposition (Luke 10.17), and over disease (Luke 10.9).
They will live in the power of the Holy Spirit (Matt: 12.28; Rom_
8.4-17; 14.17), who is the dynamic power of the
kingdom:
Eventually Jesus will return and his kingdom reign will extend over
all creation (1 Cor: 15.24-28).

body
goal
goal
unbelievers even if
do not respond with
gratitude
acceptance of the
gospel message. Jesus tells us,
Love your enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing in
retum; and your reward will be great; and yOu will be sons of the
Most High; for he is kind to the ungrateful and the selfish: Be
merciful, even as your Father is merciful. (Luke 6.35-36)
The point of Jesus' explanation
that we are [0 imitate God in
kind t0
those who are being
and selfish as well:
we have the
example of Jesus who did not attempt t0 heal only those who accepted him as
Messiah:
Rather; when great crowds came to him; "he laid his hands on every
one of them and healed them'
(Luke 4.40). This should give US
encouragement
canry out deeds 0f kindness, and
pray for healing and
other needs
the lives of unbelievers as well
believers
Such ministries of
mercy t0 the world may also include participation in civic activities 0r
attempting t0 influence governmental policies t0 make them more consistent
with biblical moral principles:
In areas where there is systematic injustice
manifested in the treatment of the poor andor ethnic Or religious minorities_
the church should also pray and
has opportunity
speak
against such
injustice_
All of these are ways in which the church can supplement itS
evangelistic ministry to the world and indeed adorn the gospel that it
professes.
But such ministries of mercy t0 the world should never become
substitute for genuine evangelism or for the other areas of ministry
God
and to believers mentioned above:
Keeping These Purposes in Balance:
Once we have listed these three
purposes for the church someone might ask; Which is most important? Or
someone else might ask; Might we neglect one of these three as less important
than the others?
To that we must respond that all three purposes of the church are
commanded by the Lord in Scripture; therefore all three are
important and none can be neglected In
strong church will
have effective ministries in all three of these areas_
We should
beware of any attempts t0 reduce the purpose of the church tO only
one of these three and to say that it should be our primary focus. In
such attempts tO make one of these purposes primary will
always result in some neglect of the other Lwo.
church that
emphasizes only worship will end up with inadequate Bible
teaching of believers and its members will remain shallow in their
understanding of Scripture and immature
their Christian lives. If
they
being
ungrateful
Moreuver;
facl;
fact;
it also begins to neglect evangelism the church will cease [0 grow
and influence others;
become ingrown and eventually begin
wither:
A church that places the edification of believers as
purpose that
takes precedence over the other two will tend to produce Christians
who know much Bible doctrine but have spiritual dryness in their
lives because
know little of the joy of
worshiping God or
relling others about Christ
But
church that makes evangelism such
priority that it causes
the other two purposes t0
neglected will also end up with
immature Christians who emphasize growth in numbers but have
less and less genuine love for God expressed in their worship and
less and less doctrinal maturity and personal
holiness in their lives
All three purposes must be emphasized continually in
healthy
church
However; individuals are different from churches in placing
relative priority 0n one or another of these purposes of the church_
Because
we dre
like
body with diverse spiritual gifts and abilities,
it is right for US
place most of our emphasis on the fulfillment of
that purpose of the church that is most closely related to the gifts
and interests God has given
uS. There
certainly no obligation
for
believer to attempt to give exactly one third of his or her
time in the church to worship; one-third to
nurturing other
believers
and one-third to evangelism Or deeds of mercy Someone
with the gift of
evangelism should of course spend some time in
worship and
for other believers_
but may end up
spending the
vast majority of his or her time in
evangelistic work
Someone who
gifted worship leader may end up devoting 90 percent of his
time in the church toward preparation for and leading of worship
This is only an appropriate response t0 the diversity of gifts that
God has given uS_
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL
APPLICATION
When you think of the church as the invisible fellowship of all true
believers throughout all time_
how does it affect the way you think of
as an individual Christian? In the community in which you
is there much visible unity among genuine believers (that is, is there
much visible evidence of the tnue nature of the invisible church)? Does
the New Testament say anything about the ideal size for an individual
Will
they
every
caring
yourself
live,
church?
Would you consider the church that You are nOW in to be
true church?
Have YOu ever been
member 0f
church that YOu would think to be
false church? Do you think there is any harm done when evangelical
Christians continue
give the impression that they think liberal
Protestant churches are tnue Christian churches? Viewed from the
perspective of the final judgment; what good and what harm might come
from our failure t0 state that we think unbelieving churches are false
churches?
Did any of the metaphors for the church give YOU
new
appreciation for
the church that you currently attend?
To which purpose of the church do you think You can most effectively
contribute? Which purpose has God placed in your heart
strong desire
to fulfill?

"The Church's One Foundation"
The church $ one foundation is Jesus Christ her Lord;
She
his new creation by water and the Word:
From heav'n he came and sought her to be his holy bride;
With his own blood he bought
and for her life he died_
Elect from ev'ry nation, yet one 0'er all the earth;
Her charter of salvation one Lord
one faith; one birth;
One holy name she blesses, partakes one holy food,
King:
equip
her,
And tO one hope she presses, with evry grace endued
Though with
scornful wonder men see her sore oppressed,
By schisms rent asunder; by heresies distressed,
Yet saints their watch are keeping; their cry goes up, "How long?"
And soon the night of weeping shall be the morn of song:
The church shall never perish! Her dear Lord to defend,
sustain and cherish, is with her to the end;
Though there be those that hate her; and false sons in her pale;
Against or foe or traitor she ever shall prevail:
Mid toil and tibulation, and tumult of her war;
She waits the consummation of peace forevermore;
Til with the vision glorious her longing eyes are blest;
And the great church victorious shall be the church at rest:
Yet she on earth hath union with God the Three in One_
And
sweet communion with those whose rest
won:
happy ones and holy! Lord, give US grace that we,
Like them; the meek and lowly; on high may dwell with thee:

Chapter 45
The Purity and Unity of the Church
What makes
church more or less pleasing to God? What kinds of
churches should we cooperate with or join?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
More
Pure and Lese
Pure Churches
In the previous chapter we saw that there are
true churches'
and
"false churches:
In this chapter
further distinction must be made:
there are more pure and less pure churches_
This fact is evident from
brief comparison of Paul'$ epistles.
When we look at Philippians or
Thessalonians we find evidence
of Paul'$ great joy in these churches and the relative absence of
major doctrinal or moral problems (see Phil: 1.3-11; 410-16;
Thess. 1.2-10; 36-10;
Thess: 1.3-4; 2.13; cf: 2 Cor: &.1-5). On
the other hand, there were all sorts of serious doctrinal and moral
problems in the churches of Galatia (Gal 1.6-9; 3.1-5) and Corinth
(1 Cor: 3.1-4; 4.18-21; 5.1-2,6; 6.1-8; 11:17-22; 14.20-23;
15.12;
Cor: 1.23-2.11; 1133-5,12-15; 12.20-13.10). Other
examples could be given; but it should be clear that among true
churches there are less pure and more pure churches:
This may be
represented as in figure 45.2
Falsa Churches
Tque Chuiches
RhoNc
Tg churchgs ThorC {PELOSS
PUPC AND VORE PURC
ChuPCHGS
Fiyure 45.2
Muetnienna
urin
We may define the purity of the church as follows: The purity of the
church is itS degree of freedom from wrong doctrine and conduct;
and its degree of conformity t0 God $ revealed will for the church
As we shall see in the
following discussion, it is right to pray and
work for the greater purity of the church: But purity cannot be our
only concem;
Christians would have
tendency (0 separate into
tiny groups of very
pure
Christians and tend t0 exclude anyone
who showed the slightest deviation in doctrine or conduct of life.
Therefore the New Testament also speaks frequently about the need
to strive for the unity of the visible church: This may be defined in
the
following way: The unity of the church is its degree of freedom
from divisions among true Christians
The definition specifies
true Christians'
because_
aS we saw in the
previous chapter; there are those who are Christian in name only;
but have had no genuine experience of regeneration by the Holy
Spirit: Nonetheless
many of these people take the name "Christian"
and many churches that are filled with such unbelievers still call
themselves Christian churches

The Power of the Church
What kind of authority does the church have? How should church
discipline function?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
When we look at the powerful governments of the
and at
other business and educational organizations that have great
influence
and then consider our local churches_
01 even 0ur
denominational headquarters, the church may seem t0 US to be
weak and ineffective. Moreover; when we recognize the rapid
growth of evil that is seen daily in our society; we may wonder if
the church has power t0 make any changes at all.
On the other hand_
in some countries the officially recognized
church has great influence on the conduct of national affairs_
This
was
certainly true of the influence of the Roman Catholic Church in
former times in some southern European and Latin American
countries (and is still true today to some extent). It was true of the
Church of England in previous centuries, and of John Calvin $
church in Geneva, Switzerland, while he was alive_
and of the
church founded by the pilgrims in the Massachusetts Bay Colony in
1620.
Situations like these where the church appears to have great
influence cause uS tO ask whether Scripture places any limitations
on the church $ power:
We may define the power of the church as follows: The power of
the church is its God-given authority t0 carry on spiritual warfare,
proclaim the gospel, and exercise church discipline:
Although these three areas overlap and could be treated in any
order; since the category of
spiritual warfare
is the broader
category it will be treated
This perspective on the church s
power also reminds us that the power of the church, unlike the
worldly influence exercised by human armies and governments,
world
fitst
directly affects the spiritual realm:
SpitituilWinin
Paul reminds the Corinthians_
"For though we live in the
are not canying on
worldly war; for the weapons of our warfare
are nor
worldly but have divine power to destroy strongholds
Cor: 10.3-4). These weapons, used against demonic forces that

on the
of the members of the church: (Paul gives further details
about our spiritual

When

break through sin and hardened

not

of spiritual

The Purpose of Church Discipline.
Restoration and Reconciliation of the Believer Who Is Going Astray:

Chapter 47
Church Government
How should
church be governed? How should church officers be
chosen? Should women serve aS pastors of churches?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Churches today have many different forms of government The
Roman Catholic Church has
worldwide government under the
authority of the
Episcopalian churches have bishops with
regional authority; and archbishops over them. Presbyterian
churches
regiona
authority t0 presbyteries and national
authority t0
general assemblies. On the other hand, Baptist churches
and many other independent churches have no formal governing
authority beyond the local congregation, and affiliation with
denominations is 0n
voluntaly basis_
Within local churches; Baptists often have
single pastor with
board of deacons; but some have
board of elders as well
Presbyterians have
board of elders and Episcopalians have
vestry. Other churches simply have
church board.
there
New Testament pattern for church government? Is any
one form of church government to be preferred over another? These
are the questions addressed in this chapter:
However; at the outset
must be said that the form of church
government iS nOr
major doctrine like the Trinity, the deity of
Christ; substitutionary atonement; O the authority of Scripture
Although
believe_
atter
examining the New Testament evidence
that one particular form of church government is preferable to the
others_
nevertheless
each form has some weaknesses as well as
strengths
And church history attests that several different forms of
government have worked fairly well for severa)
centuries
Moreover; while some aspects of church government seem to be
reasonably clear from the New Testament; other matters (such as
Pope.
grant
the way in which church officers should be chosen) are less clear;
mainly because the New Testament evidence on them
not
extensive, and thus our inferences from this evidence are less
certain. It seems t0 me_
then, that there ought to be room for
evangelical Christians t0 differ amicably over this question; in the
hope that further understanding may be gained. And
also seems
that individual Christians
-While
may have
preference for
one system or another; and while
may wish at appropriate
times t0 argue forcefully for one system over another
-should
nevertheless be willing to live and minister within any of several
different Protestant systems of church government in which they
may find themselves from time t0 time_
But
do nOr mean t0 say that this is an entirely unimportant matter:
In this area as well as Others,
church may be more or less pure. If
there are clear New Testament patterns regarding some aspects of
church government; then there will be negative consequences in OUr
churches if we disregard them, even
we cannot foresee all of
those consequences at the present time.
Therefore Christians are
certainly free t0 speak and write on this subject in order t0 work for
increased purity in the church:
In this chapter we shall first suivey the New Testament data
concerning church officers, especially apostle, elder; and deacon.
Then we shall ask how church officers should be chosen: After that
shall look at tWo controversial questions: Which form of church
government
any-
-is closest tO the New
Testament pattern?
And, may women serve as officers in the church?
Church Officer:
For purposes of this chapter; we will use the
following definition:_
church officer
someone who has been
publicly recognized as
having tne rignt and responsibility tO perform certain functions for
the benefit of the whole church:
According
this definition, elders and deacons would be
considered officers in
church, as would the pastor (if that is _
distinct office).
The church treasurer and church moderator would
also be officers (these titles may vary from church t0 church) All of
these people have had public recognition, usually at
service in
which they are "installed" 01
ordained" in an office.
need
public recognition in order t0 fulfill their responsibilities: for
they
they
facl,
they
example, it would not be appropriate for people to wonder from
week tO week who was tO receive the
offering and deposit it in the
bank; or for various people t0 argue that they had been gifted
take that responsibility in any particular week! The orderly
functioning of the church requires that one person be recognized as
having that responsibility Similarly; the pastor who is responsible
do Bible
each Sunday morning must be
recognized as
having the right and responsibility t0 do that (at least; in most forms
of church government) . If this were not the case, then many people
might prepare sermons and all claim the right t0 preach, O1 on some
Sundays no one might prepare. Similarly; in order for people t0
follow the elders of the church and look to them for

must know who the elders are
By contrast many other people exercise gifts in the church; but we

becaus

of "helps'

need public recognition in order t0 function effectively in the

In the material that follows_
we shall see that the New Testament
discusses one church office which was limited t0 the time when the
early church was founded (the office of apostle), and two other
church offices which continue throughout the church age (the
offices of elder and deacon):
Apostle
Earlier in this book we saw that the New Testament apostles had
unique kind of authority in the early church: authority to speak and write
words which were
words of God" in an absolute sense. To disbelieve
disobey them was t0 disbelieve 0r disobey God
The apostles, therefore; had

This fact
itself should suggest tO 4s that there was something unique about the office of
apostle_
and that we would not expect it t0 continue today; for no one today

church: If deacons are actually
functioning
as elders and have the
highest governing authority within
local church, then the
arguments given above against women being elders would apply
directly to this situation
and it would follow that Scripture does not
permit women t0 be deacons in this sense_
On the other hand, if
deacons simply have delegated administrative responsibility for
certain aspects 0f the ministry of the church;, then there seems t0 be
reason t0 prevent women from
functioning
as deacons.
Regarding the question of women as deacons in
Timothy 3.8-13,
does not seem to the present author that this passage allows
women to be deacons in the way deacons are understood in that
situation, but there
significant difference of viewpoint among
evangelicals over the understanding of this passage
and it is
much less clear t0 US exactly what deacons did at that time than it is
clear what elders did_
With
regard
other offices, such as treasurer; for example
0r other
staff positions such as youth minister or
counseling director or
children
minister; and so forth; the only question to be asked is
whether these offices include the ruling and
functions
reserved for elders in the New Testament: If not; then all of these
offices would be open
women aS well as t0 men
for we must be
careful not t0
prohibit what the New Testament does not prohibit
good
teaching `
QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
No matter what kind of church government structure YOu currently find
in, are there ways in which you could be more encouraging and
supportive t0 the current leaders in your church?
If you are currently an officer in your church; or if yOu someday would
[0 be one
is yOur pattern of life such that you would
[0 see
imitated by others in the church? If you have had
part in the process of
selecting church leaders
have You tended t0 emphasize the character
traits and spiritual qualifications talked about in Scripture
or have you
emphasized other qualifications that the world would look for in
selecting its leaders?
Do you think that the current governing structure of your church works
quite well? How could it be improved, without changing the basic
philosophy of church goverment tO which it is committed? Whether or
not your church has officers who are called
elders,
who are the people
who carry out the functions of elders in your church? Do you know if
your own pastor would like
see some modifications in the government
of your church; to enable him to carry out his task more effectively?
Before
this chapter; what was YOur view on the question of
women
serving
teaching pastors or elders in
church? How has this
chapter changed your view; if at all? Why do you think people
emotions are often very strong concering this issue? Can you explain
how you personally feel (emotionally) about the teaching presented in
this chapter? Does
seem right [0 You, or not?

Chapter 48
Means of Grace Within the Church
What are the different activities within the life of the church that
God uses
bring blessing
us? What do we miss if we neglect
involvement in
local church?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
How Many
Means
Grace
Are Available
Us?
All of the blessings we experience in this life are ultimately
undeserved
they are all of grace: In fact; for Peter; the entire
Christian life is lived by grace (1 Peter 5.12).
But are there any special means that God uses t0 give additional
grace to us? Specifically; within the fellowship of the church are
there certain means
that is;
certain activities, ceremonies
functions
that God uses tO give more grace t0 us? Another way of
formulating that question is t0 ask whether there are certain means
through which the Holy Spirit works tO convey
into the
life of the believer: Of course, personal prayer; worship, and Bible
study; and personal faith, are all means through which God works
bring grace to us as individual Christians. But in this chapter we
are
with the doctrine of the church, and we are
specifically within the fellowship of the church what the means of
grace are that God uses to bring blessing to uS
We may define the means of grace
follows: The means of grace
any activities within the fellowship of the church that God uses
to give more grace I0 Christians:
In the history of the discussion of "means of grace within the
church;'
some theologians have restricted them
three: the
preaching of the Word, and the two sacraments (baptism and the
Lord's Supper).
blessings
dealing
asking
But is it wise [0 make such
short list of
'means of grace
If we
wish to list and discuss all the means of receiving the Holy Spirit's
blessing that come to believers specifically through the fellowship
of the church; then it does not seem wise (0 limit the
means of
grace
[0 three activities whose administration is restricted t0 the
ordained
officers f the church:
[here
wisdom, for
example, in Charles Hodge
view that prayer is
fourth means of
grace
But should we limit our discussion of the means of grace t0 these
four activities only? It would seem more helpful to list all of the
many varied activities within the church that God has given as
special ways of receiving his
grace
day by day and week by
week. Such
list may become
long; and, depending on how it
organized
may include various numbers of elements
The
following list may not be exhaustive
but it does include most of the
means of grace that believers have access t0 within the fellowship
of the church:
Teaching of the Word
Baptism
The Lord $ Supper
Prayer for one another
Worship
Church discipline
Giving
8. Spiritual gifts
9. Fellowship
10. Evangelism
IL. Personal ministry
individuals
All these are available to believers within the church: The
Spirit works through all of them to bring various kinds of blessing
clergy
quite
Holy
individuals.
Therefore ,
departing from the much shorter lists
usually given in systematic theologies
have decided t0 call all of
these
means of grace'
within the church_
The Roman Catholic Church has traditionally believed that God $
grace
comes t0 people only through the official ministry of the
church, particularly through the priests of the church Therefore,
when
specifies the means of grace (what it calls the
sacraments'
that are available tO people within the church, it has
view activities that are supervised andor performed by only the
priests of the church: The seven
sacraments
in Roman Catholic
teaching are the following:
Baptism
Confirmation
Eucharist (the Lord's Supper as experienced in the mass)
Penance
Extreme unction (popularly known as the "last rites,
the
anointing with
oil that is administered t0
dying person)
Holy orders (ordination t0 the priesthood 0r diaconate)
Matrimony
There is not only
difference in the lists given by Catholics and Protestants;
there is also
difference in fundamental meaning:
Catholics view these as
means
salvation
that make people more fit to receive justification from
God
But on
Protestant view; the means of grace are simply means of
additional blessing within the Christian life, and do not add t0 Our fitness
receive
justification from God.
Catholics teach that the means of grace
impait grace whether or not there is subjective faith on the part of the minister
or the recipient;
while Protestants hold that God only imparts grace when
there is faith on the part of the persons
administering Or receiving these
means_
And while the Roman Catholic Church firmly restricts the
administration of the sacraments
the clergy; our list
means of grace
includes many activities that are carried out by all believers_
DEc4o
0l Specific Mezns
Teaching of the Word: Even before people become Christians_
the Word
of God as preached and taught brings God's grace t0 them in that it is the
instrument God uses tO impart spiritual life t0 them and
them [0
salvation. Paul says that the gospel is the
'power of God for salvation'
(Rom:
bring
1.16) and that the
preaching of Christ
'the power of God and the wisdom of
God" (1 Cor: 1.24). God caused us to be bom again or "brought
forth by
the word of truth"
(James 1.18) and Peter says
You have been born anew,
not of perishable seed but of imperishable, through the living and
word of God" (1 Peter 1.23). It is the written Word of God_
the Bible; that is
able [0 instruct YOu fOr salvation through faith in Christ Jesus
(2 Tim
3.15).
Moreover; once we have become Christians, Paul reminds us that it
is the Word of God that is
able to build you up
(Acts 20.32). It is
necessary for spiritual
nourishment and for maintaining spiritual
because
do nOr live on bread alone but on
every word that
proceeds from the mouth
God" (Matt_ 4.4). Moses speaks of the
absolute necessity of the written Word of God when he tells the
