Spirit" (Acts 9.17). When Paul "laid his hands
upon'
the disciples at Ephesus who had just come (0 believe in
Jesus, "the Holy Spirit came on them'
(Acts 19.6).
In other cases the
laying on of hands resulted in the impartation of
SUME
spiritual gift. In the incident just mentioned_
the disciples at
Ephesus also
spoke with tongues and prophesied" (Acts 19.6) after
Paul laid his hands on them:
Moreover; he reminds Timothy; "Do
not neglect the gift you have, which was given you by prophetic
utterance (literally; "through prophecy'
when the council of elders
laid their hands upon you"
Tim: 4.14)
Paul may have been
referring
t0 the same event Or
different one when he said
remind yOu to rekindle the gift of God that
within you through
the laying on of my hands
(2 Tim_
1.6). (In
Timothy 5.22
the
healing .
asking
they
they
Holy
Holy
later,
statement
Do not be hasty in the laying on of hands" refers
the
ordination of elders; see chapter 47, p. 1120.)
If people in the early church were frequently praying for one
another'
needs_
and if they imitated the example of Jesus and his
disciples in the laying on of hands to pray for people for healing_
for bringing blessing: for receiving the Holy Spirit at the time of
conversion, for receiving spiritual gifts, or for empowering for
ministry; then we would expect that instruction given to new
Christians would have included the teaching that prayer for
individual
needs would ordinarily be accompanied by the placing of
hand or hands upon the person who was
prayed for: If this
were SO, then
would not be surprising that "the laying on of
hands" would be classified as an "elementary" doctrine, something
that
belongs to the "foundation'
of Christian instruction
which is
fact what we find in Hebrews 6.1-2. Although some have
understood this [0 refer
narrowly t0 the laying on of hands
that accompanies installation in some specific church office
that is
only one small aspect of the pattern of situations in which
of hands is found in the New Testament It seems much better t0
understand this phrase in Hebrews 6.2 to refer t0 elementary
instruction about how tO pray for others in various situations of
need s0 that young Christians would immediately be able to begin
ministering tO Others as well
It seems
appropriate, then; to count the laying on of hands as one
other dimension of the rich diversity of
means of
that God
has placed within the church to bring blessing to his people
Should
Footwashing Be Practiced As
Means of Grace Within the
Church? From time tO time some Christian groups have practiced
ceremony of washing one another's feet at
public meeting of the church:
They have based this practice 0n Jesus '$ command, "If
then, your Lord and
Teacher; have washed your
YOu also ought I0 wash one another
(John 13.14). Those who advocate footwashing consider it
ceremony that
Jesus commanded_
similar to the ceremonies of baptism and the Lord $
Supper:
However; there are several reasons why we should not think that in
John 13.14 Jesus was
establishing
another ceremony for the church
in addition to baptism and the Lord's Supper:
Baptism and the
Lord $
Supper explicitly symbolize the greatest event in the history
being
mare
laying
grace'
fecl;
feet"
of redemption, Christ'$ death and resurection for uS_
but
foorwashing symbolizes no such redemptive-historical event
Baptism and the Lord' $
were clearly
symbolic actions, but
when Jesus washed the disciples
feet it was clearly functional, not
merely symbolic; in that it met an ordinary human need of the day
(dirty feet). (3) Baptism and the Lord s Supper are appropriate
symbols of beginning and continuing in the Christian life,
but no
such symbolism attaches t0 footwashing:
To make footwashing
ordinance like baptism and the Lord $
reduces
symbol
-and if it is
symbol, then Jesus
words command us only
perform
symbol; and the real force of Jesus' command (t0 act
humility and love) is lost:
Whereas the epistles give evidence
that baptism and the Lord'$ Supper were continuing ordinances
observed by the New Testament churches_
there is no evidence thar
the apostles or the early church observed footwashing as an
ordinance.
(6) There is
simple and
straightforward explanation for
Jesus' command: he is telling his disciples t0 take lowly tasks in
one
another: But if this is what the text means
the vast
majority of the church through history has understood
this way),
then we need not look for an additional meaning (that Jesus is also
instituting
new ceremony). By contrast; the New Testament texts
about baptism and the Lord $ Supper cannot be understood
command
something other than
ceremony.
Therefore
while all
Christians would profit from pondering the application of Jesus
statement about footwashing t0 their present patterns of life, none
should think that Jesus is encouraging them to practice
ceremony
footwashing:
Conclusions
At the end of this discussion of the means of grace within the
church; we should realize first of all that when any of these are
canied out in faith and obedience
we should eagerly expect and
look for evidence that the Holy Spirit is actually ministering tO
people at the same time as these actions are being done
We as
Christians ought not t0 neglect [0
meet
(Heb. 10.25), but
ought to look forward
eagerly to any assembly of believers in
which any of these means would occur;
expecting that God will
bring blessing from each of these means!
On the other hand_
we muSt realize that all of these means of grace
occur within the fellowship of the church: Those who neglect the
Supper
Supper
serving
(and
together'
fellowship of the church willfully cut themselves off from all of
these means of grace and thereby cut themselves off from most of
the ordinary means that the
Spirit uses to bring blessing to his
people:
These means of grace ought [0 give US
appreciation for the
amazing privilege of being members of the body of Christ, the
church:

Chapter 49
Baptism
Who should be baptized? How should it be done? What does it
mean?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
In this chapter and the next we treat baptism and the Lord' $
Supper;
IWO ceremonies that Jesus commanded his church t0 perfom_
But
before we begin consideration of either one of them we must note
that there is disagreement among Protestants even over the general
term that should be applied t0 them: Because the Roman Catholic
Church calls these [Wo ceremonies
sacraments_
and because the
Catholic Church teaches that these sacraments in themselves
actually convey grace
people (without requiring faith from the
persons participating
them), some Protestants
especially
Baptists) have refused to refer to baptism and the Lord's Supper as
sacraments.
They have preferred the word ordinances instead
This is thought to be an appropriate term because baptism and the
Lord'$ Supper Were
ordained" by Christ:
On the other hand, other
Protestants such as those in the Anglican;
Lutheran, and Reformed
traditions, have been
t0 use the word
sacraments
to refer
to baptism and the Lord s Supper; without thereby
endorsing the
Roman Catholic position:
does not seem that any
significant point is at issue here in the
question of whether tO call baptism and the Lord'$ Supper
ordinances'
sacraments.
Since Protestants who use both
words explain clearly what they mean by them; the argument is not
really over doctrine but over the
of an English word_
If we
are
to explain clearly what we mean, it does not seem tO
make any difference whether we
the word sacrament 0r not:
this text; when referring to baptism and the Lord $ Supper in
Protestant teaching;
will use both
ordinances'
and
sacraments"
interchangeably; and
them as synonymous in meaning
willing -
meaning
willing -
regard
Before
beginning our discussion of baptism we must
recognize that
there has been historically, and is today;
strong difference of
viewpoint among
evangelical Christians regarding this subject: The
position advocated in this book is that baptism is not
"major"
doctrine that should be the basis of division among genuine
Christians,
but it is nonetheless
matter of importance for ordinary
church life_
and it is appropriate that we give it full consideration_
The position advocated in this chapter is "Baptistic'
-namely; that
baptism is appropriately administered only to those who give
believable profession of faith in Jesus Christ: During the discussion;
shall interact particularly with the paedobaptist
infant baptist" -
position as advocated by Louis Berkhof in his Systematic Theology;
since this is
careful and responsible representation of the
paedobaptist position; and it is in
widely used systematic theology
text:
The Mode and Mraning of Eaptism
The practice of baptism in the New Testament was carried out in
one way: the person being baptized was immersed Or put
completely under the water and then brought back up again.
Baptism by immersion is therefore the
mode
of baptism or the
way in which baptism was carried out in the New Testament: This
is evident for the following reasons:
(1) The Greek word baptizo means "tO
plunge, dip, immerse"
something
in water: This is the commonly
recognized and standard
meaning of the term
ancient Greek literature both inside and
outside of the Bible
(2) The sense "immerse
is appropriate and probably required for
the word in several New Testament passages. In Mark 1.5, people
were baptized by John "in the river Jordan'
(the Greek text has en,
"in,
and not "beside" or
by" or
near" the river)_
Mark also tells
us that when Jesus had been baptized "he came up out of the water
(Mark 1:10). The Greek text specifies that he came
out of" (ek) the
water; not that he came away trom
(this would be expressed by
Gk apo) The fact that John and Jesus went into the river and came
up out of it strongly suggests immersion
since
sprinkling or
pouring of water could much more readily have been done standing
beside the river; particularly because multitudes of people were
coming for baptism. John's gospel tells us, further; that John the
Baptist
was baptizing at Aenon near Salim; because there Was
much water there
(John 3.23). Again, it would not take
much
water" to baptize people by sprinkling; but it would take much
water tO baptize by immersion
When Philip had shared the gospel with the Ethiopian eunuch;
went along the road they
some water; and the eunuch
said, 'See_
here is water ! What is tO prevent my being baptized?
(Acts 8.36) . Apparently neither of them thought that sprinkling or
pouring
handful of water from the container of drinking water that
would have been carried in the chariot was enough t0 constitute
baptism Rather; they waited until there was
body of water near
the road. Then
he commanded the chariot t0 stop, and
both
went down into the water; Philip and the eunuch
and he baptized
him.
And when they came up OUt of the water; the Spirit of the Lord
caught up Philip; and the eunuch saw him no more, and went on his
way rejoicing'
(Acts 8.38-39). As in the case of Jesus, this baptism
occurred when Philip and the eunuch went down into
body of
water; and after the baptism they came up out of that body of water:
Once again baptism by immersion is the only satisfactory
explanation of this narrative_
The symbolism of union with Christ in his death; burial, and
resurrection seems t0 require baptism by immersion. Paul says,
Do you not know that all of uS who have been baptized into Christ
Jesus were baptized into his death? We were buried therefore with
him by baptism into death, so that as Christ was raised from the dead
by the glory of the Father;
LOO might walk in newness of life
(Rom 6.3-4)
Similarly, Paul tells the Colossians
You were buried with him in baptism, in
which you were also raised with him through faith in the working of God,
who raised him from the dead" (Col: 2.12).
Now this truth is clearly symbolized in baptism by immersion.
When the candidate for baptism goes down into the water it is
picture of going down into the grave and
buried:.
out of the water is then
picture of being raised with Christ to walk
ne MeSS
of lite_
Baptism thus very clearly pictures death
one
they
came
they
being
Coming '
old way of life and rising
new kind of life in Christ. But
baptism by sprinkling or pouring simply misses this symbolism_
Sometimes it is objected that the essential
symbolized in
baptism is not death and resurrection with Christ but purification
and cleansing from sins
Certainly
is true that water is an evident
symbol of
and
cleansing; and the waters of baptism do
symbolize washing and purification from sins aS well as death and
resurrection
Christ: Titus 3.5 speaks of
washing of
regeneration'
and, even
though the word baptism is not used in this
text, it is
certainly true that there is
cleansing from sin that occurs
at the time of conversion
Ananias told Saul, "Rise and be baptized_
and wash away your sins, calling on his name"
(Acts 22.16).
But to say that washing away of sins is the only
(or even the
most essential thing
pictured in baptism does not faithfully
represent New Testament teaching: Both washing and death and
resurrection with Christ are symbolized in baptism; but Romans
6.1-11 and Colossians 2.11-12 place
clear emphasis on dying and
rising with Christ. Even the washing is much more effectively
symbolized by immersion than by sprinkling or pouring
and death
and resurrection with Christ are symbolized only by immersion, nOt
at all by sprinkling Or pouring_
What then is the positive meaning of baptism? In all the discussion
over the mode of baptism and the disputes over its meaning;
easy for Christians to lose sight of the significance and beauty of
baptism and t0 disregard the tremendous blessing that accompanies
this ceremony: The
truuths of
passing through the waters of
judgment safely; of dying and rising with Christ; and of having our
sins washed away; are truths of momentous and eternal proportion
and ought to be an occasion for giving great glory and praise t0
God. If churches would teach these truths more clearly, baptisms
would be the occasion of much more blessing in the church:
cuaneme
aptitI
The pattern revealed at several places in the New Testament is that
only those who give
believable profession of faith should be
baptized: This view
often called "believers
baptism;
since
holds that only those who have themselves believed in Christ (01;
more precisely; those who have given reasonable evidence of
thing
washing
with
"the
thing
amazing
believing
in Christ) should be baptized_
This is because baptism;
which is
symbol of
beginning the Christian life, should only be
given to those who have in fact begun the Christian life.
The
Argument From the New Testament Narrative Passages 0n
Baptism: The narrative examples of those who were baptized suggest that
baptism was administered only t0 those who
believable profession of
faith
After Peter $ sermon at Pentecost we read
Those who received his
word were baptized" (Acts 2.41)
The text specifies that baptism was
administered
those who "received his word" and therefore trusted in Christ
for salvation_
Similarly; when Philip preached the gospel in Samaria
read
When they believed Philip as he preached
news about the
kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they
baptized, both men
and women
(Acts 8.12). Likewise,
when Peter preached to the Gentiles in
Comelius' household
he allowed baptism for those who had heard the Word
and received the
Spirit
-that is, for those who had given persuasive
evidence of an internal work of regeneration.
While Peter was
preaching;
the
Holy Spirit fell on all who heard the word" and Peter and his companions
"heard them speaking
tongues and
extolling God" (Acts 10.44-46) . Peter'$
response was that baptism is appropriate for those who have received the
regenerating work of the Holy Spirit: "Can any one forbid water for
baptizing
these people who have received the Holy Spirit just as we have?" Then Peter
commanded them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ" (Acts 10.47 -
48). The point of these three passages is that baptism is appropriately given t0
those who have received the gospel
and trusted in Christ for salvation: There
are other texts that indicate this as well
Acts 16.14-15 (Lydia and her
household, after "the Lord opened her heart"
believe); Acts 16.32-33 (the
family of the Philippian jailer; after Peter preached "the word of the Lord to
him and t0 all that were in his house
and
Corinthians 1:16 (the household
of Stephanas) , but these
be discussed more fully below when we look at
the question of "household baptisms:
2. The
Argument From the Meaning of Baptism: In addition to these
indications from New Testament narratives that baptism always followed
upon saving faith; there is
second consideration that argues for believers'
baptism: the outward symbol of beginning the Christian life should only be
given
those who show evidence of having begun the Christian life. The
New 'lestament
authors wrote as though they clearly assumed that everyone
who was baptized had also personally trusted in Christ and experienced
salvation
For example, Paul says_
As many of you as were baptized into
Christ have
on Christ" (Gal. 3.27). Paul here assumes that baptism is the
outward sign of inward regeneration. This simply would not have been true of
Bave
good
wer
Holy
Will
pul
infants
Paul could not have said,
As many infants as have been baptized
into Christ have put on Christ;
for infants have not yet come
saving faith
given any evidence of regeneration.
Paul speaks the same

Infants Were Circumcised in the Old Covenant: In the Old Testament;
circumcision was the outward sign of entrance into the covenant community
or the community of God $ people.
Circumcision was administered [0 all
Israelite children (that is
male children) when they were eight days old:
b. Baptism Is Parallel to Circumcision: In the New Testament; the outward

covenant community" is baptism: Therefore

believing parents
glace

them this benefit is t0 deprive them of them

the sign of

only

They
argue that the practice of paedobaptism in actual church life
frequently leads persons baptized in infancy t0 presume that
have been regenerated, and thereby they fail to feel the urgency of
their need t0 come [0 personal
in Christ. Over
period of
years, this tendency is likely tO result in more and more
unconverted members of the
covenant community
members
who are nOt truly members ot Christ $ church
Of course_
this
would not make
paedobaptist church
false church, but it would
make it a less-pure church, and one that will frequently be fighting
tendencies tOward liberal doctrine or other kinds of unbelief that are
brought in by the unregenerate sector of the membership.
The Effen
[aptiai
they
Faith
We have
argued above that baptism symbolizes regeneration or
spiritual rebirth
But does it only symbolize? Or is there some way
in which it is also
means of grace,
that is_
means that the Holy
Spirit uses tO
to people? We have already discussed
this question in the previous chapter;
sO here it only is necessary
to say that when baptism is properly carried out then of course it
brings some spiritual benefit to believers as well.
There is the
blessing of God' s favor that comes with all obedience_
as well as
the joy that comes through public profession of one s faith; and the
reassurance of
clear physical picture of dying and
with Christ and of
away sins. Certainly the Lord gave uS
baptism t0 strengthen and encourage our faith
and it should do s0
for everyone who is baptized and for every believer who witnesses
baptism.
Whe Aenent
LAPEni
While we recognize that Jesus commanded baptism (Matt 28:19),
did the apostles (Acts 2.38), we should not say that baptism is
necessary for salvation:
This question was discussed
some
extent above under the response t0 the Roman Catholic view of
baptism To say that baptism Or any other action is necessary for
salvation is t0 say that we are not justified by faith alone; but by
faith plus
certain
work,
the work of baptism The apostle Paul
would have opposed the idea that baptism is necessary for salvation
just as strongly as he opposed the similar idea that circumcision
was necessary for salvation (see Gal. 5.1-12).
Those who argue that baptism
necessary for salvation often point
Mark 16.16: "He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but
he who does not believe will be condemned
But the very evident
dmswer (C
this is simply t0 say that the verse says nothing about
those who believe and are not baptized.
The verse is simply
about genera
cases
without making
pedantic qualification for the
unusual case of someone who believes and is not baptized
But
certainly the verse should not be pressed into service and made to
of something it is not talking about:
More to the point is Jesus
statement t0 the
dying thief on the cross,
"Today you will be with me in Paradise
(Luke 23.43). The thief
could not be baptized before he died on the cross_
but he was
bring
blessing
having -
rising
washing
talking
speak =
certainly saved that
Moreover; the force of this point cannot be
evaded by arguing that the thief was saved under the old covenant
(under which baptism was not necessary t0 salvation), because the
new covenant took effect at the death of Jesus (see Heb. 9.17), and
Jesus died before either of the two thieves who were crucified with
him (see John 19.32-33).
Another reason why baptism is not necessary for salvation is that
our justification from sins takes place at the point of saving faith,
not at the
point of water baptism, which usually occurs later:
But
if a person is already justified and has sins forgiven eternally at the
point of saving faith, then baptism is not necessary for forgiveness
of sins
or for the bestowal of new spiritual life.
Baptism, then; is not necessary for salvation. But
is necessary
we are t0 be obedient
Christ; for he commanded baptism for all
who believe in him.
The Aet [or DAntine
Those who are convinced by the arguments for believers
baptism
must then
begin to ask;
How old should children be before they
are baptized?"
The most direct answer is that they should be old enough t0 give
believable profession of faith: It is impossible t0 set
precise age
that will apply to every child_
but when parents see convincing
evidence of genuine spiritual life_
and also some
understanding regarding the meaning of trusting in Christ, then
baptism is appropriate. Of course
this will require careful
administration by the church;
well as
explanation by
parents in their homes. The exact age for baptism will vary from
child to child, and somewhat from church t0 church as well.
Kemuling Qucticns
1. Do Churches Need to Be Divided Over Baptism?
spite of many years
of division over this question among Protestants, is there
way in which
Christians who differ on baptism can demonstrate greater unity of fellowship?
And is there
way that progress can be made in bringing the church closer to
unity on this question?
day-
degree
good
One way forward could be for paedobaptists and advocates of
believers' baptism both to come t0
common admission that
baptism is not
major doctrine f the faith; and that they are willing
[O live with each other"
views 0n this matter and not allow
differences over baptism to be
cause for division within the body
of Christ.
Specifically; this would mean allowing both views of
baptism to be taught and practiced in denominations on both sides
of the question
No doubt this would be
difficult
to do both for Baptist
denominations and for paedobaptist denominations
because they
have
traditions of arguing for one side Or the other on this
question.
Certainly Christians are entitled [O make up their Own
minds regarding baptism; but it does nOt seem appropriate that
denominational divisions should depend on and reinforce these
differences
does it seem right that churches require one view Or
another on baptism for those who wish to be ordained or to function
as teachers within the church:
Specifically; this would mean that
Baptist churches would have to be willing to allow into
membership those who had been baptized as infants and whose
conviction of conscience
after careful consideration,
that their
infant baptism was valid and should not be repeated. Of course;
Baptist churches could be free t0 teach and
attempt
persuade
prospective church members that they should be baptized as
believers, but if some, after careful consideration, are simply not
persuaded, it does not seem appropriate to make this
barrier [0
membership. What good is accomplished by such
barrier? And
certainly much harm can be accomplished in failure to demonstrate
the unity of the church and in barring from full participation in the
church those whom the Lord has in fact brought into that
fellowship.
On the other hand_
those who believe
paedobaptism would have
agree not to put undue pressure upon parents who do not wish t0
have their infants baptized and not t0 count those parents as
somehow disobedient to the Lord. There might need to be
willingness to have some kind of brief ceremony of dedication of
children to the Lord shortly after
are bom_
instead of _
ceremony of baptism; if the parents s0 desired_
And of course both
sides would have
agree not t0 make one view on baptism
criterion for church office or for ordination.
thing
long
nor
they
If such concessions in actual practice were made by both sides on
this question, the issue might in fact diminish the level of
controversy within
generation; and baptism might eventually
cease t0 be
point of division at all among Christians.
Who Can Baptize? Finally;
may ask;
Who can perform the ceremony
of baptism? Can only ordained
perform this ceremony?"
We should
recognize here that Scripture simply does not specify
any restrictions 0n who can perform the ceremony of baptism:
Those churches that have
special priesthood through which
certain actions (and blessings
come
(such as Roman Catholics
and
LO some extent Anglicans) will wish t0 insist that only properly
ordained
should baptize in ordinary circumstances (though
exceptions could be made in unusual circumstances). But if we
truly believe in the priesthood of all believers (see
Peter 2.4-10),
then there seems tO be no need in principle t0 restrict the right to
perform baptism only
ordained clergy:
However; another consideration arises: Since baptism
the sign of
entrance into the body of Christ; the church (cf.
Cor: 12.13 on
inward spiritual baptism), then
seems appropriate that it be done
within the fellowship of the church wherever possible; so that the
church as
whole can rejoice
the person being baptized and s0
that the faith of all believers in that church might be built up.
Moreover, since
baptism is
sign of beginning the Christian life
and therefore of beginning life in the true church as well, it is fitting
that the local church be assembled to give testimony t0 this fact and
LO give visible welcome to the baptized person
Also
in order thar
the people being baptized have
right understanding of what
actually is happening
it is right for the church to safeguard the
practice of baptism and
from abuse. Finally; if baptism is the
sign of entering the fellowship of the visible church; then
seems
appropriate that some officially designated representative Or
representatives of the church be selected t0 administer it. For these
reasons it is usually the ordained
who baptize; but there
seems t0 be nO reason why the church from time
time
and where
deems
appropriate, might not call on other church officers or
mature believers [0
baptize new converts_
For example, someone
effective in evangelism in
local church may be an appropriately
designated person
baptize people who have come
Christ
through the practice of that person
evangelistic ministry: (Note in
clergy
clergy
with
keep
clergy
Acts &:12 that Philip preached the gospel in Samaria and then
apparently baptized those who came t0 faith in Christ )

the person being

way?

function in this way?

The Roman Catholic View: Transubstantiation: According to the
teaching of the Roman Catholic Church, the bread and wine actually become
the body and blood of Christ. This happens at the moment the priest says,

At the same time as the

the subjective disposition of the recipient of grace
Moreover;

but he is continually explaining it in terms of

3. The Rest of Protestantism:
Symbolic and Spiritual Presence of
Christ: In distinction from Martin Luther; John Calvin and other Reformers
that the bread and wine of the Lord's Supper did not change into the
body and blood of Christ; nor did
somehow contain the
and blood
of Christ. Rather; the bread and wine symbolized the body and blood of
Christ; and they gave
visible sign of the fact that Christ himself was truly
present:
Calvin said:
By the showing of the symbol the thing itself is also shown. For
unless
man means t0 call God
deceiver; he would never dare assert
that an empty symbol is set forth by him.
And the
godly ought by
all means t0
this rule: whenever they see symbols appointed by
the Lord_
to think and be persuaded that the truth of the thing
signified
is surely present there. For why would the Lord put in your hand the
symbol of his body; except to assure YOu of
true participation in it?
(Institutes, 4.17.10; p. 1371)
Yer Calvin was careful t0 differ both with Roman Catholic
teaching
(which said that the bread became Christ'$ body) and with Lutheran
teaching (which said that the bread contained Christ' s body).
But we must establish such
presence of Christ in the Supper as may
neither fasten him t0 the element of bread, nor enclose him in bread,
nor circumscribe him in any way (all which things, it is clear; detract
from his heavenly glory) . (Institutes, 4.17.19;
1381)
Today most Protestants would say; in addition t0 the fact that the

partake of the

Chapter_51
Worship
How can our worship fulfill its great purpose in the New
Testament age? What does it mean
worship "in spirit and in
truth"?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The term worship
sometimes applied t0 all of
Christian $ life_
and it is rightly said that
everything in our life should be an act of
worship, and
everything the church does should be considered
worship, for everything we do should glorify God. However; in this
chapter
am nOt using the word in that broad sense: Rather;
using worship in
more
specific sense t0 refer t0 the music and
words that Christians direct t0 God in praise, together with the heart
attitudes that accompany that praise, especially when Christians
assemble
Since the chapters in this part of the book deal
with the doctrine of the church; it is appropriate in this chapter t0
focus attention on the worship activities of the assembled church:
Definition
WVorthin
Worship is the activity of glorifying God in his presence with our
voices and nearts.
In this definition we note that worship is an act of glorifying God
Yet all aspects of our lives are supposed to glorify God, so this
definition specifies that worship is something we do especially
when we come into God'$ presence, when we are conscious of
adoration of him in our hearts_
and when we praise him with our
voices and speak about him so others may hear: Paul encourages the
Christians in Colossae, "Let the word of Christ dwell in you richly;
teach and admonish one another in all wisdom, and sing psalms
and hymns and spiritual songs with thankfulness in your hearts t0
God" (Col. 316).
together:
Te
the primary reason that God called us into the assembly of
the church is that as
corporate assembly we might worship him:
Edmund Clowney wisely says:
God had demanded of Pharaoh,
'Let my people go_
that they may
worship me in the desert" (Ex. 7:16b).
God brings them out that he
might bring them in, into his assembly; to the
company of those
who stand before his face_
God $ assembly at Sinai is therefore the
immediate
of the exodus:
God
his people into his presence
that they might hear his voice and worship nim:
But Clowney explains that the worshiping assembly at Mount Sinai could not
remain
session before God forever: Therefore God established other
festivals in which the whole nation would assemble before him three times
year: He says that "Israelites are
nation formed for worship, called to
assemble in the courts of the Lord, and
praise together the name of the
Most High
Yer Clowney points out
rather than
worshiping God in a
unified, holy assembly; the people turned aside to serving idols and,
rather than
assembling the people to worship before him; "in
judgment God scattered the people in
But God promised that his purposes for his people would yer be
fulfilled, that there would someday be
great assembly not just of
Israel but of all nations before his throne (Isa. 2.2-4; 25.6-8; 49.22;
66.18-21; cf. Jer: 48.47; 49.6, 39).
notes thar the
fulfillment of that promise began only when Jesus started to build
his church:
Pentecost was the time of the firstfruits, the beginning of the great
harvest of redemption. Peter preached the fulfillment of the prophecy of
Joel. The Spirit had been poured Out; the worship of the new age had
been ushered in. The church, the assembly for worship_
WuS
praising
God:
Now the ingathering had begun:
The gospel call is
call to worship
to turn from sin and call upon the
name of the Lord:
The picture of the church as
worshiping
assembly
nowhere more powerfully presented than by the author of
the Epistle to the Hebrews (12.18-29).
In our worship in Christ' $
church
approach the throne of God the judge of all. We enter the
festival assembly of the saints and the angels_
We gather
spirit with
fact;
grear
goal
brings
that,
exile.
Clowney
the spirits of just men made perfect We enter the assembly of glory
through Christ our mediator; and the blood of his atoning death:
Reverent corporate worship_
then
not optional for the church of
God
Rather; it brings to expression the very being of the church:
Ic manifests 0n earth the reality of the heavenly assembly:
Worship is therefore
direct expression of our ultimate purpose for living;
glorify God and fully t0 enjoy him forever

QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Do you experience genuine, fulfilling worship in YOur church each
Sunday? How much time is specifically allotted to worship (narrowly
defined)
tthat is, t0 times of praise and thanksgiving to God? Would you
like the time to be longer? What aspects of the worship time do you
most meaningful? Which aspects are least meaningful? How could your
church take steps
strengthen and deepen its experience of worship (if
that is needed)?
Have Yu ever felt
strong sense of the presence of God in corporate
worship? When was this? Can you describe it? Do you know what
factors contributed t0 this sense?
During times of worship; can you describe the emotions that are most
prominent in your consciousness? Is this experience similar t0 other
experiences in daily life, 0r are these feelings unique tO times of
worship? Have YOu ever sensed that God is ministering t0 YOu while You
are worshiping him? What made YOu aware of that?
Do you think there is enough genuine worship in a typical week in YOur
life? If not; what are the hindrances t0 such worship?
How do you feel about the fact that God is jealous for his own honor and
seeks his honor? Can you think of
anything in the universe that would be
more right than for God to seek his Own honor? Can you think of
anything other than worship of God that would make you feel more
deeply that you are doing the thing for which YOu were created?

Chapter 52
Gifts of the Holy Spirit:
(Part 1)
General Questions
What are spiritual gifts? How many are there? Have some gifts
ceased? Seeking and using spiritual gifts:
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
Questione
Regarding Spiritual Gifts
General
In previous
generations, systematic theologies did not have chapters
on spiritual gifts, for there were few questions
regarding the nature
and use of spiritual gifts in the church. But the twentieth century
has seen
remarkable increase in interest in spiritual gifts,
primarily because of the influence of the Pentecostal and
charismatic movements within the church:
In this chapter
first look at some general questions regarding spiritual gifts, then
examine tne
specific question of whether some (miraculous) gifts
have ceased
In the next chapter we shall analyze the New
Testa
teaching about particular gifts
Before
beginning the discussion, however; we may define spiritual
gifts as follows:
spiritual gift is any ability that is empowered by
the Holy Spirit and used in any ministry of the church This broad
definition includes both gifts that are related to natural abilities
(such as
showing mercy; or administration) and gifts that
seem t0 be more
miraculous
and less related tO natural abilities
(such as prophecy; healing;
distinguishing between spirits). The
reason for this is that when Paul lists spiritual gifts (in Rom: 12.6
Cor: 7.7; 12.8-10,
28; and Eph: 411) he includes both kinds of
gifts_
Yet not every natural ability that people have is included here,
because Paul
clear that all spiritual gifts must be empowered "by
one and the same Spirit"
Cor: 12.11) , that
are given "for the
common
(1 Cor: 12.7) , and that they are all to be used for
edification'
(1 Cor: 14.26), or for
up the church:
Spiritual Gifts in the History of Redemption: Certainly the Holy Spirit
Will
iment
teaching:
they
good"
building
was ar work in the Old Testament;
people to faith and working in
remarkable ways in
few individuals such as Moses or Samuel, David or
Elijah But in general there was less powerful activity of the
Spirit in the
lives of most believers.
Effective
evangelism of the nations had been
diminished, casting out of demons
was unknown, miraculous
healing was
uncommon (though it did happen; especially in the ministries of Elijah and
Elisha) , prophecy was restricted t0
few prophets or small bands of prophets_
and
resurection
over sin in the sense of Romans 6.1-14 and
Philippians 3:10 was rarely experienced
But at severa
points the Old Testament looks forward t0
time
there would be
greater empowering of the Holy Spirit that
would reach t0 all of God's people
Moses said,
Would that all the
LORD
people were prophets_
that the LORD would put his spirit

And

pass afterward,

Even upon the menservants and maidservants
in those days,
will pour out my spirit: (Joel 2.28-29)
John the Baptist heightens people'$ expectations of the fulfillment of Joel'$
prophecy when he announces that someone
after him who "will
baptize YOu with the Holy Spirit and
fire
(Matt %1l; cf. Mark 1.8;

When Jesus begins his ministry he comes bringing the fullness and
power of the

And Jesus

(Luke 4.14). The

the Holy Spirit; and he has come t0 conquer Satan
kingdom:
bringing
Holy
power"
when
coming
with
Holy

The

But this new covenant power of the Holy Spirit is not limited to the

"Heal the sick; raise

cast out demons" (Matt: 10.7-8).
Nevertheless, this new covenant power of the Holy Spirit is nOt yet

The pouring out of the Holy Spirit in new covenant fullness and

not [0

but

recognized that the new

This Jesus God raised Up, and of that we are all witnesses. Being

which YOu see and hear: (Acts 2.32-33)
Against the background of Jesus' ministry and the earlier ministry

fact;

The Apostolic Church was characteristically

2. The Purpose of Spiritual Gifts in the New Testament Age: Spiritual gifts
are given t0 equip the church t0 carry out its ministry until Christ returns
Paul tells the Corinthians
You
not lacking in any spiritual gift; as you
wait for tne revealing of our Lord Jesus Christ
Cor: 1.7) . Here he
connects the
possession of spiritual gifts and their situation in the history of
redemption (waiting for Christ' $ retum), suggesting that gifts are given tO the
church for the period berween Christ $ ascension and his return. Similarly;
Paul looks forward tO the time of Christ'$ return and says, "When the perfect
comes
the
imperfect will pass away" (1 Cor: 13:10), indicating also that these
"imperfect" gifts (mentioned in vv: 8-9)
be in operation until Christ
returns
when they will be superseded by
something far greater:
Indeed
the
pouring out of the Holy Spirit in "power" at Pentecost (Acts 1:8) was to equip
the church
preach the gospel
(Acts 1.8)
-something that
continue until
Christ returns_
And Paul reminds believers that
their use of spiritual gifts
they are to
strive [0 excel
building up the church" (1Cor: 14.12). Finally;
to the Ephesians_
Paul specifies that when Christ ascended into
heaven he gave gifts "to equip the saints for the work of ministry; for building
up the body of Christ" (Eph: 4.12).
But spiritual gifts not only
the church for the time until Christ
returns, they also give
foretaste of the age
come. Paul reminds
the Corinthians that they were
enriched" in all their speech and all
facl,
Ore
will
will

equip
their knowledge, and that the result of this

were
not lacking in any spiritual gift" (1 Cor: 1:5, 7). Of course,

heaven; but only
foretaste or down payment of that heavenly
perfection. Similarly, Paul reminds the Corinthians that spiritual
gifts are "imperfect" but when the
perfect" way of knowing comes
at the Lord $ retum; then these gifts will pass away (1 Cor: 13.10)
Just as the Holy Spirit himself is in this age
"down payment"
Cor: 1.22 NASB mg_
cf. 2 Cor: 5.5; Eph: 1:14) of the fuller work
of the Holy Spirit within US in the age tO come, s0 the gifts the Holy

working of the
Holy Spirit that :-
be OuIs in the age

In this way; gifts of insight and discernment prefigure the much

Gifts of
give

Even the diversity

in heaven:

the church

concerned arise when
want the extraordinary and
exceptional t0 be made the frequent and habitual. Let all who develop
excessive desire for "messages
through the gifts take warning from
the
of past generations as well as of contemporaries
The Holy Scriptures are
amp unto our feet and
light unto our
On the other hand, even among very Reformed cessationists, there
willingness
admit some kind of continuing "illumination" by
the Holy Spirit in believers
lives. For example, Westminster
Seminary professor Richard Gaffin says,
Often; [00,
what is seen as prophecy
actually
spontaneous; Spirit-
worked application of Scripture_
more or less sudden grasp of the
bearing that biblical teaching has on
particular situation or problem_
AlL Christians need
be open
these more spontaneous workings of
the Spirit
And Robert Reymond defines illumination as "the Holy Spirit $ enabling of
Christians generally tO understand
recall to mind, and to apply the
Scriptures they have studied_
But if these writers will allow for the present activity of the Holy
Spirit
enabling Christians to
understand" or "recall to mind" or
apply" or
grasp
the
teachings of Scripture
then there does nOt
seem [0 be such
great difference in principle between what they
are saying and what many in the charismatic movement are doing
(even though there will probably be some remaining differences
over the precise way guidance functions
yer this is nOt SO much
difference about prophecy as about
guidance generally and
particularly the way guidance from Scripture relates
guidance
from advice_
counsel, conscience, circumstances, sermons, etc.).
The
larger point is that what Gaffin and Reymond here call
kept
gifts ,
wreckuage _
path
"illumination;
the New Testament seems t0 call
"revelation;
and
what they would call
spoken report of such illumination, the New
Testament seems t0 call
prophecy:
wonder if there may be room for more joint theological
reflection in this area. Charismatics need t0 realize that cessationists
skeptical about the scope and
frequency of such "illumination;
whether it is right to call it New Testament prophecy; whether it
really does have value for the church, and whether
should be
sought after: And cessationists need to realize that their Own highly
developed and carefully formulated doctrine of the sufficiency of
Scripture in
guidance is not usually shared or even understood by
much of evangelicalism, including those in the charismatic
movement. Nevertheless, perhaps the Reformed idea of
"illumination'
allows for what is happening in prophecy today; and
may provide
way of understanding
that is not seen as
challenging the sufficiency of Scripture
What shall we
conclude then about the relationship between the gift
of prophecy and the sufficiency of Scripture? We must say that we
appreciate the desire of the cessationists
protect the uniqueness
of Scripture and not t0 allow
anything to compete with the authority
of Scripture in our lives.
We also must be thankful for the desire of
cessationists that Christians understand and follow sound principles
of guidance in their daily lives
and not get off into an area of
excessive subjectivism that does not have the controls of Scripture
attached t0 it On the other hand, there is certainly
danger that
comes with the cessationist viewpoint
it is wrong here. It is the
very real
danger of opposing something that God is
in the
church
and failing t0 give him glory for that work God is
jealous for his works and seeks glory from them for himself, and

continually pray not only that he would keep us from
endorsing error; but also that he would
uS from opposing
something that
genuinely from him:
Were Miraculous Gifts Limited to the Apostles and Their
Companions? Another cessationist argument is that miraculous gifts were
limited t0 the apostles and their close companions. Since
have discussed this
argument
length in chapter 17_
will not repeat the discussion here_
Did Miraculous Gifts Only Accompany the Giving of New Scripture?
Another objection is tO say that miraculous gifts accompanied the giving of
doing
today
keep
Scripture_
and since there is no new Scripture given today; we should expect
no new miracles today:
But in response t0 that
must be said that this is not the only
purpose for miraculous gifts.
As we noted in chapter 17, miracles
have several other purposes in Scripture: (1) they authenticate the
gospel message throughout the church age; (2)
give help t0
those in need_
and thereby demonstrate God'$ mercy and love; (3)
they
people for ministry; and (4) they glorify God.
We should also note that not all miracles accompany the giving of
additional Scripture. For example_
the ministries of Elijah and
Elisha were marked by several miracles in the Old Testament; but
wrote no books or sections of the Bible: In the New Testament;
there were many occurences of miracles that were not
accompanied by the giving of Scripture_
Both Stephen and Philip in
the book of Acts worked miracles but wrote no Scripture: There
were prophets who wrote no Scripture in Caesarea (Acts 21.4) and
Tyre (Acts 21.9-1) and Rome (Rom: 12.6) and Thessalonica
Thess. 5.20-21) and Ephesus (Eph 411) and the communities t0
which
John was written
John 4.1-6).
There were apparently
many miracles in the churches of Galatia (Gal. 3.5). There were
many miraculous things occuring at Corinth (1 Cor: 12.8-10) , but
Corinthians 14.36 Paul denies that any Scripture has come
forth from the Corinthian church:
And James expects that
will occur at the hands of the elders in all the churches t0 which he
writes (see James 5.14-16).
5. Is It a Historical Fact That Miraculous Gifts Ceased Early in the
History of the Church? Some cessationists have argued that miraculous gifts
in fact ceased when the apostles died
because the purpose of miracles was t0
give authentication to the apostles
For this reason, it is
argued, there should
be no miraculous gifts today. B. B Warfield argued this extensively in his
book; Counterfeit Miracles
In response_
it must
be said first that the premise just stated
doubtful on historical grounds_
There
increasing historical
evidence
that miraculous gifts were
occurring throughout the
history of the church in
lesser
even when
exaggerated or evidently spurious claims are discounted.
and other kinds of miraculous answers t0 prayer are often recorded_
they
equip
they
healing
vely
degree;
greater
Healings
There were also people
claiming
to be prophets throughout the
history of the early church
-the
problem was that tOo often they
misunderstood their gift;
others misunderstood it; S0 that their
Mtterances
were (mistakenly) treated like actual words of God:
Sometimes they would be tolerated, and sometimes they were tOo
much
threat t0 the established leadership of the churches and
would begin splinter groups
tragically, no longer under the
restraining
and
evaluating authority of the established churches
Then t00_
others may have had
revelations'
given [O them which
they then did not express
or simply included without comment in
prayer; Or in
sermon 0r word of exhortation, Or in the
of a
hymn Or" some devotional literature.
should also be clear that when Paul said, "When the perfect
comes, the
imperfect will pass away" (1 Cor: 13.10) , he was not
saying anything about the relative frequency of miraculous gifts in
the history of the church:
That would be subject to much variation
depending
the spiritual maturity and vitality of the church in
various periods, the degree
which these gifts were sought as
blessing
rejected as
heresy; the frequency with which the
meetings of the church normally made provision for the exercise of
these gifts, the degree tO which the nature of these gifts was
correctly understood, and, over all of this_
the Holy Spirit's
sovereign work in
distributing gifts to the church.
What Paul is speaking about; however; is the total and final
abolition of these gifts that is to be brought about by divine
initiative at the return of Christ. And he is saying that he thinks that
until the time of the return of Christ these gifts will at least tO some
extent remain available for use_
and the
Spirit will continue t0
distribute these gifts t0 people_
Calvin notes the abundance 0f
spiritual gifts in Paul?
and then comments (on
Cor: 14.32):
Today
ouI own slender resources,
poverty in fact; but this
undoubtedly the punishment we deserve
as the reward fOL our
ingratitude. For God s riches are not exhausted
nor has His liberality
grown less; but we are not worthy of His largess,
capable of
receiving all that He generously gives.
6. Are Miraculous Gifts Today the Same As the Miraculous Gifts in
Scripture? Yet another objection to the continuation of miracles today is to
say that the
alleged miracles today are not like the miracles in Scripture
they
wtiting
Holy -
day
because they are far weaker and often are only partially effective_
In response
to this objection we must ask whether
really matters whether the miracles
today are exactly as powerful as those that occurred at the time of the
Testament. For one
we have very little information about the kind of
miracles done by ordinary Christians in various congregations, such as the
Christians at Corinth Or in the churches in Galatia:
Moreover; although
remarkable miracles done by Jesus are recorded in the gospels_
when Jesus
healed
every disease and every infirmity" (Matt: 9.35,
this must have
included many with less serious diseases_
We muSt also ask whar the expected
benefit is for the objection that miracles today are not as powerful as those in
Scripture. If today only three hundred are converted at an
evangelistic
meeting instead of the three thousand converted on the
of Pentecost (Acts
2.41), shall we say that the speaker does not really have the gift of
evangelism, since the gift did not operate as powerfully as it did with the
apostles? Or if only 30 percent of the people we pray for
regarding physical
illness are fully healed instead of 100 percent in the life of Jesus 0r of the
apostles, shall we say this
not the New Testament
gift of healing?
We
must remember that gifts can vary in strength and no gift is perfect in this age.
But does that mean that we should stop using these gifts altogether; Or oppose
them where we see them functioning with some degree of effectiveness? Shall
we not
praise God if 300 are converted rather than three thousand, 0r if 30
percent are healed rather than 100 percent of those for whom we pray? Is not
the work of the Lord being done?
quantity
not as great as in New
Testament times, then we may ask the Lord for more grace Or mercy; but it
does not seem
appropriate
give up on the use of these gifts Or to oppose
those who do use them:
7. Is It Dangerous for
Church to Allow for the Possibility of Miraculous
Gifts Today? A final objection from the cessationist position is t0 say that _
church that emphasizes the use of miraculous gifts is in danger of becoming
imbalanced
and will likely neglect other important
such as
evangelism, sound doctrine, and moral purity of life:
To say that the use of miraculous
is "dangerous" is not by
itself an adequate criticism; because some things that are right are
dangerous
at least in some sense_
Missionary work is dangerous
Driving
is dangerous_
If we define dangerous
MEdl
something might go wrong-
then
we can criticize anything that
anybody might do as
dangerous
and this just becomes an all-
purpose criticism when there is no specific abuse
point t0_
better approach with respect tO spiritual gifts is t0 ask; "Are they
used in accordance with Scripture?" and
Are adequate steps
New
thing:
day
Lf the
things
gifts .
car
being
being taken t0 guard
the dangers of abuse?
Of course it is tnue that churches can become imbalanced, and some
in fact have done S0
But not all will, nor do
have
do so_
Furthermore, since this argument is one based on actual results in
the life of
church; it is also appropriate to ask;, "Which churches in
the world today have the most effective
evangelism? Which have
the most sacrificial giving among their members? Which in fact
have the most emphasis 0n purity of life? Which have the deepest
love for the Lord and for his Word?" It seems t0
that it is
difficult to answer these questions clearly; but
do not think that we
can fairly say that those churches in the charismatic and Pentecostal
movements by and
are weaker in these areas than other
evangelical churches In fact, in some cases they may be stronger in
these areas.
The point is simply that any argument that says that
churches emphasizing miraculous gifts will become imbalanced is
simply not proven
actual
practice:
8. A Final Note: Cessationists and Charismatics Need Each Other: Finally;
it can be
that those
the charismatic and Pentecostal camps, and
those
the cessationist camp (primarily Reformed and dispensational
Christians) really need each other; and they would do well to appreciate each
other more_
The former tend to have more practical experience in the use of
spiritual gifts and in vitality in worship that cessationists could benefit
if they
#ere
willing
learn_
On the other hand, Reformed and dispensational
groups have traditionally been very strong in
understanding of Christian
doctrine and
deep and accurate understanding of the teachings of Scripture_
Charismatic and Pentecostal
groups could
leamn much from them if they
would be
[0 do so_
But it certainly is not helpful to the church as
whole for both sides t0 think
can learn
from the other; Or that
they can gain no benefit from fellowship with each other:

Chapter 52
Gifts of the Holy Spirit:
(Part 2)
Specific Gifts
How should we understand and
use
specific spiritual gifts?
EAFL
ANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
In this chapter we will build on the general discussion about
spiritual gifts in the previous chapter and examine several specific
gifts in more detail
We will not consider every gift mentioned in
the New Testament; but will focus on several gifts that are not well
understood or whose use has aroused some controversy
today:
Therefore we will not examine gifts whose
meaning and use are
self-evident from the term involved (such as serving; encouraging
contributing; showing leadership_
or showing mercy) , but will
rather concentrate 0n those in the
following list, primarily taken
from
Corinthians 12.28 and 12.8-10:
prophecy
miracles
tongues and interpretation
word of wisdom' word of knowledge
distinguishing between spirits
Proplci
Although several definitions have been given for the gift of
prophecy;
fresh examination of the New Testament teaching on
teaching
healing
this gift will show that
should be defined not as
predicting the
future,
nor as
proclaiming
word from the Lord
nor as
powerful preaching'
but rather as "telling something that God
has spontaneously brought to mind
The first four points in the
following material support this conclusion; the remaining points
deal with other considerations regarding this gift:
The New Testament Counterparts to Old Testament: Prophets Are
New 'Testament Apostles. Old Testament prophets had an amazing
responsibility
they were able to speak and write words that had absolute
divine authority. They could say; "Thus says the Lord
and the words that
followed were the very words of God: The Old Testament prophets wrote
their words as God's words in Scripture for all time (see Num 22.38; Deut:
18.18-20; Jer: 1.9; Ezek: 2.7; et al.)
Therefore; t0 disbelieve or disobey
prophet's words was to disbelieve 01
disobey God (see Deut: 18.19;
Sam:
8.7;
Kings 20.36; and many other passages).
In the New Testament there were also people who
and wrote
God's very words and had them recorded in Scripture, but
may
be surprised to find that Jesus no longer calls them
prophets
buc
uses
new term;
apostles:
The apostles are the New Testament
counterpart t0 the Old Testament prophets (see
Cor: 2.13;
Cor:
13.3; Gal: 1.8-9; 11-12; 2 Thess. 12.13; 4.8,15;
Peter 3.2). It is
the apostles_
not the prophets_
who have authority [0 write the
words of New Testament Scripture.
When the apostles want
establish their unique authority they
appeal
the title
"prophet" but rather call themselves
apostles'
(Rom_
1:1;
Cor: 1.1; 9.1-2; 2 Cor: 1.1; 11.12-13;
12.11-12; Gal: 1:1; Eph 1:1;
Peter 1.1; 2 Peter 1:1; 3.2; et al.)
2. The Meaning of the Word Prophet in the Time of the New Testament:
Why did Jesus choose the new term apostle to designate those who had the
authority t0 write Scripture? It was probably because the Greek word
prophetes
"prophet"
at the time of the New Testament had
broad
range of
It generally did not have the sense
one who
God $
very words" but rather
one who
on the basis of some exteral
influence'
(often
spiritual influence of some kind)
1.12 uses the word
in this sense_
where Paul quotes the pagan Greek poet Epimenides:
One of
themselves,
prophet of their Own
said,
Cretans are always liars_
evil beasts_
lazy gluttons
The soldiers who mock Jesus also seem
use the word
prophesy in this way; when they blindfold Jesus and cruelly demand
spoke
never.
very
meanings.
speaks
speaks
Titus
"Prophesy! Who is it that struck
(Luke 22.64)
do not mean,
"Speak words of absolute divine authority;'
but,
Tell us something that has
been revealed tO
(cf: John 419).
Many
outside the Bible use the word prophet (Gk:
prophetes) in this way; without signifying any divine authority
the words of one called
'prophec
In fact; by the time of the New
Testament the term prophet in everyday use often simply meant
one who has supernatural knowledge
one who predicts the
future'
Or' even
just
spokesman'
(without any connotations of
divine authority). Several examples near the time of the New
Testament are given in Helmu Krimer"
article in Theological
Dictionary of the New Testament:
A philosopher is called "a prophet of immortal nature
(Dio
Chrysostom, AD. 40-120)
reacher
(Diogenes) wants to be
prophet of truth and candor"
(Lucian of Samosata_
A.DJ
120-180)
who advocale
Epicurean philosophy are called "prophets of
Epicurus
(Plutarch; A.D: 50-120)
Written history is called "the prophetess of truth" (Diodorus Siculus
wrole
60-30 BC.)
A "specialist" in botany is called
"prophet'
(Dioscurides of Cilicia_
first century AD)
quack" in medicine is called
"prophet
(Galen of Pergamum,
AD. 129-199)
Kramer concludes that the Greek word for
prophet" (prophetes) "simply
expresses the formal function of declaring; proclaiming;
Known_
Yet;
because "every prophet declares something which is not his Own,
the Greek
word for "herald" (keryx) "is the closest synonym:
Of course; the words prophet and prophecy were sometimes used of
the apostles
contexts that emphasized the external spiritua
influence (from the Holy Spirit) under which they
(so Rev:
1.3; 22.7; and Eph: 2.20; 3.5),
but this was not the
ordinary
terminology used for the apostles
nor did the terms prophet and
vou?"
They
You'
writings
Those
making
spoke
prophecy in themselves imply divine authority for their speech or
writing: Much more commonly; the words prophet and prophecy
were used of
ordinary Christians who spoke not with absolute
divine authority; but simply to report
something that God had laid
on their hearts or brought t0 their minds_
There are many
indications in the New Testament that this ordinary gift of prophecy
had authority less than that of the Bible, and even less than that of
recognized Bible
in the early church; as
evident from the
following section.
3. Indications 'That
Prophets
Did Not Speak With Authority Equal to
the Words of Scripture:
Acts 21:4: In Acts 21:4,we read of the disciples at Tyre:
Through the
Spirit they told Paul not tO go on tO Jerusalem
This seems t0 be
reference
to prophecy directed towards Paul, but Paul disobeyed it! He never would
have done this if this prophecy contained God $ very words and had authority
equal to Scripture_
Acts 21:40-H: Then in Acts 21.10-41_
Agabus prophesied that the Jews at
Jerusalem would bind Paul and "deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles
prediction that was nearly correct but not quite: the Romans_
not the Jews,
bound Paul (v 33; also 22.29),
and the Jews, rather than delivering him
voluntarily, tried t0 kill him and he had to be rescued by force
32).
The
prediction was not far off, but it had inaccuracies in detail that would have
called into question the validity of any Old Testament prophet: On the other
hand, this text could be perfectly well explained by supposing that Agabus
had had
vision of Paul as
prisoner of the Romans in Jerusalem, surrounded
by an angry mob of Jews
His own interpretation of such .
vision'
"revelation
from the Holy Spirit would be that the Jews had bound Paul and
handed him over t0 the Romans, and that is what Agabus would (somewhat
erroneously) prophesy: This is exactly the kind of fallible prophecy that
would fit the definition of New Testament congregational prophecy proposed
above
reporting in one
own words something that God has spontaneously
brought to mind
One objection t0 this view is to say that Agabus' prophecy was in
fact fulfilled_
and that Paul even reports that in Acts 28.17: "[ was
delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
But the verse itself will not support that interpretation. The Greek
teaching
text of Acts 28.17 explicitly refers to Paul's transfer out of
Jerusalem as
prisoner:
Therefore Paul $ statement describes his
transfer Out of the Jewish judicial system (the Jews were seeking t0
him again to be examined by the Sanhedrin in Acts 23.15,20)
and into the Roman judicial system at Caesarea (Acts 23.23-35).
Therefore Paul correctly says in Acts 28.18 that the same Romans
into whose hands he had been delivered as
prisoner (v 17) were
the ones who (Gk: hoitines
18) , "When
had examined me
wished to set me at liberty; because there was no reason for the
death penalty in my case
(Acts 28.18; cf: 23.29; also 25.11, 18-19;
26.31-32). Then Paul adds that when the Jews objected he was
compelled "to appeal to Caesar" (Acts 28.19; cf. 25.11). This whole
narrative in Acts 28.17-19 refers t0 Paul' $ transfer OUt of Jerusalem
t0 Caesarea in Acts 23.12-35_
and explains t0 the Jews in Rome
why Paul is in Roman custody The narrative does not refer t0 Acts
21.27-36 and the mob scene near the Jerusalem temple at all. So
this objection is nOt persuasive_
The verse does not point t0 a
fulfillment of either half of Agabus' prophecy:
does not mention
any
binding by the Jews_
does it mention that the Jews handed
Paul over [0 the Romans_
In fact; in the scene
refers to (Acts
23.12-35), once again Paul had just been taken from the Jews "by
force
(Acts 23:10), and, far from seeking to hand him over t0 the
Romans_
they were waiting in an ambush to kill him (Acts 23.13
15).
Another objection t0 my understanding of Acts 21:10-I is t0 say
that the Jews did not really have
bind Paul and deliver him into
the hands of the Gentiles for the prophecy of Agabus to be true
because the Jews were responsible for these activities even if -
did not canry them Out: Robert Thomas says, "It is common to
speak of the responsible party Or parties as performing an act even
though he or they may not have been the immediate agent(s) "@
Thomas cites similar examples from Acts 2.23 (where Peter says
that the Jews crucified Christ; whereas the Romans actually did it)
and John 19:1 (we read that Pilate scourged Jesus
whereas his
soldiers no doubt carried out the action). Thomas concludes;
therefore;, "the Jews were the ones who put Paul
chains just as
Agabus predicted_
In response_
agree that Scripture can speak of someone as doing
an act that is carried out by that person'$ agent But in every case
bring
they
they
the person who is said to do the action both wills the act to be done
and gives directions [0 Others t0 do it: Pilate directed his soldiers to
scourge Jesus. The Jews actively demanded that the Romans would
crucify Christ: By contrast; in the situation of Paul's capture in
Jerusalem, there is no such parallel. The Jews did not order him t0
be bound but the Roman tribune did it:
the tribune came up
and arrested him; and ordered him t0 be bound with two chains"
(Acts 21.33). And in fact the parallel form of speech is found here;
because, although the tribune ordered Paul to be bound
later
read that
the tribune also was afraid, for he realized that Paul was
Roman citizen and that he had bound him-
(Acts 22.29). So this
narrative does speak of the
as done either by the
responsible agent or by the people who carried
out, but in both
cases these are Romans
not Jews. In summary; this objection says
that the Jews put Paul in chains.
But Acts says twice that the
Romans bound him: This objection says that the Jews tumed Paul
over t0 the Gentiles
But Acts says that
violently refused [0
turn him over; s0 that he had to be taken from them by force: The
objection does not fit the words of the text:
Thessalonians 5.19-21: Paul tells the Thessalonians
do not despise
prophesying; but test everything; hold fast what is
(1 Thess. 5.20-21)
If the Thessalonians had thought that prophecy equaled God's Word in
authority; he would never have had to tell the Thessalonians not to despise it
received" and "accepted" God's Word
with joy from the
Spirit"
Thess_
1.6; 2.13; cf. 415). But when Paul tells them to
test
everything'
must include at least the prophecies he mentioned in the
previus phrase_
He implies that prophecies contain some
that are
good
and some
that are not
good when he encourages them to "hold fast
what is good.
This is something that could never have been said of the words
of an Old Testament prophet; or the authoritative
New
Testament apostle:
Corinthians 14:29-38: More extensive evidence on
Testament
prophecy is found in
Corinthians 14
When Paul says, "Let tWo or three
prophets speak; and let the others weigh what is said"
Cor: 14.29), he
suggests that they should listen carefully and sift the
from the bad;
accepting
sume

here translated
weigh what is said")
We cannot imagine that

say

what yOu accept from

If prophecy had absolute divine authority;
#Then

they
good"

Holy
things
things_
teachings
New
good

But here Paul commands that it be done, suggesting

Corinthians 14.30, Paul allows one prophet to interrupt another
one:
revelation is made
another sitting by, let the first be

Again, if prophets had
been speaking God $ very words_
equa_
in value to Scripture; it is

Paul suggests that no one at Corinth;

All these passages indicate that the common idea that prophets

not present in

Apostolic Preparations for Their Absence: In addition t0 the verses
have considered so far; one other type of evidence suggests that New

spirit

The Doctrine of the Future

Chapter 54
The Return of Christ: When and How?
When and how will Christ return? Could he come back at any
hour?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
As we begin the final
unit of this book, we turn
consider events
that
happen in the future. The study of future events
often
called
eschatology;
from the Greek word eschatos_
which means
"last.
The study of
eschatology; then, is the study of "the last
things_
Unbelievers can make reasonable predictions about future events
based on patterns of past occurrences, but in the nature of human
experience it is clear that human beings of themselves cannot know
the fucure_
Therefore unbelievers can have no certain
knowledge of
any future event: But Christians who believe the Bible are in a
different situation. Although
Lammol
know everything about the
future; God knows everything about the future and he has in
Scripture told us about the major events yet t0 come in the history
of the universe_
About these events occuring we can have absolute
confidence because God is never wrong and never lies_
Regarding
our wn personal
future as individuals,
we nave
already
discussed the teaching of Scripture in chapter 41 (on death and the
intermediate state) and chapter 42 (on glorification) The study of
these future events that will happen t0 individuals
sometimes
called
personal eschatology:
But the Bible also talks about
certain major events that will affect the entire universe. Specifically;
it tells us about the second coming of Christ, the millennium; the
final judgment; eternal punishment for unbelievers and eternal
reward for believers_
and life with God in the new heaven and new
earth: The study of these events is sometimes called
general
eschatology:
In this chapter we will study the question of the
return of
Christ, or his
second coming
Subsequent chapters will
Will
deal with the
remaining topics in
study of the last
There have been many debates

-in the
of the church over questions regarding the future

with which all

disagreement: whether Christ could return atany time. Then in the
following chapter
will discuss the question of the millennium;
topic that has long been
source of disagreement among Christians.

Do Christians in fact eagerly long for Christ'$ return? The more

Severa)

It is simply an evasion of the force of those passages
say that we

at an hour you

not necessarily

we should be ready at all times for him tO return:
The practical result of this is that anyone who claims to know

on which Christ will retur
from whatever source
-should be

AlI Evangelicals Agree 0n the Final Results of Christ'$ Return
No matter what their differences on the details; all Christians who
take the Bible as their final authority agree that the final and
ultimate result of Christ'$ return will be the judgment of unbelievers
and the final reward of believers, and that believers will live with
Christ in
new heaven and
new earth for all eternity. God the
Father; Son, and Holy Spirit will reign and will be worshiped in
never-ending kingdom with no more sin Or SOrTOw Or"
suffering_

Why do You think Jesus decided to leave the world for
time and then
return, rather than staying on earth after his resurection and
preaching
the gospel throughout the world himself?
Do you nOw eagerly
for Christ $ retum? Have YOu had
greater
longing for it in the past? If you do not have
very strong yearning for
Christ'$ return, what factors in your life do you think contribute to that
lack of longing?
Have You ever decided not t0 undertake
term project because yOu
thought Christ'$ return was near? Do you have any hesitancy now about
term projects because of that reason? If so, do you think that
hesitancy has any negative consequences on
life?
Are you ready for Christ tO return today? If you knew he were going to
return within 24 hours, what situations Or relationships would you want
straighten out before he retumed? Do yOu think that the command to
"be ready" means that you should attempt t0 straighten out those things
nOw; even
You think it unlikely that he would return today?

Chapter 55
The Millennium
What is the millennium? When does it occur? Will Christians go
through the Great Tribulation?
EXPLANATION AND SCRIPTURAL BASIS
The word millennium means
one thousand years'
(from Lat:
millennium; "thousand years'
The term comes from Revelation
20.4-
where
says that certain people
came
life, and reigned
with Christ
thousand years. The rest of the dead did not come tO
life until the thousand years were ended_
Just prior t0 this
stalement;
read that an angel
came down from heaven and
seized the devil
and bound him for
thousand years, and threw
him into the pit; and shut it and sealed it over him, that he should
deceive the nations nO more_
till the thousand years were ended"
(Rev: 20.2-3)
Throughout the history of the church there have been three major
views On the time and nature of this
millennium.
Exuhanation of tlz Thrt
Victar
Amillennialism: The first view to be explained here, amillennialism; is
really the simplest: It can be pictured as in figure 55.1:
ANILLENNIAVSN
churchaGL
EterNaL State
NOLUTIHLULNALIN
Z0-1-n
ANILLCNNIALSY
Fiyure 55.
Naret
According
this position the passage in Revelation 20:1-10
describes the present church age. This is an age in which Satan'$
influence over the nations has been greatly reduced s0 that the
gospel can be preached to the whole world_
Those who are said [0
be reigning with Christ fOr the thousand years are Christians who
have died and are already reigning with Christ in heaven_
Christ'$
reign in the millennium; according t0 this view; is nOt
bodily reign
here on earth but rather the heavenly reign he
of when he
said, "All authority in heaven and on earth has been given t0 me
(Matt. 28.18).
This view is called
amillennial" because
maintains that there is
no future millennium yet tO come. Since amillennialists believe that
Revelation 20 is nOw being fulfilled in the church age
they hold
that the
millennium
described there
curently happening:
The
exact duration of the church age cannot be known; and the
expression "thousand years
is simply
figure of speech for
long
period of time in which God'$ perfect purposes will be
accomplished
According
this position, the present church age will continue
until the time of Christ'$ retum (see figure 55.1). When Christ
returns_
there will be
resurrection of both believers and
unbelievers- The bodies of believers will rise t0 be reunited with
their spirits and enter into full enjoyment of heaven forever:
Unbelievers will be raised t0 face the final judgment and eternal
condemnation. Believers will also stand before the judgment seat of
Christ (2 Cor: 5.10) , but this judgment
only determine degrees
of reward in heaven; for only unbelievers will be condemned
eterally At this time also the new heavens and new earth will
begin. Immediately after the final judgment, the eternal state will
commence and continue forever:
This scheme
quite simple because all of the end time events
happen at once, immediately after Christ $ retum. Some
amillennialists say that Christ could return at any time_
while others
(such as Berkhof) argue that certain signs have yet to be fulfilled.
2. Postmillennialism: The prefix post- means
after:
According to this view;
Christ will return after the millennium. The postmillennial view may be
represented as in figure 55.2.
spoke
will
According
to this view, the progress of the gospel and the growth of
the church
gradually increase, s0 that
larger and larger
proportion of the world's population will be Christians.
result;
there will be significant Christian influences 0n society; society will
more and more function according t0 God $ standards_
and
gradually
'millennial age'
of peace and righteousness will occur
on the earth_
This
millennium
will last for
period of time
(not necessarily
literal one thousand years), and finally; at the end
of this period, Christ will return t0 earth; believers and unbelievers
be raised_
the final judgment will occur; and there will be
new
heaven and new earth: We will then enter into the eternal state_

POSTHILLENNIRLISM
Fiuure 55.2
The primary characteristic of postmillennialism is that it is very
optimistic about the power of the gospel to change lives and bring
about much
in the world
Belief in postmillennialism tends to
increase
times when the church is experiencing
revival,
when there is an absence of war and international conflict; and
when
appears that great progress is being made in overcoming the
evil and suffering in the world. But postmillennialism in its most
responsible form is not based simply on the observation of events in
the world around us, but on arguments from various Scripture
passages, which will be examined below:
3. Premillennialism:
Classic or Historic Premillennialism: The prefix
pre -
means
~before;
and the "premillennial" position says that Christ will come back before the
millennium_
This viewpoint has
long history from the earliest centuries
onward. It may be represented aS in figure 55.3.
According
this viewpoint; the present church age will continue
until, as it nears the end,
time of great tribulation and
suffering
will
long
will
good
great
comes on the earth (T in the figure above stands for tribulation).
After that time of tribulation at the end of the church age, Christ
will return t0 earth to establish
millennial kingdom When he
comes
believers who have died will be raised from the dead,
their bodies will be reunited with their spirits, and these believers
will reign with Christ on earth for one thousand years:
Some
premillennialists take this to be
literab
one thousand years, and
others understand
symbolic expression for
period of
time
During this time
Christ will be physically present on the
earth in his resurrected body; and will reign as
over the entire
earth: The believers who have been raised from the dead_
and those
who were on earth when Christ returns
will receive glorified
resurection bodies that will never die, and in these resurrection
bodies
will live on the earth and reign with Christ. Of the
unbelievers who remain on earth, many (but not all) will turn to
Christ and be saved. Jesus will reign in perfect righteousness and
there will be peace throughout the earth: Many premillennialists
hold that the earth will be renewed and we will in fact see the new
heavens and new earth at this time (but it is not essential to
premillennialism
hold to this, for one could be
premillennialist
and hold that the new heavens and new earth will nOr occur until
after the
judgment) At the beginning of this time Satan will be

influence on the earth
the millennium (Rev: 20.1-3)

the earth_
