Although it is not specifically an argument in favor of
pretribulation position, it must also be noted that pretribulationists
then view the
teaching about the tribulation in Matthew 24 and the
wamings and encouragements given to believers in that situation as
applying to Jewish believers during the tribulation, and not
the
church generally:
In response t0 these arguments_
the following points may be made:
1. It is inconsistent with the New Testament descriptions of the
tribulation to say that all the
suffering that occurs =
that time
is specifically the result of the wrath of God. Much of the suffering
is due t0 the fact that "wickedness is multiplied" (Matt: 24.12) and
the fact that persecution of the church and opposition from Satan
greatly increases during this period
Of course all Christians
(whether Gentile or Jewish believers) will avoid the wrath of God
at all times_
but this does nOt mean they will avoid all suffering;
even in times of intense hardship.
The fact that Jesus tells faithful believers in the church in
Philadelphia (Rev: 3.10) that he will
them from the hour of
trial thar is
on the whole world is not strong enough
evidence t0 say that the entire church will be taken out of the world
before the tribulation. First; this statement is made t0 one specific
church (Philadelphia) and should not be applied t0 the whole
church
some future point in history. Moreover; "the hour of trial
which is coming on the whole
need
refer to the time of
the great tribulation, but more likely refers to
time of
suffering and persecution that would come upon the entire Roman
Empire or the entire inhabited world. Finally; the promise that the
church in Philadelphia will be guarded does not imply that they will
be taken out of the world, but simply that they will be
faithful
and will be
guarded from being harmed by that period of suffering
and testing:
3. It is no argument for the pretribulation view tO say that there
must be some people in
nonglorified bodies who will enter the
millennium; because (0n
posttribulational view) when Christ
comes at the end of the tribulation he will defeat all the forces
arrayed
him, but that does nOr mean he will kill or
annihilate all of them: Many will simply surrender without trusting
Christ; and will thus enter the millennium as unbelievers _

that precede his return. The position presented in the previous
chapter
~thar
unlikely but possible that the signs have been
fulfilled
-is also consistent with these ideas_
But
must be said that behind this argument of pretribulationists is
probably
more fundamental concern: the desire to preserve
distinction between the church (which they think will be taken up
into heaven t0 be with Christ) and Israel (which they think will
constitute the people of God on earth during the tribulation and then
during the millennial kingdom) But; as we noted in an earlier
chapter;
the
Testament does not support
distinction of this
kind between Israel
and the church:
Hence
does not imply
need
[O see
distinction between these groups at the time of the
tribulation and the millennium:
There is
variation of the pretribulation rapture position that is
known as the midtribulation rapture view: It is defended by
Gleason Archer in his essay;
Case for the Mid-Seventieth -
Week Rapture Position
He sees the tribulation as separated into
[WO halves_
The
three and
half years are characterized by the
wrath of man, and the church
present at that time: The second
three and
half years are characterized by the wrath of God, and
during that time the church is absent from the earth:
The primary
argument from Scripture to support
midtribulational rapture is the
fact that in Daniel 7.25,9.27
and 12.7 and 14, as well as in
Revelation 12.14, the seven
01 times indicated are cuL in half;
mentioning the interval of three and
half times or three and
half
days in
symbolic week, thus indicating
period of three and
half
years, after which God's people will be rescued from tribulation.
Another argument in favor of this position is that it gives
heightened sense of expectancy
Christ' $ retum; since three and
half years
shorter period of time than seven years_
However; though the passages in Daniel do speak of an interruption
of the seventieth week which Daniel predicts for the future, they do
not give any clear indication that mid-way through the week
during
New
"The

days
believers will be removed trom the earth:
It is also hard t0 see thal
the expectation of
three-and-a-half-year tribulation provides
much greater sense of imminence than does the expectation of
seven-year tribulation:
Finally; some objections to the pretribulational rapture position can
be stated in the form of arguments in favor of the posttribulational
rapture view (the historic premillennial view that Christ will retum
atter
period of tribulation on the earth):
The New Testament nowhere clearly says that the church will be
taken out of the world before the tribulation. If this significant event
were to happen; we might at least expect that explicit teaching t0
that effect would be found in the New Testament: Certainly Jesus
tells us that he will come again and take us t0 be with himself (John
14.3), and Paul tells us that we shall be caught up in the clouds to
meet the Lord in the air (1 Thess. 4:17), and that we shall be
changed in the twinkling of an eye and receive resurrection bodies
Cor: 15.51-52) , but each of these passages has been understood
by believers throughout history as speaking not of
secret rapture
of the church before the tribulation_

of the fact thar the church

Thess. 4.16). Of these words Leon Morris

Cor: 15.52) , then

come: He tells them

does it seem likely
that the disciples are here as representatives of
future Jewish
kingdom and not as representatives of the church, with

(Eph: 2.20).
Finally, the New Testament does not seem

But it is nOt at all difficult t0 see these

seems best tO conclude, with the great majority of the church

Peter 4.14), and,

QUESTIONS FOR PERSONAL APPLICATION
Before reading this chapter; did you have any conviction about whether
Christ'$ return would be amillennial, postmillennial, Or premillennial?
And whether
would be posttribulational
pretribulational? If SO, how
has your view nOw changed, if at all?
Explain how your present view of the millennium affects your Christian
life today: Similarly, explain how your view of the tribulation affects
your present Christian life.
What do you think it will feel like to be living on earth with
glorified
body; and with Jesus Christ as King over the whole world? Can yOu
describe in any detail some of the attitudes and emotional responses YOU
will have toward various situations in such
kingdom? Do you really
look forward [0 such
kingdom? ( Your answers will differ somewhat
depending on whether YOu expect
glorified body during the millennium
or not until the eternal state_
What might be both the positive and the negative results of
pretribulation rapture
position in the everyday lives and attitudes of
Christians? Similarly; what might be the positive and negative results of
posttribulation rapture position?

Necexiry of Final Judenent

Appendix k:
Historic Confessions of Faith
This appendix reprints several of the most significant confessions of faith
from various periods in the history of the church_
From the ancient church
have included the four great ecumenical confessions: the Apostles' Creed
(third-fourth centuries
A.D.), the Nicene Creed (AD. 325/381), the
Athanasian Creed (late fourth-early fifth century A.D.); and the Chalcedonian
Creed (AD. 451). From the Protestant churches since the Reformation
have
included four other contessions_
the Thirty-nine Articles (1571) [Church of
England; also Methodist]; the Westminster Confession of Faith (1643-1646)
[British Reformed and Presbyterian]; the New Hampshire Baptist Confession
1833); and the Baptist Faith and Message (1925/1963) [Southern Baptist].
Finally;
have also included the
Statement on Biblical Inerrancy
(1978), because it was the product of
conference representing
broad
variety of evangelical traditions_
and because
has gained widespread
acceptance as
valuable doctrinal standard concerning an issue
recent and
current controversy in the church:
Because of space
limitations_
was able t0 include only one of the
confessions of faith that came out of the Reformation, and
chose the
Westminster Confession of Faith; which represents
doctrinal position very
close t0 the position of this book: This meant that
did not have space to
include either of the two great Lutheran confessions, the Augsburg
Confession (1530) or the Formula of Concord (1576).
Students who take the time
read these creeds thoughtfully will find that
they provide excellent summaries of the doctrinal teachings of Scripture:
Following
list of creed found in this appendix:
Apostles' Creed
Nicene Creed
Chalcedonian Creed
Athanasian Creed
Chicago
very
long
Thirty-nine Articles
Westminster Confession
New Hampshire Baptist Confession
Baptist Faith and Message
Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy

Whosoever will be saved: before all

And the Catholic Faith is this: That we worship one God in Trinity, and
Trinity in Unity;
Neither confounding the Persons: nor dividing the Substance:
For there is one Person of the Father: another of the Son: and another of
the Holy Spirit:
But the Godhead of the Father; of the Son, and of the

together

sins;

The Father eternal: the Son eternal: and the Holy Spirit eternal.
And yet
are nOr three eternals: but one eternal:
And also there are not three uncreated: nor three incomprehensibles_
but
one uncreated: and one incomprehensible.
So likewise the Father is Almighty: the Son Almighty: and the Holy
Spirit Almighty:
And yet
are not three Almighties: but one Almighty:
So the Father is God: the Son is God: and the Holy Spirit is God.
And yet
are nOr three Gods: but one God:
So likewise the Father is Lord: the Son Lord: and the
Spirit Lord:
And yet not three Lords: but one Lord_
For like as we are compelled by the Christian verity: to acknowledge
every Person by himself to be God and Lord:
So are we forbidden by the Catholic Religion:
say, There be three
Gods
three Lords
The Father is made of none: neither created, nor
begotten.
The Son is of the Father alone: nOr made;
nor created: but

created_
nor begotten: but

Holy Spirit; not three Holy Spirits_
And in this Trinity none
afore,
after another: none is greater; O1 less
than another:
But the whole three Persons are coeternal, and coequal:
So that in all things,
as aforesaid: the Unity in Trinity, and the Trinity in
Unity, is t0 be worshipped_
He therefore that will be saved, must thus think of the Trinity:

We believe that the Holy Bible was written by men divinely inspired, and is a
perfect treasure of heavenly instruction; that it has God for its author;

it reveals the principles by which God will judge us; and therefore is, and

THE CHICAGO STATEMENT ON
BIBLICAL INERRANCY
(1978)
PREFACE
The authority of Scripture is
key issue for the Christian Church in this and
every age. Those who profess faith in Jesus Christ as Lord and Savior are
called to show the reality of their discipleship by humbly and faithfully
obeying God's written Word. To stray from Scripture in faith or conduct is
disloyalty to our Master: Recognition of the total truth and trustworthiness of
Holy Scripture is essential tO
full grasp and adequate confession of its
authority:
The following Statement affirms this inerrancy of Scripture afresh; making
clear our understanding of it and warning against its denial. We are persuaded
that [0
it is t0 set aside the witness of Jesus Christ and of Holy Spirit and
[0 refuse that submission t0 the claims of God $ own word which marks tnue
Christian faith_
We see it as OUL timely
to make this affirmation in the
face of current lapses from the truth of inerrancy among our fellow Christians
and
misunderstanding of this doctrine in the world at
Statement consists of three parts:
Summary Statement; Articles of
Affirmation and Denial, and an accompanying Exposition. It has been
prepared in the course of
three-day consultation in Chicago. Those who
have signed the Summary Statement and the Articles wish to affirm their Own
conviction aS t0 the inerrancy of Scripture and to encourage and challenge
one another and all Christians to growing appreciation and
understanding of
this doctrine:
We acknowledge the limitations of
document prepared in a
brief, intensive conference and do not propose that this Statement be given
creedal weight
Yet we rejoice in the
deepening of our own convictions
through our discussions
together; and we pray that the Statement we have
signed may be used to the glory of our God toward
me
reformation of the
Church in its faith, life, and mission_
We offer this Statement in .
spirit, not of contention_
but of humility and love,
which we purpose by God's
maintain
any
future dialogue arising
out of what we have said. We
gladly acknowledge that many who deny the
inerrancy of Scripture do not display the consequences of this denial in the
rest of their belief and behavior; and we are conscious that we who confess
this doctrine often deny it in life by failing
bring our thoughts and deeds;
our traditions and habits, into tnue subjection t0 the divine Word_
deny
duty
large
This
grace
We invite responses t0 this statement from any who see reason t0 amend its
affirmations about Scripture by the light of Scripture itself, under whose
infallible authority we stand as we speak We claim no personal infallibility
for the witness we bear; and for any help which enables uS
strengthen this
testimony t0 God's Word we shall be grateful
SHORT STATEMENT
God, who is Himself Truth and speaks truth only; has inspired Holy
Scripture in order thereby to reveal Himself to lost mankind through Jesus
Christ as Creator and Lord, Redeemer and Judge_
Scripture is God $
witness t0 Himself:
2. Holy Scripture, being God's own Word_
written by men prepared and
superintended by His Spirit; is of infallible divine authority in all matters
upon which it touches: it is to be believed, as God s instruction, in all that it
affirms; obeyed_
as God $ command
in all that it requires; embraced_
God'$ pledge; in all that
promises_
3. The Holy Spirit; Scripture'$ divine Author; both authenticates it t0 us by
His inward witness and opens OUr minds tO understand its meaning
wholly and verbally God-given, Scripture is without error Or fault in
all its

the individual and the Church:

Appendix 4
Annotated Bibliography
of Evangelical Systematic Theologies
This bibliography lists most of the major evangelical systematic theologies
available in English and
few shorter
guides to Christian doctrine. With the
exception of the two Roman Catholic theologies (by McBrien and Ott) which
are included because
have cross-referenced them at the end of each chapter;
all of the authors on this list fall generally within
conservative evangelical"
theological position.
In the appendix following this bibliography
have added
master list of the
four Protestant and two Roman Catholic theologies which
Cross-
referenced at the end of each chapter:

vols. Vols_
and 2
trans. by James Nichols_
Vol:
translated by W: R Bagnell
Grand
Rapids: Baker; 1956_
Arminius (1560-1609) was
Reformed pastor in Amsterdam and
later professor of
at the University of Leyden: His
disagreement with some of the central
tenets of Calvinism led tO
controversy in the Netherlands which continued long after his
death_
His ideas became the foundation of
system of thought now
known as Arminianism; which continues today in conservative
Wesleyan and Methodist churches, and in many other Protestant
groups. This collection of writings, assembled after his death, is not
strictly organized as
systematic theology; but does contain
discussions of most important theologica
topics.

Appendix 6:
The Monogenes Controversy:
"Only" or "Only Begotten"?
(See Chapter 14, "God in Three Persons: The Trinity;
especially C.Z.a,
Arian Controversy;
in Chapter 12. See also the Nicene Creed in the
beginning of chapter 48.
The controversy over the term
only begotten'
was unnecessary because it
was based on
misunderstanding of the meaning of the Greek word
monogenems (used of Jesus in John 1:14, 18; 3.16, 18; and
John 4.9).
For many years it was thought to be derived from two Greek terms: mono_
meaning
only;
and gennao, meaning
beget" or "bear:
Even the received
version of the Nicene Creed understands
that way; since the explanatory
phrases
begotten of the Father before all worlds
and
"begotten, not made'
both use the verb gennao (beget) to explain monogenes_
But linguistic study
in the [wentieth
Lemluty
has shown that the second half of the word
nor
closely related to the verb gennao (beget; bear)
but rather [0 the term genos
(class; kind)_
Thus the word means rather the "one-of-a-kind" Son 0r the
unique'
Son. (See BAGD, 527; D. Moody; "The Translation of John 3.16 in
the Revised Standard Version;
JBL 72 [1953], 213-19.) The idea of
only-
begotten'
in Greek would have been, not monogenes_
but monogennetos_
However; it is not impossible that the Nicene fathers in AD.325 and 381
would have understood monogenes t0 include the idea of
begetting;
since
the word is used severa
times elsewhere
refer [0 someone who is an
only'
child
and the idea of begetting could commonly be assumed to be present
The fact that the word does not mean "the only son that someone has
begotten'
can be confirmed by
its use in Hebrews 11.17, where Isaac
is called Abraham'$ monogenes
but certainly Isaac was not the only son
Abraham had begotten, for he had also begotten Ishmael: The term there
means rather that Isaac was Abraham'$ "unique" sOn, that there was none
other like him. (The word elsewhere means
unique
with no idea of
begetting in view; in the
XX in Psalms 21[22].20; 34[35].17; Wisdom 7.22;
Clement 25.2
Thus the NIV translates John 3.16, "he
his one and
only Son;-
and the NA SB margin reads
O1, unique; only one of His kind
The
noticing
gave
The RSV translates,
he gave his only Son.
All of these versions have rightly
omitted any idea of "begetting
from the translation:
It is reassuring-
however; [0 see that even
though the early church had
misunderstanding of one biblical word_
the rest of Scripture came to the
defense of doctrinal purity and prevented the church from falling into the
error of Arianism (although the struggle consumed most of the fourth century
A.D.)
If the phrases "begotten of the Father before all worlds" and "begotten, not
made'
were not in the Nicene Creed, the phrase would only be of historical
interest [O US nOW; and there would be no need to talk of any doctrine of the
eternal begetting of the Son.
But since the phrase remains in
creed that is
still commonly used_
perpetuate the unfortunate necessity of having
explain tO every new
generation of Christians that "begotten of the Father"
has nothing t0 do with any other English sense of the word beget: It would
seem more helpful if the language of
eternal begetting of the Son" (also
called the
eternal generation of the Son'
were not retained in any modern
theological
formulations. Similarly; tO refer to Jesus as God's "only begotten'
Son
anguage that derives from the King James translation
seems
t0 be
more confusing than helpful. What is needed is simply that we insist on
eternal
personal differences in the relationship between Father; Son, and Holy
Spirit; and that the Son eterally relates
the Father as
son does t0 his
father:
(The fact that Jesus
said t0 be "bom of God" in
John 5.18
probably not
reference tO an eteral relationship, but rather refers to the incarnation when
Christ was born as
man; compare Acts 13.33; Hebrews 1.5.)
Finally; in previous discussions of what this
eterna_
begetting" might have
meant; it has been suggested that the Father has eternally been in some sense
the source of the distinctions in role among the Father; Son, and
Spirit
(e.g-, Louis Berkhof, Systematic Theology_
93-94). So
as we do not
assume that these personaE
distinctions had
beginning at some point in time
nothing in Scripture would seem
contradict this idea; but nothing in
Scripture would indicate that we should affirm it, either: Perhaps there is no
meaningful sense in which we should speak about any one of the persons
being
source"
of these personal distinctions
have always existed
and are essential to the nature of God himself:
